paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Thunder and lightning. Enter three WITCHES$NEWLINE$WITCHES
paragraphs.translated: Thunder and lightning. Three WITCHES enter$NEWLINE$WITCHES

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$When shall we three meet again?$NEWLINE$In thunder, lightning, or in rain?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$When should the three of us meet again? Will it be in thunder, lightning, or rain?

paragraphs.original: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$When the hurly-burly’s done,$NEWLINE$When the battle’s lost and won.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$We’ll meet when the noise of the battle is over, when one side has won and the other side has lost.

paragraphs.original: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$That will be ere the set of sun.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$That will happen before sunset.

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Where the place?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Where should we meet?

paragraphs.original: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Upon the heath.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Let’s do it in the open field.

paragraphs.original: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$There to meet with Macbeth.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$We’ll meet Macbeth there.
The WITCHES hear the calls of their spirit friends or “familiars,” which look like animals—one is a cat and one is a toad.$NEWLINE$WITCHES

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$I come, Graymalkin!
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$(calling to her cat) I’m coming, Graymalkin!$NEWLINE$(calling to her cat)

paragraphs.original: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Paddock calls.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$My toad, Paddock, calls me.

paragraphs.original: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$Anon.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$(to her spirit) I’ll be right here!$NEWLINE$(to her spirit)

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Fair is foul, and foul is fair$NEWLINE$Hover through the fog and filthy air.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Fair is foul, and foul is fair. Let’s fly away through the fog and filthy air.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alarum within. Enter KING DUNCAN, MALCOLM, DONALBAIN, LENNOX, with attendants, meeting a bleeding CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$KING DUNCAN$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$DONALBAIN$NEWLINE$LENNOX$NEWLINE$CAPTAIN
paragraphs.translated: Sounds of a trumpet and soldiers fighting offstage. KING DUNCAN enters with his sons MALCOLM and DONALBAIN, LENNOX, and a number of attendants. They meet a wounded and bloody CAPTAIN.$NEWLINE$KING DUNCAN$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$DONALBAIN$NEWLINE$LENNOX$NEWLINE$CAPTAIN

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$What bloody man is that? He can report,$NEWLINE$As seemeth by his plight, of the revolt$NEWLINE$The newest state.
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$Who is this bloody man? Judging from his appearance, I bet he can tell us the latest news about the revolt.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$This is the sergeant$NEWLINE$Who like a good and hardy soldier fought$NEWLINE$'Gainst my captivity. Hail, brave friend!$NEWLINE$Say to the king the knowledge of the broil$NEWLINE$As thou didst leave it.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$This is the brave sergeant who fought to keep me from being captured. Hail, brave friend! Tell the king what was happening in the battle when you left it.

paragraphs.original: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$Doubtful it stood,$NEWLINE$As two spent swimmers that do cling together$NEWLINE$And choke their art. The merciless Macdonwald—$NEWLINE$Worthy to be a rebel, for to that$NEWLINE$The multiplying villanies of nature$NEWLINE$Do swarm upon him—from the Western Isles$NEWLINE$Of kerns and gallowglasses is supplied,$NEWLINE$And fortune, on his damnèd quarrel smiling,$NEWLINE$Showed like a rebel’s whore. But all’s too weak,$NEWLINE$For brave Macbeth—well he deserves that name—$NEWLINE$Disdaining fortune, with his brandished steel,$NEWLINE$Which smoked with bloody execution,$NEWLINE$Like valor’s minion carved out his passage$NEWLINE$Till he faced the slave;$NEWLINE$Which ne'er shook hands, nor bade farewell to him,$NEWLINE$Till he unseamed him from the nave to th' chops,$NEWLINE$And fixed his head upon our battlements.
paragraphs.translated: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$For a while you couldn’t tell who would win. The armies were like two exhausted swimmers clinging to each other and struggling in the water, unable to move. The villainous rebel Macdonwald was supported by foot soldiers and horsemen from Ireland and the Hebrides, and Lady Luck was with him, smiling cruelly at his enemies as if she were his whore. But Luck and Macdonwald together weren’t strong enough. Brave Macbeth, laughing at Luck, chopped his way through to Macdonwald, who didn’t even have time to say good-bye or shake hands before Macbeth split him open from his navel to his jawbone and stuck his head on our castle walls.

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$O valiant cousin! Worthy gentleman!
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$My brave relative! What a worthy man!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$As whence the sun 'gins his reflection$NEWLINE$Shipwracking storms and direful thunders break,$NEWLINE$So from that spring whence comfort seemed to come$NEWLINE$Discomfort swells. Mark, King of Scotland, mark:$NEWLINE$No sooner justice had, with valor armed,$NEWLINE$Compelled these skipping kerns to trust their heels,$NEWLINE$But the Norweyan lord, surveying vantage,$NEWLINE$With furbished arms and new supplies of men,$NEWLINE$Began a fresh assault.
paragraphs.translated: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$But in the same way that violent storms always come just as spring appears, our success against Macdonwald created new problems for us. Listen to this, King: as soon as we sent those Irish soldiers running for cover, the Norwegian king saw his chance to attack us with fresh troops and shiny weapons.

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$Dismayed not this our captains, Macbeth and Banquo?
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$Didn’t this frighten our captains, Macbeth and Banquo?

paragraphs.original: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$Yes, as sparrows eagles, or the hare the lion.$NEWLINE$If I say sooth, I must report they were$NEWLINE$As cannons overcharged with double cracks,$NEWLINE$So they doubly redoubled strokes upon the foe.$NEWLINE$Except they meant to bathe in reeking wounds,$NEWLINE$Or memorize another Golgotha,$NEWLINE$I cannot tell—$NEWLINE$But I am faint, my gashes cry for help.
paragraphs.translated: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$The new challenge scared them about as much as sparrows frighten eagles, or rabbits frighten a lion. To tell you the truth, they fought the new enemy with twice as much force as before; they were like cannons loaded with double ammunition. Maybe they wanted to take a bath in their enemies' blood, or make that battlefield as infamous as Golgotha, where Christ was crucified, I don’t know. But I feel weak. My wounds must be tended to.

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$So well thy words become thee as thy wounds;$NEWLINE$They smack of honor both. Go get him surgeons.
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$Your words, like your wounds, bring you honor. Take him to the surgeons.

paragraphs.original: Exit CAPTAIN with attendants$NEWLINE$CAPTAIN
paragraphs.translated: The CAPTAIN exits, helped by attendants.$NEWLINE$CAPTAIN

paragraphs.original: Enter ROSS and ANGUS$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$ANGUS
paragraphs.translated: ROSS and ANGUS enter.$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$ANGUS

paragraphs.original: Who comes here?
paragraphs.translated: Who is this?

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$The worthy thane of Ross.
paragraphs.translated:
MALCOLM$NEWLINE$The worthy
Thane of Ross.$NEWLINE$Thane$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$What a haste looks through his eyes! So should he look$NEWLINE$That seems to speak things strange.
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$His eyes seem frantic! He looks like someone with a strange tale to tell.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$God save the king.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$God save the king!

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$Whence cam’st thou, worthy thane?
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$Where have you come from, worthy thane?

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$From Fife, great king,$NEWLINE$Where the Norweyan banners flout the sky$NEWLINE$And fan our people cold.$NEWLINE$Norway himself, with terrible numbers,$NEWLINE$Assisted by that most disloyal traitor,$NEWLINE$The thane of Cawdor, began a dismal conflict,$NEWLINE$Till that Bellona’s bridegroom, lapped in proof,$NEWLINE$Confronted him with self-comparisons,$NEWLINE$Point against point, rebellious arm 'gainst arm,$NEWLINE$Curbing his lavish spirit; and to conclude,$NEWLINE$The victory fell on us.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$Great king, I’ve come from Fife, where the Norwegian flag flies, mocking our country and frightening our people. Leading an enormous army and assisted by that disloyal traitor, the thane of Cawdor, the king of Norway began a bloody battle. But outfitted in his battle-weathered armor, Macbeth met the Norwegian attacks shot for shot, as if he were the goddess of war’s husband. Finally he broke the enemy’s spirit, and we were victorious.

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$Great happiness!
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$Great happiness!

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$That now$NEWLINE$Sweno, the Norways' king, craves composition.$NEWLINE$Nor would we deign him burial of his men$NEWLINE$Till he disbursed at Saint Colme’s Inch$NEWLINE$Ten thousand dollars to our general use.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$So now Sweno, the Norwegian king, wants a treaty. We told him we wouldn’t even let him bury his men until he retreated to Saint Colme’s Inch and paid us ten thousand dollars.

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$No more that thane of Cawdor shall deceive$NEWLINE$Our bosom interest: go pronounce his present death,$NEWLINE$And with his former title greet Macbeth.
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$The thane of Cawdor will never again betray me. Go announce that he will be executed, and tell Macbeth that Cawdor’s titles will be given to him.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$I’ll see it done.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$I’ll get it done right away.

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$What he hath lost, noble Macbeth hath won.
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$The thane of Cawdor has lost what the noble Macbeth has won.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Thunder. Enter the three WITCHES$NEWLINE$WITCHES
paragraphs.translated: Thunder. The three WITCHES enter.$NEWLINE$WITCHES

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Where hast thou been, sister?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Where have you been, sister?

paragraphs.original: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Killing swine.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Killing pigs.

paragraphs.original: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$Sister, where thou?
paragraphs.translated: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$And you, sister?

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$A sailor’s wife had chestnuts in her lap,$NEWLINE$And munched, and munched, and munched. “Give me,”$NEWLINE$quoth I.$NEWLINE$“Aroint thee, witch!” the rump-fed runnion cries.$NEWLINE$Her husband’s to Aleppo gone, master o' th' Tiger;$NEWLINE$Tiger$NEWLINE$But in a sieve I’ll thither sail,$NEWLINE$And like a rat without a tail,$NEWLINE$I’ll do, I’ll do, and I’ll do.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$A sailor’s wife had chestnuts in her lap and munched away at them. “Give me one,” I said. “Get away from me, witch!” the fat woman cried. Her husband has sailed off to Aleppo as master of a ship called the Tiger. I’ll sail there in a kitchen strainer, turn myself into a tailless rat, and do things to him—$NEWLINE$Tiger

paragraphs.original: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$I’ll give thee a wind.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$I’ll give you some wind to sail there.

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Thou 'rt kind.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$How nice of you!

paragraphs.original: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$And I another.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$And I will give you some more.

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$I myself have all the other,$NEWLINE$And the very ports they blow,$NEWLINE$All the quarters that they know$NEWLINE$I' th' shipman’s card.$NEWLINE$I’ll drain him dry as hay.$NEWLINE$Sleep shall neither night nor day$NEWLINE$Hang upon his penthouse lid.$NEWLINE$He shall live a man forbid.$NEWLINE$Weary sev'nnights nine times nine$NEWLINE$Shall he dwindle, peak and pine.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$I already have control of all the other winds, along with the ports from which they blow and every direction on the sailor’s compass in which they can go. I’ll drain the life out of him. He won’t catch a wink of sleep, either at night or during the day. He will live as a cursed man. For eighty-one weeks he will waste away in agony.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Though his bark cannot be lost,$NEWLINE$Yet it shall be tempest-tossed.$NEWLINE$Look what I have.
paragraphs.translated: Although I can’t make his ship disappear, I can still make his journey miserable. Look what I have here.

paragraphs.original: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Show me, show me.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Show me, show me.

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Here I have a pilot’s thumb,$NEWLINE$Wrecked as homeward he did come.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Here I have the thumb of a pilot who was drowned while trying to return home.

paragraphs.original: Drum within
paragraphs.translated: A drum sounds offstage.

paragraphs.original: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$A drum, a drum!$NEWLINE$Macbeth doth come.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$A drum, a drum! Macbeth has come.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$(dancing together in a circle) The weird sisters, hand in$NEWLINE$(dancing together in a circle)$NEWLINE$hand,$NEWLINE$Posters of the sea and land,$NEWLINE$Thus do go about, about,$NEWLINE$Thrice to thine and thrice to mine$NEWLINE$And thrice again, to make up nine.$NEWLINE$Peace! The charm’s wound up.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$(dancing together in a circle) We weird sisters, hand in hand, swift travelers over the sea and land, dance around and around like so. Three times to yours, and three times to mine, and three times again, to add up to nine. Enough! The charm is ready.$NEWLINE$(dancing together in a circle)

paragraphs.original: Enter MACBETH and BANQUO$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$BANQUO
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH and BANQUO enter.$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$BANQUO

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$So foul and fair a day I have not seen.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(to BANQUO) I have never seen a day that was so good and bad at the same time.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$How far is ’t called to Forres?—What are these$NEWLINE$So withered and so wild in their attire,$NEWLINE$That look not like th' inhabitants o' th' Earth,$NEWLINE$And yet are on ’t?—Live you? Or are you aught$NEWLINE$That man may question? You seem to understand me,$NEWLINE$By each at once her choppy finger laying$NEWLINE$Upon her skinny lips. You should be women,$NEWLINE$And yet your beards forbid me to interpret$NEWLINE$That you are so.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$How far is it supposed to be to Forres? (he sees the WITCHES) What are these creatures? They’re so withered-looking and crazily dressed. They don’t look like they belong on this planet, but I see them standing here on Earth. (to the WITCHES) Are you alive? Can you answer questions? You seem to understand me, because each of you has put a gruesome finger to her skinny lips. You look like women, but your beards keep me from believing that you really are.$NEWLINE$(he sees the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Speak, if you can: what are you?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Speak, if you can. What kind of creatures are you?

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$All hail, Macbeth! Hail to thee, thane of Glamis!
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$All hail, Macbeth! Hail to you, thane of Glamis!

paragraphs.original: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$All hail, Macbeth! Hail to thee, thane of Cawdor!
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$All hail, Macbeth! Hail to you, thane of Cawdor!

paragraphs.original: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$All hail, Macbeth, that shalt be king hereafter!
paragraphs.translated: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$All hail, Macbeth, the future king!

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Good sir, why do you start and seem to fear$NEWLINE$Things that do sound so fair? (to the WITCHES) I' th' name of truth,$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Are ye fantastical, or that indeed$NEWLINE$Which outwardly ye show? My noble partner$NEWLINE$You greet with present grace and great prediction$NEWLINE$Of noble having and of royal hope,$NEWLINE$That he seems rapt withal. To me you speak not.$NEWLINE$If you can look into the seeds of time$NEWLINE$And say which grain will grow and which will not,$NEWLINE$Speak, then, to me, who neither beg nor fear$NEWLINE$Your favors nor your hate.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$My dear Macbeth, why do you look so startled and afraid of these nice things they’re saying? (to the WITCHES) Tell me honestly, are you illusions, or are you really what you seem to be? You’ve greeted my noble friend with honors and talk of a future so glorious that you’ve made him speechless. But you don’t say anything to me. If you can see the future and say how things will turn out, tell me. I don’t want your favors and I’m not afraid of your hatred.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Hail!
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Hail!

paragraphs.original: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Hail!
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Hail!

paragraphs.original: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$Hail!
paragraphs.translated: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$Hail!

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Lesser than Macbeth and greater.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$You are lesser than Macbeth but also greater.

paragraphs.original: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Not so happy, yet much happier.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$You are not as happy as Macbeth, yet much happier.

paragraphs.original: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$Thou shalt get kings, though thou be none.$NEWLINE$So all hail, Macbeth and Banquo!
paragraphs.translated: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$Your descendants will be kings, even though you will not be one. So all hail, Macbeth and Banquo!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Banquo and Macbeth, all hail!
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Banquo and Macbeth, all hail!

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Stay, you imperfect speakers, tell me more.$NEWLINE$By Sinel’s death I know I am thane of Glamis.$NEWLINE$But how of Cawdor? The thane of Cawdor lives,$NEWLINE$A prosperous gentleman, and to be king$NEWLINE$Stands not within the prospect of belief,$NEWLINE$No more than to be Cawdor. Say from whence$NEWLINE$You owe this strange intelligence, or why$NEWLINE$Upon this blasted heath you stop our way$NEWLINE$With such prophetic greeting. Speak, I charge you.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Wait! You only told me part of what I want to know. Stay and tell me more. I already know I am the thane of Glamis because I inherited the position when my father, Sinel, died. But how can you call me the thane of Cawdor? The thane of Cawdor is alive, and he’s a rich and powerful man. And for me to be the king is completely impossible, just as it’s impossible for me to be thane of Cawdor. Tell me where you learned these strange things, and why you stop us at this desolate place with this prophetic greeting? Speak, I command you.

paragraphs.original: WITCHES vanish$NEWLINE$WITCHES
paragraphs.translated: The WITCHESvanish.$NEWLINE$WITCHES

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$The earth hath bubbles, as the water has,$NEWLINE$And these are of them. Whither are they vanished?
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$The earth has bubbles, just like the water, and these creatures must have come from a bubble in the earth. Where did they disappear to?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Into the air, and what seemed corporal$NEWLINE$Melted, as breath into the wind. Would they had stayed.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Into thin air. Their bodies melted like breath in the wind. I wish they had stayed!

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Were such things here as we do speak about?$NEWLINE$Or have we eaten on the insane root$NEWLINE$That takes the reason prisoner?
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Were these things we’re talking about really here? Or are we both on drugs?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Your children shall be kings.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Your children will be kings.

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$You shall be king.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$You will be the king.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$And thane of Cawdor too: went it not so?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$And thane of Cawdor too. Isn’t that what they said?

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$To the selfsame tune and words. Who’s here?
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$That’s exactly what they said. Who’s this?

paragraphs.original: Enter ROSS and ANGUS$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$ANGUS
paragraphs.translated: ROSS and ANGUS enter.$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$ANGUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$The king hath happily received, Macbeth,$NEWLINE$The news of thy success, and when he reads$NEWLINE$Thy personal venture in the rebels' fight,$NEWLINE$His wonders and his praises do contend$NEWLINE$Which should be thine or his. Silenced with that,$NEWLINE$In viewing o'er the rest o' the selfsame day,$NEWLINE$He finds thee in the stout Norweyan ranks,$NEWLINE$Nothing afeard of what thyself didst make,$NEWLINE$Strange images of death. As thick as tale$NEWLINE$Can post with post, and every one did bear$NEWLINE$Thy praises in his kingdom’s great defense,$NEWLINE$And poured them down before him.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$The king was happy to hear of your success, Macbeth. Whenever he hears the story of your exploits in the fight against the rebels, he becomes so amazed it makes him speechless. He was also shocked to learn that on the same day you fought the rebels you also fought against the army of Norway, and that you weren’t the least bit afraid of death, even as you killed everyone around you. Messenger after messenger delivered news of your bravery to the king with praise for how you defended his country.

paragraphs.original: ANGUS$NEWLINE$We are sent$NEWLINE$To give thee from our royal master thanks,$NEWLINE$Only to herald thee into his sight,$NEWLINE$Not pay thee.
paragraphs.translated: ANGUS$NEWLINE$The king sent us to give you his thanks and to bring you to him. Your real reward won’t come from us.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$And, for an earnest of a greater honor,$NEWLINE$He bade me, from him, call thee thane of Cawdor:$NEWLINE$In which addition, hail, most worthy thane,$NEWLINE$For it is thine.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$And to give you a taste of what’s in store for you, he told me to call you the thane of Cawdor. So hail, thane of Cawdor! That title belongs to you now.

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$What, can the devil speak true?
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$(shocked) Can the devil tell the truth?$NEWLINE$(shocked)

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$The thane of Cawdor lives. Why do you dress me$NEWLINE$In borrowed robes?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$The thane of Cawdor is still alive. Why are you giving me his title?

paragraphs.original: ANGUS$NEWLINE$Who was the thane lives yet,$NEWLINE$But under heavy judgment bears that life$NEWLINE$Which he deserves to lose. Whether he was combined$NEWLINE$With those of Norway, or did line the rebel$NEWLINE$With hidden help and vantage, or that with both$NEWLINE$He labored in his country’s wrack, I know not;$NEWLINE$But treasons capital, confessed and proved,$NEWLINE$Have overthrown him.
paragraphs.translated: ANGUS$NEWLINE$The man who was the thane of Cawdor is still alive, but he’s been sentenced to death, and he deserves to die. I don’t know whether he fought on Norway’s side, or if he secretly aided the rebels, or if he fought with both of our enemies. But his treason, which has been proven, and to which he’s confessed, means he’s finished.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(aside)      Glamis, and thane of Cawdor!$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$The greatest is behind. (to ROSS and ANGUS) Thanks for your pains.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(aside to BANQUO) Do you not hope your children shall be kings,$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$When those that gave the thane of Cawdor to me$NEWLINE$Promised no less to them?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(to himself) It’s just like they said—now I’m the thane of Glamis and the thane of Cawdor. And the best part of what they predicted is still to come. (to ROSS and ANGUS) Thank you for the news. (speaking so that only BANQUO can hear) Aren’t you beginning to hope your children will be kings? After all, the witches who said I was thane of Cawdor promised them nothing less.$NEWLINE$(to himself)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$That, trusted home,$NEWLINE$Might yet enkindle you unto the crown,$NEWLINE$Besides the thane of Cawdor. But ’tis strange.$NEWLINE$And oftentimes, to win us to our harm,$NEWLINE$The instruments of darkness tell us truths,$NEWLINE$Win us with honest trifles, to betray ’s$NEWLINE$In deepest consequence.$NEWLINE$(to ROSS and ANGUS) Cousins, a word, I pray you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$If you trust what they say, you might be on your way to becoming king, as well as thane of Cawdor. But this whole thing is strange. The agents of evil often tell us part of the truth in order to lead us to our destruction. They earn our trust by telling us the truth about little things, but then they betray us when it will damage us the most. (to ROSS and ANGUS) Gentlemen, I’d like to have a word with you, please.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BANQUO, ROSS, and ANGUS move to one side$NEWLINE$BANQUO$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$ANGUS
paragraphs.translated: ROSS, ANGUS, and BANQUO move to one side.$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$ANGUS$NEWLINE$BANQUO

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(aside)      Two truths are told,$NEWLINE$(aside$NEWLINE$As happy prologues to the swelling act$NEWLINE$Of the imperial theme. (to ROSS and ANGUS) I thank you, gentlemen.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(aside) This supernatural soliciting$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Cannot be ill, cannot be good. If ill,$NEWLINE$Why hath it given me earnest of success,$NEWLINE$Commencing in a truth? I am thane of Cawdor.$NEWLINE$If good, why do I yield to that suggestion$NEWLINE$Whose horrid image doth unfix my hair$NEWLINE$And make my seated heart knock at my ribs,$NEWLINE$Against the use of nature? Present fears$NEWLINE$Are less than horrible imaginings.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(to himself) So far the witches have told me two things that came true, so it seems like this will culminate in my becoming king. (to ROSS and ANGUS) Thank you, gentlemen. (to himself) This supernatural temptation doesn’t seem like it can be a bad thing, but it can’t be good either. If it’s a bad thing, why was I promised a promotion that turned out to be true? Now I’m the thane of Cawdor, just like they said I would be. But if this is a good thing, why do I find myself thinking about murdering King Duncan, a thought so horrifying that it makes my hair stand on end and my heart pound inside my chest? The dangers that actually threaten me here and now frighten me less than the horrible things I’m imagining.$NEWLINE$(to himself)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: My thought, whose murder yet is but fantastical,$NEWLINE$Shakes so my single state of man$NEWLINE$That function is smothered in surmise,$NEWLINE$And nothing is but what is not.
paragraphs.translated: Even though it’s just a fantasy so far, the mere thought of committing murder shakes me up so much that I hardly know who I am anymore. My ability to act is stifled by my thoughts and speculations, and the only things that matter to me are things that don’t really exist.

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Look how our partner’s rapt.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Look at Macbeth—he’s in a daze.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(aside) If chance will have me king, why, chance may crown me$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Without my stir.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(to himself) If fate wants me to be king, perhaps fate will just make it happen and I won’t have to do anything.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$New honors come upon him,$NEWLINE$Like our strange garments, cleave not to their mold$NEWLINE$But with the aid of use.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$(to ROSS and ANGUS) Macbeth is not used to his new titles. They’re like new clothes: they don’t fit until you break them in over time.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(aside)      Come what come may,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Time and the hour runs through the roughest day.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(to himself) One way or another, what’s going to happen is going to happen.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Worthy Macbeth, we stay upon your leisure.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Good Macbeth, we’re ready when you are.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Give me your favor. My dull brain was wrought$NEWLINE$With things forgotten. Kind gentlemen, your pains$NEWLINE$Are registered where every day I turn$NEWLINE$The leaf to read them. Let us toward the king.$NEWLINE$(aside to BANQUO) Think upon what hath chanced, and, at more time,$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$The interim having weighed it, let us speak$NEWLINE$Our free hearts each to other.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I beg your pardon; I was distracted. Kind gentlemen, I won’t forget the trouble you’ve taken for me whenever I think of this day. Let’s go to the king. (speaking so that only BANQUO can hear) Think about what happened today, and when we’ve both had time to consider things, let’s talk.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Very gladly.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Absolutely.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Till then, enough. (to ROSS and ANGUS) Come, friends.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Until then, we’ve said enough. (to ROSS and ANGUS) Let’s go, my friends.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Enter KING DUNCAN, LENNOX, MALCOLM, DONALBAIN, and attendants$NEWLINE$KING DUNCAN$NEWLINE$LENNOX$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$DONALBAIN
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet fanfare sounds. KING DUNCAN, LENNOX, MALCOLM, DONALBAIN, and their attendants enter.$NEWLINE$KING DUNCAN$NEWLINE$LENNOX$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$DONALBAIN

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$Is execution done on Cawdor? Are not$NEWLINE$Those in commission yet returned?
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$Has the former thane of Cawdor been executed yet? Haven’t the people in charge of that come back?

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$My liege,$NEWLINE$They are not yet come back. But I have spoke$NEWLINE$With one that saw him die, who did report$NEWLINE$That very frankly he confessed his treasons,$NEWLINE$Implored your highness' pardon, and set forth$NEWLINE$A deep repentance. Nothing in his life$NEWLINE$Became him like the leaving it. He died$NEWLINE$As one that had been studied in his death$NEWLINE$To throw away the dearest thing he owed$NEWLINE$As ’twere a careless trifle.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$My king, they haven’t come back yet. But I spoke with someone who saw Cawdor die, and he said that Cawdor openly confessed his treasons, begged your highness’s forgiveness, and repented deeply. He never did anything in his whole life that looked as good as the way he died. He died like someone who had practiced how to toss away his most cherished possession as if it were a worthless a piece of garbage.

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$There’s no art$NEWLINE$To find the mind’s construction in the face.$NEWLINE$He was a gentleman on whom I built$NEWLINE$An absolute trust.
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$There’s no way to read a man’s mind by looking at his face. I trusted Cawdor completely.

paragraphs.original: Enter MACBETH, BANQUO, ROSS, and ANGUS$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$BANQUO$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$ANGUS
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH, BANQUO, ROSS, and ANGUS enter.$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$BANQUO$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$ANGUS

paragraphs.original: (to MACBETH) O worthiest cousin,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$The sin of my ingratitude even now$NEWLINE$Was heavy on me. Thou art so far before$NEWLINE$That swiftest wing of recompense is slow$NEWLINE$To overtake thee. Would thou hadst less deserved,$NEWLINE$That the proportion both of thanks and payment$NEWLINE$Might have been mine! Only I have left to say,$NEWLINE$More is thy due than more than all can pay.
paragraphs.translated: (to MACBETH) My worthiest kinsman! Just this moment I was feeling guilty for not having thanked you enough. You have done so much for me so fast that it has been impossible to reward you properly. If you deserved less, then perhaps my payment would have matched your deeds! All I can say is that I owe you more than I can ever repay.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$The service and the loyalty I owe$NEWLINE$In doing it pays itself. Your highness' part$NEWLINE$Is to receive our duties, and our duties$NEWLINE$Are to your throne and state children and servants,$NEWLINE$Which do but what they should, by doing everything$NEWLINE$Safe toward your love and honor.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$The opportunity to serve you is its own reward. Your only duty, your highness, is to accept what we owe you. Our duty to you and your state is like the duty of children to their father or servants to their master. By doing everything we can to protect you, we’re only doing what we should.

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$Welcome hither.$NEWLINE$I have begun to plant thee, and will labor$NEWLINE$To make thee full of growing. (to BANQUO) Noble Banquo,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$That hast no less deserved, nor must be known$NEWLINE$No less to have done so, let me infold thee$NEWLINE$And hold thee to my heart.
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$You are welcome here. By making you thane of Cawdor, I have planted the seeds of a great career for you, and I will make sure they grow. (to BANQUO) Noble Banquo, you deserve no less than Macbeth, and everyone should know it. Let me bring you close to me and give you the benefit of my love and good will.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$There, if I grow,$NEWLINE$The harvest is your own.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Then if I accomplish anything great, it will be a credit to you.

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$My plenteous joys,$NEWLINE$Wanton in fullness, seek to hide themselves$NEWLINE$In drops of sorrow. Sons, kinsmen, thanes,$NEWLINE$And you whose places are the nearest, know$NEWLINE$We will establish our estate upon$NEWLINE$Our eldest, Malcolm, whom we name hereafter$NEWLINE$The prince of Cumberland; which honor must$NEWLINE$Not unaccompanied invest him only,$NEWLINE$But signs of nobleness, like stars, shall shine$NEWLINE$On all deservers. (to MACBETH) From hence to Inverness,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And bind us further to you.
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$My joy is so overwhelming it brings tears to my eyes. My sons, relatives, lords, and all those closest to me, I want you to witness that I will bestow my kingdom on my eldest son, Malcolm. Today I name him the prince of Cumberland. But Malcolm isn’t going to be alone in receiving honors—titles of nobility will shine like stars on all of you who deserve them. (to MACBETH) And now, let’s go to your castle at Inverness, where I will become even more obliged to you because of your hospitality.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$The rest is labor which is not used for you:$NEWLINE$I’ll be myself the harbinger and make joyful$NEWLINE$The hearing of my wife with your approach.$NEWLINE$So humbly take my leave.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I’m not happy unless I can be working for you. I will go ahead and bring my wife the good news that you are coming. With that, I’ll be off.

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$My worthy Cawdor!
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$My worthy Cawdor!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(aside) The prince of Cumberland! That is a step$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$On which I must fall down, or else o'erleap,$NEWLINE$For in my way it lies. Stars, hide your fires;$NEWLINE$Let not light see my black and deep desires.$NEWLINE$The eye wink at the hand, yet let that be$NEWLINE$Which the eye fears, when it is done, to see.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(to himself) Malcolm is now the prince of Cumberland! To become king myself, I’m either going to have to step over him or give up, because he’s in my way. Stars, hide your light so no one can see the terrible desires within me. I won’t let my eye look at what my hand is doing, but in the end I’m still going to do that thing I’d be horrified to see.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH exits.$NEWLINE$MACBETH

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$True, worthy Banquo. He is full so valiant,$NEWLINE$And in his commendations I am fed;$NEWLINE$It is a banquet to me.—Let’s after him,$NEWLINE$Whose care is gone before to bid us welcome:$NEWLINE$It is a peerless kinsman.
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$(to BANQUO, in the middle of a conversation we haven’t heard) You’re right, Banquo. Macbeth is every bit as valiant as you say, and I am satisfied with these praises of him. Let’s follow after him, now that he has gone ahead to prepare our welcome. He is a man without equal.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$, in the middle of a conversation we haven’t heard)

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: Trumpet fanfare. They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LADY MACBETH, alone, with a letter$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH enters, reading a letter.$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$(reading) “They met me in the day of success, and I have learned by the perfectest report they have more in them than mortal knowledge. When I burned in desire to question them further, they made themselves air, into which they vanished. Whiles I stood rapt in the wonder of it came missives from the king, who all-hailed me 'Thane of Cawdor,' by which title, before, these weird sisters saluted me, and referred me to the coming on of time with 'Hail, king that shalt be!' This have I thought good to deliver thee, my dearest partner of greatness, that thou might’st not lose the dues of rejoicing, by being ignorant of what greatness is promised thee. Lay it to thy heart, and farewell.”$NEWLINE$(reading)
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$“The witches met me on the day of my victory in battle, and I have since learned that they have supernatural knowledge. When I tried desperately to question them further, they vanished into thin air. While I stood spellbound, messengers from the king arrived and greeted me as the thane of Cawdor, which is precisely how the weird sisters had saluted me before calling me ’the future king!' I thought I should tell you this news, my dearest partner in greatness, so that you could rejoice along with me about the greatness that is promised to us. Keep it secret, and farewell.”

paragraphs.original: Glamis thou art, and Cawdor; and shalt be$NEWLINE$What thou art promised. Yet do I fear thy nature;$NEWLINE$It is too full o' th' milk of human kindness$NEWLINE$To catch the nearest way: thou wouldst be great,$NEWLINE$Art not without ambition, but without$NEWLINE$The illness should attend it. What thou wouldst highly,$NEWLINE$That wouldst thou holily; wouldst not play false,$NEWLINE$And yet wouldst wrongly win. Thou'ld’st have, great Glamis,$NEWLINE$That which cries, “Thus thou must do,” if thou have it,$NEWLINE$And that which rather thou dost fear to do,$NEWLINE$Than wishest should be undone. Hie thee hither,$NEWLINE$That I may pour my spirits in thine ear$NEWLINE$And chastise with the valor of my tongue$NEWLINE$All that impedes thee from the golden round,$NEWLINE$Which fate and metaphysical aid doth seem$NEWLINE$To have thee crowned withal.
paragraphs.translated: (she looks up from the letter) You are thane of Glamis and Cawdor, and you’re going to be king, just like you were promised. But I worry about whether or not you have what it takes to seize the crown. You are too full of the milk of human kindness to strike aggressively at your first opportunity. You want to be powerful, and you don’t lack ambition, but you don’t have the mean streak that these things call for. The things you want to do, you want to do like a good man. You don’t want to cheat, yet you want what doesn’t belong to you. There’s something you want, but you’re afraid to do what you need to do to get it. You want it to be done for you. Hurry home so I can persuade you and talk you out of whatever’s keeping you from going after the crown. After all, fate and witchcraft both seem to want you to be king.$NEWLINE$(she looks up from the letter)

paragraphs.original: Enter SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: A SERVANT enters.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: What is your tidings?
paragraphs.translated: What news do you bring?

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$The king comes here tonight.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$The king is coming here tonight.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Thou 'rt mad to say it.$NEWLINE$Is not thy master with him, who, were ’t so,$NEWLINE$Would have informed for preparation?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$You must be crazy to say that! Isn’t Macbeth with the king, and wouldn’t Macbeth have told me in advance so I could prepare, if the king were really coming?

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$So please you, it is true: our thane is coming.$NEWLINE$One of my fellows had the speed of him,$NEWLINE$Who, almost dead for breath, had scarcely more$NEWLINE$Than would make up his message.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$I’m sorry, but it’s the truth. Macbeth is coming. He sent a messenger ahead of him who arrived here so out of breath that he could barely speak his message.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Give him tending.$NEWLINE$He brings great news.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Take good care of him. He brings great news.

paragraphs.original: Exit SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: The SERVANT exits.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: The raven himself is hoarse$NEWLINE$That croaks the fatal entrance of Duncan$NEWLINE$Under my battlements. Come, you spirits$NEWLINE$That tend on mortal thoughts, unsex me here,$NEWLINE$And fill me from the crown to the toe top-full$NEWLINE$Of direst cruelty. Make thick my blood.$NEWLINE$Stop up the access and passage to remorse,$NEWLINE$That no compunctious visitings of nature$NEWLINE$Shake my fell purpose, nor keep peace between$NEWLINE$The effect and it! Come to my woman’s breasts,$NEWLINE$And take my milk for gall, you murd'ring ministers,$NEWLINE$Wherever in your sightless substances$NEWLINE$You wait on nature’s mischief. Come, thick night,$NEWLINE$And pall thee in the dunnest smoke of hell,$NEWLINE$That my keen knife see not the wound it makes,$NEWLINE$Nor heaven peep through the blanket of the dark$NEWLINE$To cry “Hold, hold!”
paragraphs.translated: So the messenger is short of breath, like a hoarse raven, as he announces Duncan’s entrance into my fortress, where he will die. Come, you spirits that asist murderous thoughts, make me less like a woman and more like a man, and fill me from head to toe with deadly cruelty! Thicken my blood and clog up my veins so I won’t feel remorse, so that no human compassion can stop my evil plan or prevent me from accomplishing it! Come to my female breast and turn my mother’s milk into poisonous acid, you murdering demons, wherever you hide, invisible and waiting to do evil! Come, thick night, and cover the world in the darkest smoke of hell, so that my sharp knife can’t see the wound it cuts open, and so heaven can’t peep through the darkness and cry, “No! Stop!”

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter MACBETH$NEWLINE$MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH enters.$NEWLINE$MACBETH

paragraphs.original: Great Glamis, worthy Cawdor,$NEWLINE$Greater than both, by the all-hail hereafter,$NEWLINE$Thy letters have transported me beyond$NEWLINE$This ignorant present, and I feel now$NEWLINE$The future in the instant.
paragraphs.translated: Great thane of Glamis! Worthy thane of Cawdor! You’ll soon be greater than both those titles, once you become king! Your letter has transported me from the present moment, when who knows what will happen, and has made me feel like the future is already here.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$My dearest love,$NEWLINE$Duncan comes here tonight.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$My dearest love, Duncan is coming here tonight.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$And when goes hence?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$And when is he leaving?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Tomorrow, as he purposes.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$He plans to leave tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$O, never$NEWLINE$Shall sun that morrow see!$NEWLINE$Your face, my thane, is as a book where men$NEWLINE$May read strange matters. To beguile the time,$NEWLINE$Look like the time. Bear welcome in your eye,$NEWLINE$Your hand, your tongue. Look like th' innocent flower,$NEWLINE$But be the serpent under ’t. He that’s coming$NEWLINE$Must be provided for; and you shall put$NEWLINE$This night’s great business into my dispatch,$NEWLINE$Which shall to all our nights and days to come$NEWLINE$Give solely sovereign sway and masterdom.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$That day will never come. Your face betrays strange feelings, my lord, and people will be able to read it like a book. In order to deceive them, you must appear the way they expect you to look. Greet the king with a welcoming expression in your eyes, your hands, and your words. You should look like an innocent flower, but be like the snake that hides underneath the flower. The king is coming, and he’s got to be taken care of. Let me handle tonight’s preparations, because tonight will change every night and day for the rest of our lives.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$We will speak further.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$We will speak about this further.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Only look up clear.$NEWLINE$To alter favor ever is to fear.$NEWLINE$Leave all the rest to me.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$You should project a peaceful mood, because if you look troubled, you will arouse suspicion. Leave all the rest to me.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: hautboys and torches. Enter KING DUNCAN, MALCOLM, DONALBAIN, BANQUO, LENNOX, MACDUFF, ROSS, ANGUS, and attendants$NEWLINE$KING DUNCAN$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$DONALBAIN$NEWLINE$BANQUO$NEWLINE$LENNOX$NEWLINE$MACDUFF$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$ANGUS
paragraphs.translated:
The stage is lit by torches.
Hautboys play. DUNCAN enters, together with MALCOLM, DONALBAIN, BANQUO, LENNOX, MACDUFF, ROSS, ANGUS, and their attendants.$NEWLINE$Hautboys$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$DUNCAN$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$DONALBAIN$NEWLINE$BANQUO$NEWLINE$LENNOX$NEWLINE$MACDUFF$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$ANGUS

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$This castle hath a pleasant seat. The air$NEWLINE$Nimbly and sweetly recommends itself$NEWLINE$Unto our gentle senses.
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$This castle is in a pleasant place. The air is sweet and appeals to my refined senses.

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$This guest of summer,$NEWLINE$The temple-haunting martlet, does approve,$NEWLINE$By his loved mansionry, that the heaven’s breath$NEWLINE$Smells wooingly here. No jutty, frieze,$NEWLINE$Buttress, nor coign of vantage, but this bird$NEWLINE$Hath made his pendant bed and procreant cradle.$NEWLINE$Where they most breed and haunt, I have observed,$NEWLINE$The air is delicate.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$The fact that this summer bird, the house martin, builds his nests here proves how inviting the breezes are. There isn’t a single protrusion in the castle walls where these birds haven’t built their hanging nests to sleep and breed. I’ve noticed that they always like to settle and mate where the air is the nicest.

paragraphs.original: Enter LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH enters.$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$See, see, our honored hostess!$NEWLINE$The love that follows us sometime is our trouble,$NEWLINE$Which still we thank as love. Herein I teach you$NEWLINE$How you shall bid God 'ild us for your pains,$NEWLINE$And thank us for your trouble.
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$Look, here comes our honored hostess! Sometimes the love my subjects bring me is inconvenient, but I still accept it as love. In doing so, I’m teaching you to thank me for the incovenience I’m causing you by being here, because it comes from my love to you.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$All our service,$NEWLINE$In every point twice done and then done double,$NEWLINE$Were poor and single business to contend$NEWLINE$Against those honors deep and broad wherewith$NEWLINE$Your majesty loads our house. For those of old,$NEWLINE$And the late dignities heaped up to them,$NEWLINE$We rest your hermits.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Everything we’re doing for you, even if it were doubled and then doubled again, is nothing compared to the honors you have brought to our family. We gladly welcome you as our guests, with gratitude for both the honors you’ve given us before and the new honors you’ve just given us.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$Where’s the thane of Cawdor?$NEWLINE$We coursed him at the heels and had a purpose$NEWLINE$To be his purveyor; but he rides well,$NEWLINE$And his great love, sharp as his spur, hath holp him$NEWLINE$To his home before us. Fair and noble hostess,$NEWLINE$We are your guest tonight.
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$Where is Macbeth, the thane of Cawdor? We followed closely after him. I hoped to arrive here before him, but he rides swiftly. And his great love, which is as sharp as his spur, helped him beat us here. Fair and noble hostess, we are your guests tonight.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Your servants ever$NEWLINE$Have theirs, themselves, and what is theirs in compt,$NEWLINE$To make their audit at your highness' pleasure,$NEWLINE$Still to return your own.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$We are your servants, your highness, and as always our house and everything in it is at your disposal, for after all, we keep it in your trust and we’re glad to give you back what’s yours.

paragraphs.original: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$Give me your hand.$NEWLINE$Conduct me to mine host. We love him highly$NEWLINE$And shall continue our graces towards him.$NEWLINE$By your leave, hostess.
paragraphs.translated: DUNCAN$NEWLINE$Give me your hand. Bring me to my host, Macbeth. I love him dearly, and I shall continue to favor him. Whenever you’re ready, hostess.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Hautboys. Torches. Enter a sewer and divers servants with dishes and service over the stage. Then enter MACBETH$NEWLINE$MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: Hautboys play. The stage is lit by torches. A butler enters, and various servants carry utensils and dishes of food across the stage. Then MACBETH enters.$NEWLINE$MACBETH

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$If it were done when ’tis done, then ’twere well$NEWLINE$It were done quickly. If the assassination$NEWLINE$Could trammel up the consequence, and catch$NEWLINE$With his surcease success; that but this blow$NEWLINE$Might be the be-all and the end-all here,$NEWLINE$But here, upon this bank and shoal of time,$NEWLINE$We’d jump the life to come. But in these cases$NEWLINE$We still have judgment here, that we but teach$NEWLINE$Bloody instructions, which, being taught, return$NEWLINE$To plague th' inventor: this even-handed justice$NEWLINE$Commends the ingredients of our poisoned chalice$NEWLINE$To our own lips. He’s here in double trust:$NEWLINE$First, as I am his kinsman and his subject,$NEWLINE$Strong both against the deed; then, as his host,$NEWLINE$Who should against his murderer shut the door,$NEWLINE$Not bear the knife myself. Besides, this Duncan$NEWLINE$Hath borne his faculties so meek, hath been$NEWLINE$So clear in his great office, that his virtues$NEWLINE$Will plead like angels, trumpet-tongued, against$NEWLINE$The deep damnation of his taking-off;$NEWLINE$And pity, like a naked newborn babe,$NEWLINE$Striding the blast, or heaven’s cherubim, horsed$NEWLINE$Upon the sightless couriers of the air,$NEWLINE$Shall blow the horrid deed in every eye,$NEWLINE$That tears shall drown the wind. I have no spur$NEWLINE$To prick the sides of my intent, but only$NEWLINE$Vaulting ambition, which o'erleaps itself$NEWLINE$And falls on th' other.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$If this business would really be finished when I did the deed, then it would be best to get it over with quickly. If the assassination of the king could work like a net, sweeping up everything and preventing any consequences, then the murder would be the be-all and end-all of the whole affair, and I would gladly put my soul and the afterlife at risk to do it. But for crimes like these there are still punishments in this world. By committing violent crimes we only teach other people to commit violence, and the violence of our students will come back to plague us teachers. Justice, being equal to everyone, forces us to drink from the poisoned cup that we serve to others. The king trusts me in two ways. First of all, I am his kinsman and his subject, so I should always try to protect him. Second, I am his host, so I should be closing the door in his murderer’s face, not trying to murder him myself. Besides, Duncan has been such a humble leader, so free of corruption, that his virtuous legacy will speak for him when he dies, as if angels were playing trumpets against the injustice of his murder. Pity, like an innocent newborn baby, will ride the wind with winged angels on invisible horses through the air to spread news of the horrible deed to everyone everywhere. People will shed a flood of tears that will drown the wind like a horrible downpour of rain. I can’t spur myself to action. The only thing motivating me is ambition, which makes people rush ahead of themselves toward disaster.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH enters.$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH

paragraphs.original: How now! What news?
paragraphs.translated: What news do you have?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$He has almost supped. Why have you left the chamber?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$He has almost finished dinner. Why did you leave the dining room?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Hath he asked for me?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Has he asked for me?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Know you not he has?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Don’t you know he has?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$We will proceed no further in this business.$NEWLINE$He hath honored me of late, and I have bought$NEWLINE$Golden opinions from all sorts of people,$NEWLINE$Which would be worn now in their newest gloss,$NEWLINE$Not cast aside so soon.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$We can’t go on with this plan. The king has just honored me, and I have earned the good opinion of all sorts of people. I want to enjoy these honors while the feeling is fresh and not throw them away so soon.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Was the hope drunk$NEWLINE$Wherein you dressed yourself? Hath it slept since?$NEWLINE$And wakes it now, to look so green and pale$NEWLINE$At what it did so freely? From this time$NEWLINE$Such I account thy love. Art thou afeard$NEWLINE$To be the same in thine own act and valor$NEWLINE$As thou art in desire? Wouldst thou have that$NEWLINE$Which thou esteem’st the ornament of life,$NEWLINE$And live a coward in thine own esteem,$NEWLINE$Letting “I dare not” wait upon “I would, ”$NEWLINE$Like the poor cat i' th' adage?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Were you drunk when you seemed so hopeful before? Have you gone to sleep and woken up green and pale in fear of this idea? From now on this is what I’ll think of your love. Are you afraid to act the way you desire? Will you take the crown you want so badly, or will you live as a coward, always saying “I can’t” after you say “I want to”? You’re like the poor cat in the old story.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Prithee, peace:$NEWLINE$I dare do all that may become a man;$NEWLINE$Who dares do more is none.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Please, stop! I dare to do only what is proper for a man to do. He who dares to do more is not a man at all.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$What beast was ’t, then,$NEWLINE$That made you break this enterprise to me?$NEWLINE$When you durst do it, then you were a man;$NEWLINE$And to be more than what you were, you would$NEWLINE$Be so much more the man. Nor time nor place$NEWLINE$Did then adhere, and yet you would make both.$NEWLINE$They have made themselves, and that their fitness now$NEWLINE$Does unmake you. I have given suck, and know$NEWLINE$How tender ’tis to love the babe that milks me.$NEWLINE$I would, while it was smiling in my face,$NEWLINE$Have plucked my nipple from his boneless gums$NEWLINE$And dashed the brains out, had I so sworn as you$NEWLINE$Have done to this.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$If you weren’t a man, then what kind of animal were you when you first told me you wanted to do this? When you dared to do it, that’s when you were a man. And if you go one step further by doing what you dared to do before, you’ll be that much more the man. The time and place weren’t right before, but you would have gone ahead with the murder anyhow. Now the time and place are just right, but they’re almost too good for you. I have suckled a baby, and I know how sweet it is to love the baby at my breast. But even as the baby was smiling up at me, I would have plucked my nipple out of its mouth and smashed its brains out against a wall if I had sworn to do that the same way you have sworn to do this.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$If we should fail?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$But if we fail—

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$We fail?$NEWLINE$But screw your courage to the sticking-place,$NEWLINE$And we’ll not fail. When Duncan is asleep—$NEWLINE$Whereto the rather shall his day’s hard journey$NEWLINE$Soundly invite him—his two chamberlains$NEWLINE$Will I with wine and wassail so convince$NEWLINE$That memory, the warder of the brain,$NEWLINE$Shall be a fume, and the receipt of reason$NEWLINE$A limbeck only: when in swinish sleep$NEWLINE$Their drenchèd natures lie as in a death,$NEWLINE$What cannot you and I perform upon$NEWLINE$The unguarded Duncan? What not put upon$NEWLINE$His spongy officers, who shall bear the guilt$NEWLINE$Of our great quell?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$We, fail? If you get your courage up, we can’t fail. When Duncan is asleep—the day’s hard journey has definitely made him tired—I’ll get his two servants so drunk that their memory will go up in smoke through the chimneys of their brains. When they lie asleep like pigs, so drunk they’ll be dead to the world, what won’t you and I be able to do to the unguarded Duncan? And whatever we do, we can lay all the blame on the drunken servants.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Bring forth men-children only,$NEWLINE$For thy undaunted mettle should compose$NEWLINE$Nothing but males. Will it not be received,$NEWLINE$When we have marked with blood those sleepy two$NEWLINE$Of his own chamber and used their very daggers,$NEWLINE$That they have done ’t?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$May you only give birth to male children, because your fearless spirit should create nothing that isn’t masculine. Once we have covered the two servants with blood, and used their daggers to kill, won’t people believe that they were the culprits?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Who dares receive it other,$NEWLINE$As we shall make our griefs and clamor roar$NEWLINE$Upon his death?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Who could think it happened any other way? We’ll be grieving loudly when we hear that Duncan has died.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I am settled, and bend up$NEWLINE$Each corporal agent to this terrible feat.$NEWLINE$Away, and mock the time with fairest show.$NEWLINE$False face must hide what the false heart doth know.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Now I’m decided, and I will exert every muscle in my body to commit this crime. Go now, and pretend to be a friendly hostess. Hide with a false pleasant face what you know in your false, evil heart.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter BANQUO, and FLEANCE, with a torch before him$NEWLINE$BANQUO$NEWLINE$FLEANCE
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO enters with FLEANCE, who lights the way with a torch.$NEWLINE$BANQUO$NEWLINE$FLEANCE

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$How goes the night, boy?
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$How’s the night going, boy?

paragraphs.original: FLEANCE$NEWLINE$The moon is down. I have not heard the clock.
paragraphs.translated: FLEANCE$NEWLINE$The moon has set. The clock hasn’t struck yet.

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$And she goes down at twelve.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$The moon sets at twelve, right?

paragraphs.original: FLEANCE$NEWLINE$I take ’t ’tis later, sir.
paragraphs.translated: FLEANCE$NEWLINE$I think it’s later than that, sir.

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Hold, take my sword. There’s husbandry in heaven;$NEWLINE$Their candles are all out. Take thee that too.$NEWLINE$A heavy summons lies like lead upon me,$NEWLINE$And yet I would not sleep. Merciful powers,$NEWLINE$Restrain in me the cursèd thoughts that nature$NEWLINE$Gives way to in repose.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Here, take my sword. The heavens are being stingy with their light. Take this, too. I’m tired and feeling heavy, but I can’t sleep. Merciful powers, keep away the nightmares that plague me when I rest!

paragraphs.original: Enter MACBETH and a SERVANT with a torch$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH enters with a SERVANT, who carries a torch.$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: Give me my sword. Who’s there?
paragraphs.translated: Give me my sword. Who’s there?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$A friend.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$A friend.

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$What, sir, not yet at rest? The king’s a-bed.$NEWLINE$He hath been in unusual pleasure, and$NEWLINE$Sent forth great largess to your offices.$NEWLINE$This diamond he greets your wife withal,$NEWLINE$By the name of most kind hostess, and shut up$NEWLINE$In measureless content.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$You’re not asleep yet, sir? The king’s in bed. He’s been in an unusually good mood and has granted many gifts to your household and servants. This diamond is a present from him to your wife for her boundless hospitality. (he hands MACBETH a diamond)$NEWLINE$(he hands$NEWLINE$a diamond)

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Being unprepared,$NEWLINE$Our will became the servant to defect,$NEWLINE$Which else should free have wrought.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Because we were unprepared for the king’s visit, we weren’t able to entertain him as well as we would have wanted to.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$All’s well.$NEWLINE$I dreamt last night of the three weird sisters:$NEWLINE$To you they have showed some truth.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Everything’s OK. I had a dream last night about the three witches. At least part of what they said about you was true.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I think not of them.$NEWLINE$Yet, when we can entreat an hour to serve,$NEWLINE$We would spend it in some words upon that business,$NEWLINE$If you would grant the time.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I don’t think about them now. But when we have an hour to spare we can talk more about it, if you’re willing.

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$At your kind’st leisure.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Whenever you like.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$If you shall cleave to my consent, when ’tis,$NEWLINE$It shall make honor for you.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$If you stick with me, when the time comes, there will be something in it for you.

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$So I lose none$NEWLINE$In seeking to augment it, but still keep$NEWLINE$My bosom franchised and allegiance clear,$NEWLINE$I shall be counselled.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$I’ll do whatever you say, as long as I can do it with a clear conscience.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Good repose the while!
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Rest easy in the meantime.

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Thanks, sir: the like to you!
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Thank you, sir. You do the same.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt BANQUO and FLEANCE$NEWLINE$BANQUO$NEWLINE$FLEANCE
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO and FLEANCE exit.$NEWLINE$BANQUO$NEWLINE$FLEANCE

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(to the SERVANT) Go bid thy mistress, when my drink is ready,$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$She strike upon the bell. Get thee to bed.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(to the SERVANT) Go and tell your mistress to strike the bell when my drink is ready. Get yourself to bed.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: The SERVANT exits.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: Is this a dagger which I see before me,$NEWLINE$The handle toward my hand? Come, let me clutch thee.$NEWLINE$I have thee not, and yet I see thee still.$NEWLINE$Art thou not, fatal vision, sensible$NEWLINE$To feeling as to sight? Or art thou but$NEWLINE$A dagger of the mind, a false creation,$NEWLINE$Proceeding from the heat-oppressèd brain?$NEWLINE$I see thee yet, in form as palpable$NEWLINE$As this which now I draw.$NEWLINE$Thou marshall’st me the way that I was going,$NEWLINE$And such an instrument I was to use.$NEWLINE$Mine eyes are made the fools o' th' other senses,$NEWLINE$Or else worth all the rest. I see thee still,$NEWLINE$And on thy blade and dudgeon gouts of blood,$NEWLINE$Which was not so before. There’s no such thing.$NEWLINE$It is the bloody business which informs$NEWLINE$Thus to mine eyes. Now o'er the one half-world$NEWLINE$Nature seems dead, and wicked dreams abuse$NEWLINE$The curtained sleep. Witchcraft celebrates$NEWLINE$Pale Hecate’s offerings, and withered murder,$NEWLINE$Alarumed by his sentinel, the wolf,$NEWLINE$Whose howl’s his watch, thus with his stealthy pace,$NEWLINE$With Tarquin’s ravishing strides, towards his design$NEWLINE$Moves like a ghost. Thou sure and firm-set earth,$NEWLINE$Hear not my steps, which way they walk, for fear$NEWLINE$Thy very stones prate of my whereabout,$NEWLINE$And take the present horror from the time,$NEWLINE$Which now suits with it. Whiles I threat, he lives.$NEWLINE$Words to the heat of deeds too cold breath gives.
paragraphs.translated:
$NEWLINE$Is this a dagger I see in front of me, with its handle pointing toward my hand? (to the dagger) Come, let me hold you. (he grabs at the air in front of him without touching anything) I don’t have you but I can still see you. Fateful apparition, isn’t it possible to touch you as well as see you? Or are you nothing more than a dagger created by the mind, a hallucination from my fevered brain? I can still see you, and you look as real as this other dagger that I’m pulling out now. (he draws a dagger) You’re leading me toward the place I was going already, and I was planning to use a weapon just like you. My eyesight must either be the one sense that’s not working, or else it’s the only one that’s working right. I can still see you, and I see blood splotches on your blade and handle that weren’t there before. (to himself) There’s no dagger here. It’s the murder I’m about to do that’s making me think I see one. Now half the world is asleep and being deceived by evil nightmares. Witches are offering sacrifices to their goddess Hecate. Old man murder, having been roused by the howls of his wolf, walks silently to his destination, moving like
Tarquin, as quiet as a ghost. (speaking to the ground) Hard ground, don’t listen to the direction of my steps. I don’t want you to echo back where I am and break the terrible stillness of this moment, a silence that is so appropriate for what I’m about to do. While I stay here talking, Duncan lives. The more I talk, the more my courage cools.$NEWLINE$(to the dagger)$NEWLINE$(he grabs at the air in front of him without touching anything)$NEWLINE$(he draws a dagger)$NEWLINE$(to himself)$NEWLINE$Tarquin$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$(speaking to the ground)$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: A bell rings
paragraphs.translated: A bell rings.

paragraphs.original: I go, and it is done. The bell invites me.$NEWLINE$Hear it not, Duncan, for it is a knell$NEWLINE$That summons thee to heaven or to hell.
paragraphs.translated: I’m going now. The murder is as good as done. The bell is telling me to do it. Don’t listen to the bell, Duncan, because it summons you either to heaven or to hell.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH exits.$NEWLINE$MACBETH

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH enters.$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$That which hath made them drunk hath made me bold.$NEWLINE$What hath quenched them hath given me fire.$NEWLINE$Hark! Peace! It was the owl that shrieked, the fatal bellman,$NEWLINE$Which gives the stern’st good-night. He is about it.$NEWLINE$The doors are open, and the surfeited grooms$NEWLINE$Do mock their charge with snores. I have drugged their possets,$NEWLINE$That death and nature do contend about them,$NEWLINE$Whether they live or die.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$The alcohol that got the servants drunk has made me bold. The same liquor that quenched their thirst has fired me up. Listen! Quiet! That was the owl that shrieked, with a scary “good night” like the bells they ring before they execute people. Macbeth must be killing the king right now. The doors to Duncan’s chamber are open, and the drunk servants make a mockery of their jobs by snoring instead of protecting the king. I put so many drugs in their drinks that you can’t tell if they’re alive or dead.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(within)     Who’s there? What, ho!$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(from offstage) Who’s there? What is it?$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Alack, I am afraid they have awaked,$NEWLINE$And ’tis not done. Th' attempt and not the deed$NEWLINE$Confounds us. Hark! I laid their daggers ready;$NEWLINE$He could not miss 'em. Had he not resembled$NEWLINE$My father as he slept, I had done ’t.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Oh no, I’m afraid the servants woke up, and the murder didn’t happen. For us to attempt murder and not succeed would ruin us. (She hears a noise.) Listen to that! I put the servants' daggers where Macbeth would find them. He couldn’t have missed them. If Duncan hadn’t reminded me of my father when I saw him sleeping, I would have killed him myself.$NEWLINE$(She hears a noise.)

paragraphs.original: Enter MACBETH, with bloody daggers$NEWLINE$MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH enters carrying bloody daggers.$NEWLINE$MACBETH

paragraphs.original: My husband!
paragraphs.translated: My husband!

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I have done the deed. Didst thou not hear a noise?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I have done the deed. Did you hear a noise?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$I heard the owl scream and the crickets cry.$NEWLINE$Did not you speak?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$I heard the owl scream and the crickets cry. Didn’t you say something?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$When?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$When?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Now.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Just now.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$As I descended?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$As I came down?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Ay.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Yes.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Hark! Who lies i' th' second chamber?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Listen! Who’s sleeping in the second chamber?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Donalbain.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Donalbain.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(looking at his hands) This is a sorry sight.$NEWLINE$(looking at his hands)
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(looking at his bloody hands) This is a sorry sight.$NEWLINE$(looking at his bloody hands)

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$A foolish thought, to say a sorry sight.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$That’s a stupid thing to say.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$There’s one did laugh in ’s sleep, and one cried. “Murder!”$NEWLINE$That they did wake each other. I stood and heard them.$NEWLINE$But they did say their prayers, and addressed them$NEWLINE$Again to sleep.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$One of the servants laughed in his sleep, and one cried, “Murder!” and they woke each other up. I stood and listened to them, but then they said their prayers and went back to sleep.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$There are two lodged together.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Malcolm and Donalbain are asleep in the same room.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$One cried, “God bless us!” and “Amen” the other,$NEWLINE$As they had seen me with these hangman’s hands.$NEWLINE$List'ning their fear I could not say “Amen,”$NEWLINE$When they did say “God bless us!”
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$One servant cried, “God bless us!” and the other replied, “Amen,” as if they had seen my bloody hands. Listening to their frightened voices, I couldn’t reply “Amen” when they said “God bless us!”

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Consider it not so deeply.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Don’t think about it so much.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$But wherefore could not I pronounce “Amen”?$NEWLINE$I had most need of blessing, and “Amen”$NEWLINE$Stuck in my throat.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$But why couldn’t I say “Amen”? I desperately needed God’s blessing, but the word “Amen” stuck in my throat.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$These deeds must not be thought$NEWLINE$After these ways. So, it will make us mad.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$We can’t think that way about what we did. If we do, it’ll drive us crazy.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Methought I heard a voice cry, “Sleep no more!$NEWLINE$Macbeth does murder sleep”—the innocent sleep,$NEWLINE$Sleep that knits up the raveled sleave of care,$NEWLINE$The death of each day’s life, sore labor’s bath,$NEWLINE$Balm of hurt minds, great nature’s second course,$NEWLINE$Chief nourisher in life’s feast.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I thought I heard a voice cry, “Sleep no more! Macbeth is murdering sleep.” Innocent sleep. Sleep that soothes away all our worries. Sleep that puts each day to rest. Sleep that relieves the weary laborer and heals hurt minds. Sleep, the main course in life’s feast, and the most nourishing.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$What do you mean?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$What are you talking about?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Still it cried, “Sleep no more!” to all the house.$NEWLINE$“Glamis hath murdered sleep, and therefore Cawdor$NEWLINE$Shall sleep no more. Macbeth shall sleep no more.”
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$The voice kept crying, “Sleep no more!” to everyone in the house. “Macbeth has murdered sleep, and therefore Macbeth will sleep no more.”
