paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Who was it that thus cried? Why, worthy thane,$NEWLINE$You do unbend your noble strength to think$NEWLINE$So brainsickly of things. Go get some water,$NEWLINE$And wash this filthy witness from your hand.$NEWLINE$Why did you bring these daggers from the place?$NEWLINE$They must lie there. Go carry them and smear$NEWLINE$The sleepy grooms with blood.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Who said that? Why, my worthy lord, you let yourself become weak when you think about things in this cowardly way. Go get some water and wash this bloody evidence from your hands. Why did you carry these daggers out of the room? They have to stay there. Go take them back and smear the sleeping guards with the blood.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I’ll go no more:$NEWLINE$I am afraid to think what I have done;$NEWLINE$Look on ’t again I dare not.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I can’t go back. I’m afraid even to think about what I’ve done. I can’t stand to look at it again.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Infirm of purpose!$NEWLINE$Give me the daggers. The sleeping and the dead$NEWLINE$Are but as pictures. 'Tis the eye of childhood$NEWLINE$That fears a painted devil. If he do bleed,$NEWLINE$I’ll gild the faces of the grooms withal,$NEWLINE$For it must seem their guilt.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Coward! Give me the daggers. Dead and sleeping people can’t hurt you any more than pictures can. Only children are afraid of scary pictures. If Duncan bleeds I’ll paint the servants' faces with his blood. We must make it seem like they’re guilty.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH exits.$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH

paragraphs.original: Knock within
paragraphs.translated: A sound of knocking from offstage.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Whence is that knocking?$NEWLINE$How is ’t with me when every noise appals me?$NEWLINE$What hands are here? Ha! They pluck out mine eyes.$NEWLINE$Will all great Neptune’s ocean wash this blood$NEWLINE$Clean from my hand? No, this my hand will rather$NEWLINE$The multitudinous seas incarnadine,$NEWLINE$Making the green one red.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Where is that knocking coming from? What’s happening to me, that I’m frightened of every noise? (looking at his hands) Whose hands are these? Ha! They’re plucking out my eyes. Will all the water in the ocean wash this blood from my hands? No, instead my hands will stain the seas scarlet, turning the green waters red.$NEWLINE$(looking at his hands)

paragraphs.original: Enter LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH enters.$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$My hands are of your color, but I shame$NEWLINE$To wear a heart so white.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$My hands are as red as yours, but I would be ashamed if my heart were as pale and weak.

paragraphs.original: Knock within
paragraphs.translated: A sound of knocking from offstage.

paragraphs.original: I hear a knocking$NEWLINE$At the south entry. Retire we to our chamber.$NEWLINE$A little water clears us of this deed.$NEWLINE$How easy is it, then! Your constancy$NEWLINE$Hath left you unattended.
paragraphs.translated: I hear someone knocking at the south entry. Let’s go back to our bedroom. A little water will wash away the evidence of our guilt. It’s so simple! You’ve lost your resolve.

paragraphs.original: Knock within
paragraphs.translated: A sound of knocking from offstage.

paragraphs.original: Hark! More knocking.$NEWLINE$Get on your nightgown, lest occasion call us$NEWLINE$And show us to be watchers. Be not lost$NEWLINE$So poorly in your thoughts.
paragraphs.translated: Listen! There’s more knocking. Put on your nightgown, in case someone comes and sees that we’re awake. Snap out of your daze.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$To know my deed, ’twere best not know myself.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Rather than have to think about my crime, I’d prefer to be completely unconscious.

paragraphs.original: Knock within
paragraphs.translated: A sound of knocking from offstage.

paragraphs.original: Wake Duncan with thy knocking. I would thou couldst.
paragraphs.translated: Wake Duncan with your knocking. I wish you could!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter a PORTER. Knocking within$NEWLINE$PORTER
paragraphs.translated:
A sound of knocking from offstage. A
PORTER , who is obviously drunk, enters.$NEWLINE$PORTER$NEWLINE$PORTER$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PORTER$NEWLINE$Here’s a knocking indeed! If a man were porter of hell-gate, he should have old turning the key.
paragraphs.translated: PORTER$NEWLINE$This is a lot of knocking! Come to think of it, if a man were in charge of opening the gates of hell to let people in, he would have to turn the key a lot.

paragraphs.original: Knock within
paragraphs.translated: A sound of knocking from offstage.

paragraphs.original: Knock, knock, knock! Who’s there, i' th' name of Beelzebub? Here’s a farmer that hanged himself on the expectation of plenty. Come in time, have napkins enough about you, here you’ll sweat for ’t.
paragraphs.translated: Knock, knock, knock! (pretending he’s the gatekeeper in hell) Who’s there, in the devil’s name? Maybe it’s a farmer who killed himself because grain was cheap. (talking to the imaginary farmer) You’re here just in time! I hope you brought some handkerchiefs; you’re going to sweat a lot here.$NEWLINE$(pretending he’s the gatekeeper in hell)$NEWLINE$(talking to the imaginary farmer)

paragraphs.original: Knock within
paragraphs.translated: A sound of knocking from offstage.

paragraphs.original: Knock, knock! Who’s there, in th' other devil’s name? Faith, here’s an equivocator that could swear in both the scales against either scale, who committed treason enough for God’s sake, yet could not equivocate to heaven. O, come in, equivocator.
paragraphs.translated: Knock, knock! Who’s there, in the other devil’s name? Maybe it’s some slick, two-faced con man who lied under oath. But he found out that you can’t lie to God, and now he’s going to hell for perjury. Come on in, con man.

paragraphs.original: Knock within
paragraphs.translated: A sound of knocking from offstage.

paragraphs.original: Knock, knock, knock! Who’s there? Faith, here’s an English tailor come hither for stealing out of a French hose. Come in, tailor. Here you may roast your goose.
paragraphs.translated: Knock, knock, knock! Who’s there? Maybe it’s an English tailor who liked to skimp on the fabric for people’s clothes. But now that tight pants are in fashion he can’t get away with it. Come on in, tailor. You can heat your iron up in here.

paragraphs.original: Knock within
paragraphs.translated: A sound of knocking from offstage.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Knock, knock! Never at quiet. What are you? But this place is too cold for hell. I’ll devil-porter it no further. I had thought to have let in some of all professions that go the primrose way to the everlasting bonfire.
paragraphs.translated: Knock, knock! Never a moment of peace! Who are you? Ah, this place is too cold to be hell. I won’t pretend to be the devil’s porter anymore. I was going to let someone from every profession into hell.

paragraphs.original: Knock within
paragraphs.translated: A sound of knocking from offstage.

paragraphs.original: Anon, anon! I pray you, remember the porter.
paragraphs.translated: I’m coming, I’m coming! Please, don’t forget to leave me a tip.

paragraphs.original: Opens the gate
paragraphs.translated: The PORTER opens the gate.$NEWLINE$PORTER

paragraphs.original: Enter MACDUFF and LENNOX$NEWLINE$MACDUFF$NEWLINE$LENNOX
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF and LENNOX enter.$NEWLINE$MACDUFF$NEWLINE$LENNOX

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Was it so late, friend, ere you went to bed,$NEWLINE$That you do lie so late?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Did you go to bed so late, my friend, that you’re having a hard time getting up now?

paragraphs.original: PORTER$NEWLINE$'Faith sir, we were carousing till the second cock. And drink, sir, is a great provoker of three things.
paragraphs.translated: PORTER$NEWLINE$That’s right sir, we were drinking until 3 A.M., and drink, sir, makes a man do three things.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$What three things does drink especially provoke?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$What three things does drink make a man do?

paragraphs.original: PORTER$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, nose-painting, sleep, and urine. Lechery, sir, it provokes and unprovokes. It provokes the desire, but it takes away the performance. Therefore, much drink may be said to be an equivocator with lechery. It makes him, and it mars him; it sets him on, and it takes him off; it persuades him, and disheartens him; makes him stand to and not stand to; in conclusion, equivocates him in a sleep, and, giving him the lie, leaves him.
paragraphs.translated: PORTER$NEWLINE$Drinking turns your nose red, it puts you to sleep, and it makes you urinate. Lust it turns on but also turns off. What I mean is, drinking stimulates desire but hinders performance. Therefore, too much drink is like a con artist when it comes to your sex drive. It sets you up for a fall. It gets you up but it keeps you from getting off. It persuades you and discourages you. It gives you an erection but doesn’t let you keep it, if you see what I’m saying. It makes you dream about erotic experiences, but then it leaves you asleep and needing to pee.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I believe drink gave thee the lie last night.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I believe drink did all of this to you last night.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PORTER$NEWLINE$That it did, sir, i' th' very throat on me; but I requited him for his lie, and, I think, being too strong for him, though he took up my legs sometime, yet I made a shift to cast him.
paragraphs.translated: PORTER$NEWLINE$It did, sir. It got me right in the throat. But I got even with drink. I was too strong for it. Although it weakened my legs and made me unsteady, I managed to vomit it out and laid it flat on the ground.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Is thy master stirring?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Is your master awake?

paragraphs.original: Enter MACBETH$NEWLINE$MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH enters.$NEWLINE$MACBETH

paragraphs.original: Our knocking has awaked him. Here he comes.
paragraphs.translated: Our knocking woke him up. Here he comes.

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Good morrow, noble sir.
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Good morning, noble sir.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Good morrow, both.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Good morning to both of you.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Is the king stirring, worthy thane?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Is the king awake, worthy thane?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Not yet.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Not yet.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$He did command me to call timely on him.$NEWLINE$I have almost slipped the hour.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$He commanded me to wake him up early. I’ve almost missed the time he requested.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I’ll bring you to him.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I’ll bring you to him.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I know this is a joyful trouble to you,$NEWLINE$But yet ’tis one.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I know the burden of hosting him is both an honor and a trouble, but that doesn’t mean it’s not a trouble just the same.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$The labor we delight in physics pain.$NEWLINE$This is the door.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$The work we enjoy is not really work. This is the door.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I’ll make so bold to call,$NEWLINE$For ’tis my limited service.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I’ll wake him, because that’s my job.

paragraphs.original: Exit MACDUFF$NEWLINE$MACDUFF
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF exits.$NEWLINE$MACDUFF

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Goes the king hence today?
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Is the king leaving here today?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$He does. He did appoint so.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$He is. He told us to arrange it.

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$The night has been unruly. Where we lay,$NEWLINE$Our chimneys were blown down and, as they say,$NEWLINE$Lamentings heard i' th' air, strange screams of death,$NEWLINE$And prophesying with accents terrible$NEWLINE$Of dire combustion and confused events$NEWLINE$New hatched to the woeful time. The obscure bird$NEWLINE$Clamored the livelong night. Some say the Earth$NEWLINE$Was feverous and did shake.
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$The night has been chaotic. The wind blew down through the chimneys where we were sleeping. People are saying they heard cries of grief in the air, strange screams of death, and terrible voices predicting catastrophes that will usher in a woeful new age. The owl made noise all night. Some people say that the earth shook as if it had a fever.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$'Twas a rough night.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$It was a rough night.

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$My young remembrance cannot parallel$NEWLINE$A fellow to it.
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$I’m too young to remember anything like it.

paragraphs.original: Enter MACDUFF$NEWLINE$MACDUFF
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF enters, upset.$NEWLINE$MACDUFF

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$O horror, horror, horror!$NEWLINE$Tongue nor heart cannot conceive nor name thee!
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Oh, horror, horror, horror! This is beyond words and beyond belief!

paragraphs.original: MACBETH & LENNOX$NEWLINE$What’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH & LENNOX$NEWLINE$What’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Confusion now hath made his masterpiece.$NEWLINE$Most sacrilegious murder hath broke ope$NEWLINE$The Lord’s anointed temple, and stole thence$NEWLINE$The life o' th' building!
paragraphs.translated:
MACDUFF$NEWLINE$The worst thing imaginable has happened. A murderer has broken into
God’s temple and stolen the life out of it.$NEWLINE$God’s temple$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$What is ’t you say? “The life”?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$What are you talking about? “The life”?

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Mean you his majesty?
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Do you mean the king?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Approach the chamber, and destroy your sight$NEWLINE$With a new Gorgon. Do not bid me speak.$NEWLINE$See, and then speak yourselves.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Go into the bedroom and see for yourself. What’s in there will make you freeze with horror. Don’t ask me to talk about it. Go look and then do the talking yourselves.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt MACBETH and LENNOX$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$LENNOX
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH and LENNOX exit.$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$LENNOX

paragraphs.original: Awake, awake!$NEWLINE$Ring the alarum bell. Murder and treason!$NEWLINE$Banquo and Donalbain! Malcolm! Awake!$NEWLINE$Shake off this downy sleep, death’s counterfeit,$NEWLINE$And look on death itself! Up, up, and see$NEWLINE$The great doom’s image! Malcolm! Banquo!$NEWLINE$As from your graves rise up, and walk like sprites,$NEWLINE$To countenance this horror! Ring the bell
paragraphs.translated: Wake up, wake up! Ring the alarm bell. Murder and treason! Banquo and Donalbain, Malcolm! Wake up! Shake off sleep, which looks like death, and look at death itself! Get up, get up, and look at this image of doomsday! Malcolm! Banquo! Get up from your beds as if you were rising out of your own graves, and walk like ghosts to come witness this horror. Ring the bell.

paragraphs.original: Bell rings. Enter LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: A bell rings. LADY MACBETH enters.$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$What’s the business,$NEWLINE$That such a hideous trumpet calls to parley$NEWLINE$The sleepers of the house? Speak, speak!
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$What’s going on? Why is that terrifying trumpet calling together everyone who’s sleeping in the house? Speak up and tell me!

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$O gentle lady,$NEWLINE$'Tis not for you to hear what I can speak:$NEWLINE$The repetition, in a woman’s ear,$NEWLINE$Would murder as it fell.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Oh gentle lady, my news isn’t fit for your ears. If I repeated it to you, it would kill you as soon as you heard it.

paragraphs.original: Enter BANQUO$NEWLINE$BANQUO
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO enters.$NEWLINE$BANQUO

paragraphs.original: O Banquo, Banquo,$NEWLINE$Our royal master’s murdered!
paragraphs.translated: Oh Banquo, Banquo, the king has been murdered!

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Woe, alas!$NEWLINE$What, in our house?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$How horrible! What, in our own house?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Too cruel any where.$NEWLINE$Dear Duff, I prithee, contradict thyself,$NEWLINE$And say it is not so.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$It would be a terrible event no matter where it happened. Dear Macduff, I beg you, tell us you were lying and say it isn’t so.

paragraphs.original: Enter MACBETH, LENNOX, and ROSS$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$LENNOX$NEWLINE$ROSS
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH and LENNOX reenter, with ROSS.$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$LENNOX$NEWLINE$ROSS

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Had I but died an hour before this chance,$NEWLINE$I had lived a blessèd time, for from this instant$NEWLINE$There’s nothing serious in mortality.$NEWLINE$All is but toys. Renown and grace is dead.$NEWLINE$The wine of life is drawn, and the mere lees$NEWLINE$Is left this vault to brag of.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$If I had only died an hour before this event I could say I had lived a blessed life. Because from this moment on, there is nothing worth living for. Everything is a sick joke. The graceful and renowned king is dead. The wine of life has been poured out, and only the dregs remain.

paragraphs.original: Enter MALCOLM and DONALBAIN$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$DONALBAIN
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM and DONALBAIN enter.$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$DONALBAIN

paragraphs.original: DONALBAIN$NEWLINE$What is amiss?
paragraphs.translated: DONALBAIN$NEWLINE$What’s wrong?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$You are, and do not know ’t.$NEWLINE$The spring, the head, the fountain of your blood$NEWLINE$Is stopped; the very source of it is stopped.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$You are, but you don’t know it yet. The source from which your royal blood comes has been stopped.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Your royal father’s murdered.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Your royal father is murdered.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Oh, by whom?
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Who did it?

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Those of his chamber, as it seemed, had done ’t.$NEWLINE$Their hands and faces were all badged with blood.$NEWLINE$So were their daggers, which unwiped we found$NEWLINE$Upon their pillows. They stared, and were distracted.$NEWLINE$No man’s life was to be trusted with them.
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$It seems that the guards who were supposed to be protecting his chamber did it. Their hands and faces were all covered with blood. So were their daggers, which we found on their pillows, unwiped. They stared at us in confusion. No one’s life should have been entrusted to them.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Oh, yet I do repent me of my fury,$NEWLINE$That I did kill them.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$And yet I still regret the anger that drove me to kill them.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Wherefore did you so?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$What did you do that for?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Who can be wise, amazed, temp'rate, and furious,$NEWLINE$Loyal and neutral, in a moment? No man.$NEWLINE$Th' expedition of my violent love$NEWLINE$Outrun the pauser, reason. Here lay Duncan,$NEWLINE$His silver skin laced with his golden blood,$NEWLINE$And his gashed stabs looked like a breach in nature$NEWLINE$For ruin’s wasteful entrance; there, the murderers,$NEWLINE$Steeped in the colors of their trade, their daggers$NEWLINE$Unmannerly breeched with gore. Who could refrain,$NEWLINE$That had a heart to love, and in that heart$NEWLINE$Courage to make ’s love known?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Is it possible to be wise, bewildered, calm, furious, loyal, and neutral all at once? Nobody can do that. The violent rage inspired by my love for Duncan caused me to act before I could think rationally and tell myself to pause. There was Duncan, his white skin all splattered with his precious blood. The gashes where the knives had cut him looked like wounds to nature itself. Then right next to him I saw the murderers, dripping with blood, their daggers rudely covered in gore. Who could have restrained himself, who loved Duncan and had the courage to act on it?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Help me hence, ho!
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Help me out of here, quickly!

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Look to the lady.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Take care of the lady.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$(aside to DONALBAIN ) Why do we hold our tongues,$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$That most may claim this argument for ours?
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only DONALBAIN can hear) Why are we keeping quiet? The two of us have the most to say in this matter.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: DONALBAIN$NEWLINE$(aside to MALCOLM) What should be spoken here, where our fate,$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Hid in an auger-hole, may rush and seize us?$NEWLINE$Let’s away. Our tears are not yet brewed.
paragraphs.translated: DONALBAIN$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only MALCOLM can hear) What are we going to say here, where danger may be waiting to strike at us from anywhere? Let’s get out of here. We haven’t even begun to weep yet—but there will be time for that later.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$(aside to DONALBAIN) Nor our strong sorrow$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Upon the foot of motion.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only DONALBAIN can hear) And the time hasn’t come yet for us to turn our deep grief into action.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Look to the lady.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Take care of the lady.

paragraphs.original: Exit LADY MACBETH, attended$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH is carried out.$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And when we have our naked frailties hid,$NEWLINE$That suffer in exposure, let us meet$NEWLINE$And question this most bloody piece of work,$NEWLINE$To know it further. Fears and scruples shake us.$NEWLINE$In the great hand of God I stand, and thence$NEWLINE$Against the undivulged pretense I fight$NEWLINE$Of treasonous malice.
paragraphs.translated: When we’re properly dressed for the cold, let’s meet and discuss this bloody crime to see if we can figure anything out. Right now we’re shaken up by fears and doubts. I’m putting myself in God’s hands, and with his help I plan to fight against the secret plot that caused this treasonous murder.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$And so do I.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$So will I.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$So all.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$So will we all.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Let’s briefly put on manly readiness,$NEWLINE$And meet i' th' hall together.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Let’s get dressed quickly and then meet in the hall.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Well contented.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Agreed.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but MALCOLM and DONALBAIN$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$DONALBAIN
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except MALCOLM and DONALBAIN.$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$DONALBAIN

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$What will you do? Let’s not consort with them.$NEWLINE$To show an unfelt sorrow is an office$NEWLINE$Which the false man does easy. I’ll to England.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$What are you going to do? Let’s not stay here with them. It’s easy for a liar to pretend to feel sorrow when he actually feels none. I’m going to England.

paragraphs.original: DONALBAIN$NEWLINE$To Ireland, I. Our separated fortune$NEWLINE$Shall keep us both the safer. Where we are,$NEWLINE$There’s daggers in men’s smiles. The near in blood,$NEWLINE$The nearer bloody.
paragraphs.translated: DONALBAIN$NEWLINE$I’ll go to Ireland. We’ll both be safer if we go separate ways. Wherever we go, men will smile at us while hiding daggers. Our closest relatives are the ones most likely to murder us.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$This murderous shaft that’s shot$NEWLINE$Hath not yet lighted, and our safest way$NEWLINE$Is to avoid the aim. Therefore, to horse,$NEWLINE$And let us not be dainty of leave-taking,$NEWLINE$But shift away. There’s warrant in that theft$NEWLINE$Which steals itself when there’s no mercy left.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$We haven’t yet encountered that danger, and the best thing to do is avoid it entirely. With that in mind, let’s get on our horses. We’d better not worry about saying polite good-byes; we should just get away quickly. There’s good reason to escape when there’s no mercy to be found anymore.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ROSS with an OLD MAN$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$OLD MAN
paragraphs.translated: ROSS and an OLD MAN enter.$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$OLD MAN

paragraphs.original: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$Threescore and ten I can remember well,$NEWLINE$Within the volume of which time I have seen$NEWLINE$Hours dreadful and things strange, but this sore night$NEWLINE$Hath trifled former knowings.
paragraphs.translated: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$I can remember the past seventy years pretty well, and in all that time I have seen dreadful hours and strange things. But last night’s horrors make everything that came before seem like a joke.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Ha, good father,$NEWLINE$Thou seest the heavens, as troubled with man’s act,$NEWLINE$Threatens his bloody stage. By th' clock ’tis day,$NEWLINE$And yet dark night strangles the travelling lamp.$NEWLINE$Is ’t night’s predominance or the day’s shame$NEWLINE$That darkness does the face of Earth entomb$NEWLINE$When living light should kiss it?
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$Ah yes, old man. You can see the skies. They look like they’re upset about what mankind has been doing, and they’re threatening the Earth with storms. The clock says it’s daytime, but dark night is strangling the sun. Is it because night is so strong, or because day is so weak, that darkness covers the earth when it’s supposed to be light?

paragraphs.original: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$'Tis unnatural,$NEWLINE$Even like the deed that’s done. On Tuesday last,$NEWLINE$A falcon, tow'ring in her pride of place,$NEWLINE$Was by a mousing owl hawked at and killed.
paragraphs.translated: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$It’s unnatural, just like the murder that has been committed. Last Tuesday a falcon was circling high in the sky, and it was caught and killed by an ordinary owl that usually goes after mice.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$And Duncan’s horses—a thing most strange and certain—$NEWLINE$Beauteous and swift, the minions of their race,$NEWLINE$Turned wild in nature, broke their stalls, flung out,$NEWLINE$Contending 'gainst obedience, as they would$NEWLINE$Make war with mankind.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$And something else strange happened. Duncan’s horses, which are beautiful and swift and the best of their breed, suddenly turned wild and broke out of their stalls. Refusing to be obedient as usual, they acted like they were at war with mankind.

paragraphs.original: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$'Tis said they eat each other.
paragraphs.translated: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$They say the horses ate each other.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$They did so, to th' amazement of mine eyes$NEWLINE$That looked upon ’t. Here comes the good Macduff.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$I saw it with my own eyes. It was an amazing sight. Here comes the good Macduff.

paragraphs.original: Enter MACDUFF$NEWLINE$MACDUFF
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF enters.$NEWLINE$MACDUFF

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: How goes the world, sir, now?
paragraphs.translated: How are things going now?

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Why, see you not?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Can’t you see for yourself?

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Is ’t known who did this more than bloody deed?
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$Does anyone know who committed this horrible crime?

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Those that Macbeth hath slain.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$The servants Macbeth killed.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Alas, the day!$NEWLINE$What good could they pretend?
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$It’s too bad he killed them. What good would it have done those men to kill Duncan?

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$They were suborned.$NEWLINE$Malcolm and Donalbain, the king’s two sons,$NEWLINE$Are stol'n away and fled, which puts upon them$NEWLINE$Suspicion of the deed.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$They were paid to betray their master. Malcolm and Donalbain, the king’s two sons, have run away and fled, which makes them the prime suspects.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$'Gainst nature still!$NEWLINE$Thriftless ambition, that will raven up$NEWLINE$Thine own lives' means! Then ’tis most like$NEWLINE$The sovereignty will fall upon Macbeth.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$Everything about this is unnatural! What a stupid ambition, causing a son to kill the father who supports him. Then it looks like Macbeth will become king.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$He is already named and gone to Scone$NEWLINE$To be invested.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$He has already been named king and has left for Scone to be crowned.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Where is Duncan’s body?
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$Where is Duncan’s body?

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Carried to Colmekill,$NEWLINE$The sacred storehouse of his predecessors,$NEWLINE$And guardian of their bones.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$It was carried to Colmekill to be placed in the tomb of his ancestors, where their bones are kept safe.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Will you to Scone?
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$Are you going to Scone?

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$No, cousin, I’ll to Fife.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$No, cousin, I’m going to Fife.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Well, I will thither.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$Well, I’ll go to Scone.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Well, may you see things well done there. Adieu,$NEWLINE$Lest our old robes sit easier than our new!
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I hope things go well there. Good-bye! And let’s hope things don’t get worse.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Farewell, father.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$Farewell, old man.

paragraphs.original: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$God’s benison go with you and with those$NEWLINE$That would make good of bad and friends of foes.
paragraphs.translated: OLD MAN$NEWLINE$May God’s blessing go with you and with all who turn bad into good, and enemies into friends!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter BANQUO$NEWLINE$BANQUO
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO enters.$NEWLINE$BANQUO

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Thou hast it now: king, Cawdor, Glamis, all,$NEWLINE$As the weird women promised, and I fear$NEWLINE$Thou played’st most foully for ’t. Yet it was said$NEWLINE$It should not stand in thy posterity,$NEWLINE$But that myself should be the root and father$NEWLINE$Of many kings. If there come truth from them—$NEWLINE$As upon thee, Macbeth, their speeches shine—$NEWLINE$Why, by the verities on thee made good,$NEWLINE$May they not be my oracles as well,$NEWLINE$And set me up in hope? But hush, no more.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Now you have it all: you’re the king, the thane of Cawdor, and the thane of Glamis, just like the weird women promised you. And I suspect you cheated to win these titles. But it was also prophesied that the crown would not go to your descendants, and that my sons and grandsons would be kings instead. If the witches tell the truth—which they did about you—maybe what they said about me will come true too. But shhh! I’ll shut up now.

paragraphs.original: Sennet sounded. Enter MACBETH, as king, LADY MACBETH, as queen, LENNOX, ROSS, LORDS, LADIES, and attendants$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$LENNOX$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$LORDS$NEWLINE$LADIES
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet plays. MACBETH enters dressed as king, and LADY MACBETH enters dressed as queen, together with LENNOX, ROSS, LORDS, LADIES, and their attendants$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$LENNOX$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$LORDS$NEWLINE$LADIES

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Here’s our chief guest.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(indicating BANQUO) Here’s our most important guest.$NEWLINE$(indicating BANQUO)

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$If he had been forgotten,$NEWLINE$It had been as a gap in our great feast,$NEWLINE$And all-thing unbecoming.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$If we forgot him, our big celebration wouldn’t be complete, and that wouldn’t be any good.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Tonight we hold a solemn supper, sir,$NEWLINE$And I’ll request your presence.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(to BANQUO) Tonight we’re having a ceremonial banquet, and I want you to be there.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Let your highness$NEWLINE$Command upon me, to the which my duties$NEWLINE$Are with a most indissoluble tie$NEWLINE$Forever knit.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Whatever your highness commands me to do, it is always my duty to do it.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Ride you this afternoon?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Are you going riding this afternoon?

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Ay, my good lord.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Yes, my good lord.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$We should have else desired your good advice—$NEWLINE$Which still hath been both grave and prosperous—$NEWLINE$In this day’s council, but we’ll take tomorrow.$NEWLINE$Is ’t far you ride?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$We would have liked to have heard your good advice, which has always been serious and helpful, at the council today, but we’ll wait until tomorrow. Are you riding far?

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$As far, my lord, as will fill up the time$NEWLINE$'Twixt this and supper. Go not my horse the better,$NEWLINE$I must become a borrower of the night$NEWLINE$For a dark hour or twain.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$I’m going far enough that I’ll be riding from now until dinner. Unless my horse goes faster than expected, I will be back an hour or two after sunset.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Fail not our feast.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Don’t miss our feast.

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$My lord, I will not.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$My lord, I won’t miss it.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$We hear our bloody cousins are bestowed$NEWLINE$In England and in Ireland, not confessing$NEWLINE$Their cruel parricide, filling their hearers$NEWLINE$With strange invention. But of that tomorrow,$NEWLINE$When therewithal we shall have cause of state$NEWLINE$Craving us jointly. Hie you to horse. Adieu,$NEWLINE$Till your return at night. Goes Fleance with you?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$We hear that the princes, those murderers, have hidden in England and Ireland. They haven’t confessed to cruelly murdering their own father, and they’ve been making up strange lies to tell their hosts. But we can talk more about that tomorrow, when we’ll discuss matters of state that concern us both. Hurry up and get to your horse. Good-bye, until you return tonight. Is Fleance going with you?

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Ay, my good lord. Our time does call upon ’s.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Yes, my good lord. It’s time we hit the road.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I wish your horses swift and sure of foot,$NEWLINE$And so I do commend you to their backs.$NEWLINE$Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I hope your horses are fast and surefooted. And with that, I send you to them. Farewell.

paragraphs.original: Exit BANQUO$NEWLINE$BANQUO
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO exits.$NEWLINE$BANQUO

paragraphs.original: Let every man be master of his time$NEWLINE$Till seven at night. To make society$NEWLINE$The sweeter welcome, we will keep ourself$NEWLINE$Till suppertime alone. While then, God be with you!
paragraphs.translated: Everybody may do as they please until seven o'clock tonight. In order to make your company even more enjoyable, I’m going to keep to myself until suppertime. Until then, God be with you!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all except MACBETH and a SERVANT$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except MACBETH and a SERVANT$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: Sirrah, a word with you. Attend those men$NEWLINE$Our pleasure?
paragraphs.translated: (to the SERVANT) You there, let me have a word with you. Are those men waiting for me?$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$They are, my lord, without the palace gate.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$They’re waiting outside the palace gate, my lord.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Bring them before us.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Bring them to me.

paragraphs.original: Exit SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: The SERVANT exits.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: To be thus is nothing,$NEWLINE$But to be safely thus. Our fears in Banquo$NEWLINE$Stick deep, and in his royalty of nature$NEWLINE$Reigns that which would be feared. 'Tis much he dares,$NEWLINE$And to that dauntless temper of his mind$NEWLINE$He hath a wisdom that doth guide his valor$NEWLINE$To act in safety. There is none but he$NEWLINE$Whose being I do fear, and under him$NEWLINE$My genius is rebuked, as it is said$NEWLINE$Mark Antony’s was by Caesar. He chid the sisters$NEWLINE$When first they put the name of king upon me$NEWLINE$And bade them speak to him. Then, prophetlike,$NEWLINE$They hailed him father to a line of kings.$NEWLINE$Upon my head they placed a fruitless crown$NEWLINE$And put a barren scepter in my grip,$NEWLINE$Thence to be wrenched with an unlineal hand,$NEWLINE$No son of mine succeeding. If ’t be so,$NEWLINE$For Banquo’s issue have I filed my mind;$NEWLINE$For them the gracious Duncan have I murdered;$NEWLINE$Put rancors in the vessel of my peace$NEWLINE$Only for them; and mine eternal jewel$NEWLINE$Given to the common enemy of man,$NEWLINE$To make them kings, the seed of Banquo kings!$NEWLINE$Rather than so, come fate into the list,$NEWLINE$And champion me to th' utterance. Who’s there?
paragraphs.translated: To be the king is nothing if I’m not safe as the king. I’m very afraid of Banquo. There’s something noble about him that makes me fear him. He’s willing to take risks, and his mind never stops working. He has the wisdom to act bravely but also safely. I’m not afraid of anyone but him. Around him, my guardian angel is frightened, just as Mark Antony’s angel supposedly feared Octavius Caesar. Banquo chided the witches when they first called me king, asking them to tell him his own future. Then, like prophets, they named him the father to a line of kings. They gave me a crown and a scepter that I can’t pass on. Someone outside my family will take these things away from me, since no son of mine will take my place as king. If this is true, then I’ve tortured my conscience and murdered the gracious Duncan for Banquo’s sons. I’ve ruined my own peace for their benefit. I’ve handed over my everlasting soul to the devil so that they could be kings. Banquo’s sons, kings! Instead of watching that happen, I will challenge fate to battle and fight to the death. Who’s there!

paragraphs.original: Enter SERVANT and two MURDERERS$NEWLINE$SERVANT$NEWLINE$MURDERERS
paragraphs.translated: The SERVANT comes back in with two MURDERERS$NEWLINE$SERVANT$NEWLINE$MURDERERS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Now go to the door and stay there till we call.
paragraphs.translated: Now go to the door and stay there until I call for you.

paragraphs.original: Exit SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: The SERVANT exits.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: Was it not yesterday we spoke together?
paragraphs.translated: Wasn’t it just yesterday that we spoke to each other?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$It was, so please your highness.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$It was yesterday, your highness.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Well then, now$NEWLINE$Have you considered of my speeches? Know$NEWLINE$That it was he, in the times past, which held you$NEWLINE$So under fortune, which you thought had been$NEWLINE$Our innocent self. This I made good to you$NEWLINE$In our last conference, passed in probation with you,$NEWLINE$How you were borne in hand, how crossed, the instruments,$NEWLINE$Who wrought with them, and all things else that might$NEWLINE$To half a soul and to a notion crazed$NEWLINE$Say, “Thus did Banquo.”
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Well, did you think about what I said? You should know that it was Banquo who made your lives hell for so long, which you always thought was my fault. But I was innocent. I showed you the proof at our last meeting. I explained how you were deceived, how you were thwarted, the things that were used against you, who was working against you, and a lot of other things that would convince even a half-wit or a crazy person to say, “Banquo did it!”

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$You made it known to us.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$You explained it all.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I did so, and went further, which is now$NEWLINE$Our point of second meeting. Do you find$NEWLINE$Your patience so predominant in your nature$NEWLINE$That you can let this go? Are you so gospeled$NEWLINE$To pray for this good man and for his issue,$NEWLINE$Whose heavy hand hath bowed you to the grave$NEWLINE$And beggared yours forever?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I did that and more, which brings me to the point of this second meeting. Are you so patient and forgiving that you’re going to let him off the hook? Are you so pious that you would pray for this man and his children, a man who has pushed you toward an early grave and put your family in poverty forever?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$We are men, my liege.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$We are men, my lord.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Ay, in the catalogue ye go for men,$NEWLINE$As hounds and greyhounds, mongrels, spaniels, curs,$NEWLINE$Shoughs, water-rugs, and demi-wolves are clept$NEWLINE$All by the name of dogs. The valued file$NEWLINE$Distinguishes the swift, the slow, the subtle,$NEWLINE$The housekeeper, the hunter, every one$NEWLINE$According to the gift which bounteous nature$NEWLINE$Hath in him closed, whereby he does receive$NEWLINE$Particular addition, from the bill$NEWLINE$That writes them all alike. And so of men.$NEWLINE$Now, if you have a station in the file,$NEWLINE$Not i' th' worst rank of manhood, say ’t,$NEWLINE$And I will put that business in your bosoms,$NEWLINE$Whose execution takes your enemy off,$NEWLINE$Grapples you to the heart and love of us,$NEWLINE$Who wear our health but sickly in his life,$NEWLINE$Which in his death were perfect.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Yes, you’re part of the species called men. Just as hounds and greyhounds, mongrels, spaniels, mutts, shaggy lapdogs, swimming dogs, and wolf-dog crossbreeds are all dogs. But if you list the different kinds of dogs according to their qualities, you can distinguish which breeds are fast or slow, which ones are clever, which ones are watchdogs, and which ones hunters. You can classify each dog according to the natural gifts that separate it from all other dogs. It’s the same with men. Now, if you occupy some place in the list of men that isn’t down at the very bottom, tell me. Because if that’s the case, I will tell you a plan that will get rid of your enemy and bring you closer to me. As long as Banquo lives, I am sick. I’ll be healthy when he is dead.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$I am one, my liege,$NEWLINE$Whom the vile blows and buffets of the world$NEWLINE$Have so incensed that I am reckless what$NEWLINE$I do to spite the world.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$My lord, I’ve been so kicked around by the world, and I’m so angry, that I don’t even care what I do.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$And I another$NEWLINE$So weary with disasters, tugged with fortune,$NEWLINE$That I would set my life on any chance,$NEWLINE$To mend it or be rid on ’t.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$I’m the same. I’m so sick of bad luck and trouble that I’d risk my life on any bet, as long as it would either fix my life or end it once and for all.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Both of you$NEWLINE$Know Banquo was your enemy.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$You both know Banquo was your enemy.

paragraphs.original: BOTH MURDERERS$NEWLINE$True, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: BOTH MURDERERS$NEWLINE$It’s true, my lord.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$So is he mine; and in such bloody distance$NEWLINE$That every minute of his being thrusts$NEWLINE$Against my near’st of life. And though I could$NEWLINE$With barefaced power sweep him from my sight$NEWLINE$And bid my will avouch it, yet I must not,$NEWLINE$For certain friends that are both his and mine,$NEWLINE$Whose loves I may not drop, but wail his fall$NEWLINE$Who I myself struck down. And thence it is,$NEWLINE$That I to your assistance do make love,$NEWLINE$Masking the business from the common eye$NEWLINE$For sundry weighty reasons.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$He’s my enemy too, and I hate him so much that every minute he’s alive it eats away at my heart. Since I’m king, I could simply use my power to get rid of him. But I can’t do that, because he and I have friends in common whom I need, so I have to be able to moan and cry over his death in public even though I’ll be the one who had him killed. That’s why I need your help right now. I have to hide my real plans from the public eye for many important reasons.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$We shall, my lord,$NEWLINE$Perform what you command us.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$We’ll do what you want us to, my lord.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Though our lives—
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Though our lives—

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Your spirits shine through you. Within this hour at most$NEWLINE$I will advise you where to plant yourselves,$NEWLINE$Acquaint you with the perfect spy o' th' time,$NEWLINE$The moment on ’t; for ’t must be done tonight,$NEWLINE$And something from the palace; always thought$NEWLINE$That I require a clearness. And with him—$NEWLINE$To leave no rubs nor botches in the work—$NEWLINE$Fleance, his son, that keeps him company,$NEWLINE$Whose absence is no less material to me$NEWLINE$Than is his father’s, must embrace the fate$NEWLINE$Of that dark hour. Resolve yourselves apart.$NEWLINE$I’ll come to you anon.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(interrupts him) I can see the determination in your eyes. Within the next hour I’ll tell you where to go and exactly when to strike. It must be done tonight, away from the palace. Always remember that I must be free from suspicion. For the plan to work perfectly, you must kill both Banquo and his son, Fleance, who keeps him company. Getting rid of Fleance is as important to me as knocking off Banquo. Each of you should make up your own mind about whether you’re going to do this. I’ll come to you soon.$NEWLINE$(interrupts him)

paragraphs.original: BOTH MURDERERS$NEWLINE$We are resolved, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: BOTH MURDERERS$NEWLINE$We have decided, my lord. We’re in.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I’ll call upon you straight. Abide within.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I’ll call for you soon. Stay inside.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt MURDERERS$NEWLINE$MURDERERS
paragraphs.translated: The MURDERERS exit.$NEWLINE$MURDERERS

paragraphs.original: It is concluded. Banquo, thy soul’s flight,$NEWLINE$If it find heaven, must find it out tonight.
paragraphs.translated: The deal is closed. Banquo, if your soul is going to make it to heaven, tonight’s the night.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LADY MACBETH and a SERVANT$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH and a SERVANT enter.$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Is Banquo gone from court?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Has Banquo left the court?

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Ay, madam, but returns again tonight.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Yes, madam, but he’ll be back tonight.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Say to the king I would attend his leisure$NEWLINE$For a few words.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Go tell the king I want to talk to him for a few minutes.

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Madam, I will.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$No problem, madam.

paragraphs.original: Exit SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: The SERVANT exits.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Naught’s had, all’s spent,$NEWLINE$Where our desire is got without content.$NEWLINE$'Tis safer to be that which we destroy$NEWLINE$Than by destruction dwell in doubtful joy.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$If you get what you want and you’re still not happy, you’ve spent everything and gained nothing. It’s better to be the person who gets murdered than to be the killer and be tormented with anxiety.

paragraphs.original: Enter MACBETH$NEWLINE$MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH enters.$NEWLINE$MACBETH

paragraphs.original: How now, my lord! Why do you keep alone,$NEWLINE$Of sorriest fancies your companions making,$NEWLINE$Using those thoughts which should indeed have died$NEWLINE$With them they think on? Things without all remedy$NEWLINE$Should be without regard. What’s done is done.
paragraphs.translated: What’s going on, my lord? Why are you keeping to yourself, with only your sad thoughts to keep you company? Those thoughts should have died when you killed the men you’re thinking about. If you can’t fix it, you shouldn’t give it a second thought. What’s done is done.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$We have scorched the snake, not killed it.$NEWLINE$She’ll close and be herself whilst our poor malice$NEWLINE$Remains in danger of her former tooth.$NEWLINE$But let the frame of things disjoint, both the worlds suffer,$NEWLINE$Ere we will eat our meal in fear, and sleep$NEWLINE$In the affliction of these terrible dreams$NEWLINE$That shake us nightly. Better be with the dead,$NEWLINE$Whom we, to gain our peace, have sent to peace,$NEWLINE$Than on the torture of the mind to lie$NEWLINE$In restless ecstasy. Duncan is in his grave.$NEWLINE$After life’s fitful fever he sleeps well.$NEWLINE$Treason has done his worst; nor steel nor poison,$NEWLINE$Malice domestic, foreign levy, nothing$NEWLINE$Can touch him further.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$We have slashed the snake but not killed it. It will heal and be as good as new, and we’ll be threatened by its fangs once again. But the universe can fall apart, and heaven and earth crumble, before I’ll eat my meals in fear and spend my nights tossing and turning with these nightmares I’ve been having. I’d rather be dead than endure this endless mental torture and harrowing sleep deprivation. We killed those men and sent them to rest in peace so that we could gain our own peace. Duncan lies in his grave, through with life’s troubles, and he’s sleeping well. We have already done the worst we can do to him with our treason. After that, nothing can hurt him further—not weapons, poison, rebellion, invasion, or anything else.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Come on, gentle my lord,$NEWLINE$Sleek o'er your rugged looks. Be bright and jovial$NEWLINE$Among your guests tonight.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Come on, relax, dear. Put on a happy face and look cheerful and agreeable for your guests tonight.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$So shall I, love,$NEWLINE$And so, I pray, be you. Let your remembrance$NEWLINE$Apply to Banquo; present him eminence,$NEWLINE$Both with eye and tongue: unsafe the while that we$NEWLINE$Must lave our honors in these flattering streams,$NEWLINE$And make our faces vizards to our hearts,$NEWLINE$Disguising what they are.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$That’s exactly what I’ll do, my love, and I hope you’ll do the same. Give Banquo your special attention. Talk to him and look at him in a way that will make him feel important. We’re in a dangerous situation, where we have to flatter him and hide our true feelings.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$You must leave this.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$You have to stop talking like this.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Oh, full of scorpions is my mind, dear wife!$NEWLINE$Thou know’st that Banquo, and his Fleance, lives.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Argh! I feel like my mind is full of scorpions, my dear wife. You know that Banquo and his son Fleance are still alive.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$But in them nature’s copy’s not eterne.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$But they can’t live forever.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$There’s comfort yet; they are assailable.$NEWLINE$Then be thou jocund. Ere the bat hath flown$NEWLINE$His cloistered flight, ere to black Hecate’s summons$NEWLINE$The shard-borne beetle with his drowsy hums$NEWLINE$Hath rung night’s yawning peal, there shall be done$NEWLINE$A deed of dreadful note.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$That’s comforting. They can be killed, it’s true. So be cheerful. Before the bat flies through the castle, and before the dung beetle makes his little humming noise to tell us it’s nighttime, a dreadful deed will be done.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$What’s to be done?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$What are you going to do?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Be innocent of the knowledge, dearest chuck,$NEWLINE$Till thou applaud the deed. Come, seeling night,$NEWLINE$Scarf up the tender eye of pitiful day$NEWLINE$And with thy bloody and invisible hand$NEWLINE$Cancel and tear to pieces that great bond$NEWLINE$Which keeps me pale. Light thickens, and the crow$NEWLINE$Makes wing to th' rooky wood.$NEWLINE$Good things of day begin to droop and drowse;$NEWLINE$Whiles night’s black agents to their preys do rouse.$NEWLINE$Thou marvel’st at my words: but hold thee still.$NEWLINE$Things bad begun make strong themselves by ill.$NEWLINE$So, prithee, go with me.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$It’s better you don’t know about it until after it’s done, when you can applaud it. (to the night) Come, night, and blindfold the kindhearted day. Use your bloody and invisible hand to tear up Banquo’s lease on life, which keeps me in fear. (to himself) The sky’s getting dark, and the crow is returning home to the woods. The gentle creatures of the day are falling asleep, while night’s predators are waking up to look for their prey. (to LADY MACBETH) You seem surprised at my words, but don’t question me yet. Bad deeds force you to commit more bad deeds. So please, come with me.$NEWLINE$(to the night)$NEWLINE$(to himself)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter three MURDERERS$NEWLINE$MURDERERS
paragraphs.translated: The two MURDERERS enter with a third MURDERER.$NEWLINE$MURDERERS$NEWLINE$MURDERER

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$But who did bid thee join with us?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$But who told you to come here and join us?

paragraphs.original: THIRD MURDERER$NEWLINE$Macbeth.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD MURDERER$NEWLINE$Macbeth.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$He needs not our mistrust, since he delivers$NEWLINE$Our offices and what we have to do$NEWLINE$To the direction just.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$We can trust this guy. He was given exactly the same orders we were.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Then stand with us.$NEWLINE$The west yet glimmers with some streaks of day.$NEWLINE$Now spurs the lated traveler apace$NEWLINE$To gain the timely inn, and near approaches$NEWLINE$The subject of our watch.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Then stay with us. There’s still a bit of daylight in the sky. Now all the late travellers are hurrying to reach their inns. Banquo is almost here.

paragraphs.original: THIRD MURDERER$NEWLINE$Hark, I hear horses.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD MURDERER$NEWLINE$Listen! I hear horses.

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$(within) Give us a light there, ho!$NEWLINE$within)
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$(from offstage) Hey, give us some light here!$NEWLINE$(from offstage)

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Then ’tis he: the rest$NEWLINE$That are within the note of expectation$NEWLINE$Already are i' th' court.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$That must be him. The rest of the king’s guests are already inside.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$His horses go about.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$You can hear his horses moving around as the servants take them to the stables.

paragraphs.original: THIRD MURDERER$NEWLINE$Almost a mile; but he does usually—$NEWLINE$So all men do—from hence to the palace gate$NEWLINE$Make it their walk.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD MURDERER$NEWLINE$It’s almost a mile to the palace gate, but Banquo, like everybody else, usually walks from here to the palace.

paragraphs.original: Enter BANQUO and FLEANCE with a torch$NEWLINE$BANQUO$NEWLINE$FLEANCE
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO and FLEANCE enter with a torch.$NEWLINE$BANQUO$NEWLINE$FLEANCE

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$A light, a light!
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Here comes a light! Here comes a light!

paragraphs.original: THIRD MURDERER$NEWLINE$'Tis he.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD MURDERER$NEWLINE$That’s him.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Stand to ’t.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Prepare yourselves.

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$It will be rain tonight.
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$It will rain tonight.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Let it come down.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Then let the rain come down.

paragraphs.original: The MURDERERS attack BANQUO$NEWLINE$MURDERERS$NEWLINE$BANQUO
paragraphs.translated: The MURDERERS attack BANQUO.$NEWLINE$MURDERERS$NEWLINE$BANQUO

paragraphs.original: BANQUO$NEWLINE$O treachery! Fly, good Fleance, fly, fly, fly!$NEWLINE$Thou may ’st revenge —O slave!
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO$NEWLINE$Oh, this is treachery! Get out of here, good Fleance, run, run, run! Someday you can get revenge.—Oh, you bastard!

paragraphs.original: BANQUO dies. Exit FLEANCE$NEWLINE$BANQUO$NEWLINE$FLEANCE
paragraphs.translated: BANQUO dies. FLEANCE escapes.$NEWLINE$BANQUO$NEWLINE$FLEANCE

paragraphs.original: THIRD MURDERER$NEWLINE$Who did strike out the light?
paragraphs.translated: THIRD MURDERER$NEWLINE$Who put out the light?

paragraphs.original: FIRSTMURDERER$NEWLINE$Was ’t not the way?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Wasn’t that the best thing to do?

paragraphs.original: THIRD MURDERER$NEWLINE$There’s but one down. The son is fled.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD MURDERER$NEWLINE$There’s only one body here. The son ran away.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$We have lost best half of our affair.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$We failed in half of our mission.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Well, let’s away and say how much is done.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Well, let’s get out of here and tell Macbeth what we did accomplish.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Banquet prepared. Enter MACBETH, LADY MACBETH, ROSS, LENNOX, LORDS, and attendants.$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$LENNOX$NEWLINE$LORDS
paragraphs.translated: The stage is set for a banquet. MACBETH enters with LADY MACBETH, ROSS, LENNOX, LORDS, and their attendants.$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$LENNOX$NEWLINE$LORDS

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$You know your own degrees; sit down. At first$NEWLINE$And last, the hearty welcome.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$You know your own ranks, so you know where to sit. Sit down. From the highest to the lowest of you, I bid you a hearty welcome.

paragraphs.original: The LORDS sit$NEWLINE$LORDS
paragraphs.translated: The LORDS sit down.$NEWLINE$LORDS

paragraphs.original: LORDS$NEWLINE$Thanks to your majesty.
paragraphs.translated: LORDS$NEWLINE$Thanks to your majesty.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Ourself will mingle with society$NEWLINE$And play the humble host.$NEWLINE$Our hostess keeps her state, but in best time$NEWLINE$We will require her welcome.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I will walk around and mingle with all of you, playing the humble host. My wife will stay in her royal chair, but at the appropriate time I will have her welcome you all.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Pronounce it for me, sir, to all our friends,$NEWLINE$For my heart speaks they are welcome.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Say welcome to all of our friends for me, sir, for in my heart they are all welcome.

paragraphs.original: Enter FIRST MURDERER at the door$NEWLINE$FIRST MURDERER
paragraphs.translated: The FIRST MURDERER appears at the door.$NEWLINE$FIRST MURDERER

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$See, they encounter thee with their hearts' thanks.$NEWLINE$Both sides are even. Here I’ll sit i' th' midst.$NEWLINE$Be large in mirth. Anon we’ll drink a measure$NEWLINE$The table round.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$And they respond to you with their hearts as well. The table is full on both sides. I will sit here in the middle. Be free and happy. Soon we will toast around the table.

paragraphs.original: (aside to FIRST MURDERER) There’s blood upon thy face.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: (approaching the door and speaking to the MURDERER) There’s blood on your face.$NEWLINE$(approaching the door and speaking to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$'Tis Banquo’s then.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Then it must be Banquo’s.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$'Tis better thee without than he within.$NEWLINE$Is he dispatched?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I’d rather see his blood splattered on your face than flowing through his veins. Did you finish him off?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$My lord, his throat is cut. That I did for him.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$My lord, his throat is cut. I did that to him.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Thou art the best o' th' cutthroats:$NEWLINE$Yet he’s good that did the like for Fleance.$NEWLINE$If thou didst it, thou art the nonpareil.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$You are the best of the cutthroats. But whoever did the same to Fleance must also be good. If you cut both their throats, then you are the absolute best.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Most royal sir, Fleance is ’scaped.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Most royal sir, Fleance has escaped.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Then comes my fit again. I had else been perfect,$NEWLINE$Whole as the marble, founded as the rock,$NEWLINE$As broad and general as the casing air.$NEWLINE$But now I am cabined, cribbed, confined, bound in$NEWLINE$To saucy doubts and fears.—But Banquo’s safe?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Now I’m scared again. Otherwise I would have been perfect, as solid as a piece of marble, as firm as a rock, as free as the air itself. But now I’m all tangled up with doubts and fears. But Banquo’s been taken care of?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Ay, my good lord. Safe in a ditch he bides,$NEWLINE$With twenty trenchèd gashes on his head,$NEWLINE$The least a death to nature.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Yes, my good lord. He’s lying dead in a ditch, with twenty deep gashes in his head, any one of which would have been enough to kill him.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Thanks for that.$NEWLINE$There the grown serpent lies. The worm that’s fled$NEWLINE$Hath nature that in time will venom breed;$NEWLINE$No teeth for th' present. Get thee gone. Tomorrow$NEWLINE$We’ll hear ourselves again.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Thanks for that. The adult snake lies in the ditch. The young snake that escaped will in time become poisonous and threatening, but for now he has no fangs. Get out of here. I’ll talk to you again tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: Exit FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$FIRST MURDERER
paragraphs.translated: The FIRST MURDERER exits.$NEWLINE$FIRST MURDERER

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$My royal lord,$NEWLINE$You do not give the cheer. The feast is sold$NEWLINE$That is not often vouched, while ’tis a-making,$NEWLINE$'Tis given with welcome. To feed were best at home;$NEWLINE$From thence, the sauce to meat is ceremony;$NEWLINE$Meeting were bare without it.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$My royal lord, you’re not entertaining the guests. If you don’t make your guests know they’re welcome, they’ll feel like they’re paying for their meal. When you just want to eat, it’s better to do that at home. When you’re eating out with people, you need to have a little more ceremony. Otherwise dinner parties would be boring.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Sweet remembrancer!$NEWLINE$Now, good digestion wait on appetite,$NEWLINE$And health on both!
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$It’s nice of you to remind me. (raising a glass to toast his guests) Since good digestion requires a good appetite, and good health requires both of those, here’s to good appetites, good digestion, and good health!$NEWLINE$(raising a glass to toast his guests)

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$May ’t please your highness sit.
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Why don’t you have a seat, your highness?

paragraphs.original: Enter the GHOST OF BANQUO, and sits in MACBETH’s place$NEWLINE$GHOST OF BANQUO$NEWLINE$MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: The GHOST OF BANQUO enters and sits in MACBETH’s place.$NEWLINE$GHOST OF BANQUO$NEWLINE$MACBETH

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Here had we now our country’s honor roofed,$NEWLINE$Were the graced person of our Banquo present,$NEWLINE$Who may I rather challenge for unkindness$NEWLINE$Than pity for mischance.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$We would have all the nobility of Scotland gathered under one roof, if only Banquo were here. I hope it turns out that he’s late out of rudeness, and not because something bad has happened to him.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$His absence, sir,$NEWLINE$Lays blame upon his promise. Please ’t your highness$NEWLINE$To grace us with your royal company?
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$His absence means he’s broken his promise, sir. If it pleases you, your highness, why don’t you sit with us and grace us with your royal company?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$The table’s full.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$The table’s full.

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Here is a place reserved, sir.
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Here’s an empty seat, sir.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Where?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Where?

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Here, my good lord. What is ’t that moves your highness?
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$(pointing to where the GHOST sits) Here, my good lord. What’s wrong, your highness?$NEWLINE$(pointing to where the$NEWLINE$sits)

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Which of you have done this?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(seeing the GHOST) Which one of you did this?$NEWLINE$(seeing the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LORDS$NEWLINE$What, my good lord?
paragraphs.translated: LORDS$NEWLINE$What, my good lord?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(to GHOST) Thou canst not say I did it. Never shake$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Thy gory locks at me.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(to the GHOST) You can’t say I did it. Don’t shake your bloody head at me.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Gentlemen, rise. His highness is not well.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$Gentlemen, stand up. His highness is not well.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Sit, worthy friends. My lord is often thus$NEWLINE$And hath been from his youth. Pray you, keep seat.$NEWLINE$The fit is momentary; upon a thought$NEWLINE$He will again be well. If much you note him,$NEWLINE$You shall offend him and extend his passion.$NEWLINE$Feed and regard him not. (aside to MACBETH) Are you a man?$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Sit down, worthy friends. My husband is often like this, and he has been since he was a child. Please stay seated. This is just a brief fit. In a moment he’ll be well again. If you pay too much attention to him you’ll make him angry, and that will make his convulsions go on longer. Eat your dinner and pay no attention to him. (speaking so that only MACBETH can hear) Are you a man?$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Ay, and a bold one, that dare look on that$NEWLINE$Which might appall the devil.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Yes, and a brave one, who dares to look at something that would frighten the devil.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$O proper stuff!$NEWLINE$This is the very painting of your fear.$NEWLINE$This is the air-drawn dagger which you said$NEWLINE$Led you to Duncan. Oh, these flaws and starts,$NEWLINE$Impostors to true fear, would well become$NEWLINE$A woman’s story at a winter’s fire,$NEWLINE$Authorized by her grandam. Shame itself!$NEWLINE$Why do you make such faces? When all’s done,$NEWLINE$You look but on a stool.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Oh, that’s nonsense! This is just another one of the hallucinations you always get when you’re afraid. This is like that floating dagger you said was leading you toward Duncan. These outbursts of yours don’t even look like real fear. They’re more like how you would act if you were a woman telling a scary story by the fireside in front of her grandmother. Shame on you! Why are you making these faces? When the vision passes, you’ll see that you’re just looking at a stool.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Prithee, see there! Behold! Look! Lo! How say you?$NEWLINE$Why, what care I? If thou canst nod, speak too.$NEWLINE$If charnel houses and our graves must send$NEWLINE$Those that we bury back, our monuments$NEWLINE$Shall be the maws of kites.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Please, just look over there. Look! Look! See! (to the GHOST) What do you have to say? What do I care? If you can nod, then speak too. If the dead are going to return from their graves, then there’s nothing to stop the birds from eating the bodies. So there’s no point in our burying people.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit GHOST$NEWLINE$GHOST
paragraphs.translated: The GHOST vanishes.$NEWLINE$GHOST

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$What, quite unmanned in folly?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$What, has your foolishness paralyzed you completely?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$If I stand here, I saw him.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$As sure as I’m standing here, I saw him.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Fie, for shame!
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Nonsense!

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Blood hath been shed ere now, i' th' olden time,$NEWLINE$Ere humane statute purged the gentle weal;$NEWLINE$Ay, and since too, murders have been performed$NEWLINE$Too terrible for the ear. The time has been$NEWLINE$That, when the brains were out, the man would die,$NEWLINE$And there an end. But now they rise again$NEWLINE$With twenty mortal murders on their crowns$NEWLINE$And push us from our stools. This is more strange$NEWLINE$Than such a murder is.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$In ancient times, before there were laws to make the land safe and peaceful, a lot of blood was spilled. Yes, and since then murders have been committed that are too awful to talk about. It used to be that when you knocked a man’s brains out he would just die, and that would be it. But now they rise from the dead with twenty fatal head wounds and push us off our stools. This haunting business is even stranger than murder.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$My worthy lord,$NEWLINE$Your noble friends do lack you.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$My worthy lord, your noble friends miss your company.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I do forget.$NEWLINE$Do not muse at me, my most worthy friends.$NEWLINE$I have a strange infirmity, which is nothing$NEWLINE$To those that know me. Come, love and health to all.$NEWLINE$Then I’ll sit down. Give me some wine. Fill full.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I forgot about them. (to the guests) Don’t be alarmed on my account, my most worthy friends. I have a strange disorder, which no longer shocks those who know me well. (raising his glass to toast the company) Come, let’s drink a toast: love and health to you all. Now I’ll sit down. Give me some wine. Fill up my cup.$NEWLINE$(to the guests)$NEWLINE$(raising his glass to toast the company)

paragraphs.original: Enter the GHOST OF BANQUO$NEWLINE$GHOST OF BANQUO
paragraphs.translated: The GHOST OF BANQUO reappears in MACBETH’s seat.$NEWLINE$GHOST OF BANQUO$NEWLINE$MACBETH

paragraphs.original: I drink to the general joy o' th' whole table,$NEWLINE$And to our dear friend Banquo, whom we miss;$NEWLINE$Would he were here! To all and him we thirst,$NEWLINE$And all to all.
paragraphs.translated: I drink to the happiness of everyone at the table, and to our dear friend Banquo, whom we miss. I wish he were here! Let’s drink to everyone here, and to Banquo. Now, everybody, drink

paragraphs.original: LORDS$NEWLINE$Our duties, and the pledge.
paragraphs.translated: LORDS$NEWLINE$Hear, hear.

paragraphs.original: They drink
paragraphs.translated: They drink.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(seeing the GHOST) Avaunt, and quit my sight! Let the earth hide thee.$NEWLINE$(seeing the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Thy bones are marrowless, thy blood is cold.$NEWLINE$Thou hast no speculation in those eyes$NEWLINE$Which thou dost glare with!
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(to the GHOST) Go! And get out of my sight! Stay in your grave. There’s no marrow in your bones, and your blood is cold. You’re staring at me with eyes that have no power to see.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Think of this, good peers,$NEWLINE$But as a thing of custom. 'Tis no other;$NEWLINE$Only it spoils the pleasure of the time.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Good friends, think of this as nothing more than a strange habit. It’s nothing else. Too bad it’s spoiling our pleasure tonight.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$What man dare, I dare.$NEWLINE$Approach thou like the rugged Russian bear,$NEWLINE$The armed rhinoceros, or th' Hyrcan tiger;$NEWLINE$Take any shape but that, and my firm nerves$NEWLINE$Shall never tremble. Or be alive again,$NEWLINE$And dare me to the desert with thy sword.$NEWLINE$If trembling I inhabit then, protest me$NEWLINE$The baby of a girl. Hence, horrible shadow!$NEWLINE$Unreal mockery, hence!
