paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I am as brave as any other man. Come at me in the form of a rugged Russian bear, an armor-plated rhinoceros, or a tiger from Iran. Take any shape other than the one you have now and I will never tremble in fear. Or come back to life again and challenge me to a duel in some deserted place. If I tremble then, you can call me a little girl. Get out of here, you horrible ghost, you hallucination. Get out!

paragraphs.original: Exit GHOST$NEWLINE$GHOST
paragraphs.translated: The GHOST vanishes.$NEWLINE$GHOST

paragraphs.original: Why so, being gone,
paragraphs.translated: I am a man again. Pray you sit still.

paragraphs.original: Why so, being gone,$NEWLINE$I am a man again. Pray you sit still.
paragraphs.translated: Look, now that it’s gone, I’m a man again. Please, remain seated.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$You have displaced the mirth, broke the good meeting,$NEWLINE$With most admired disorder.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$You have ruined our good cheer and disrupted the gathering by making a spectacle of yourself.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Can such things be,$NEWLINE$And overcome us like a summer’s cloud,$NEWLINE$Without our special wonder? You make me strange$NEWLINE$Even to the disposition that I owe,$NEWLINE$When now I think you can behold such sights,$NEWLINE$And keep the natural ruby of your cheeks,$NEWLINE$When mine is blanched with fear.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(to the guests) Can things like this happen so suddenly without making us all astonished? You make me feel like I don’t know myself, when I see you looking at these terrible things and keeping a straight face, while my face has gone white with fear.$NEWLINE$(to the guests)

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$What sights, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$What things, my lord?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$I pray you, speak not. He grows worse and worse.$NEWLINE$Question enrages him. At once, good night.$NEWLINE$Stand not upon the order of your going,$NEWLINE$But go at once.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Please, don’t speak to him. He’s getting worse and worse. Talk makes him crazy. Everybody, please leave right now. Don’t bother exiting in the order of your rank, but just leave right away.

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Good night, and better health$NEWLINE$Attend his majesty!
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Good night. I hope the king recovers soon!

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$A kind good night to all!
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$A kind good night to all!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but MACBETH and LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: Everyone leaves except MACBETH and LADY MACBETH.$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$It will have blood, they say. Blood will have blood.$NEWLINE$Stones have been known to move, and trees to speak.$NEWLINE$Augurs and understood relations have$NEWLINE$By magot pies and choughs and rooks brought forth$NEWLINE$The secret’st man of blood.—What is the night?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$There’s an old saying: the dead will have their revenge. Gravestones have been known to move, and trees to speak, to bring guilty men to justice. The craftiest murderers have been exposed by the mystical signs made by crows and magpies. How late at night is it?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Almost at odds with morning, which is which.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$It’s almost morning. You can’t tell whether it’s day or night.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$How say’st thou that Macduff denies his person$NEWLINE$At our great bidding?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$What do you think about the fact that Macduff refuses to come to me when I command him?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Did you send to him, sir?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Did you send for him, sir?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I hear it by the way; but I will send.$NEWLINE$There’s not a one of them but in his house$NEWLINE$I keep a servant fee’d. I will tomorrow—$NEWLINE$And betimes I will—to the weird sisters.$NEWLINE$More shall they speak, for now I am bent to know,$NEWLINE$By the worst means, the worst. For mine own good,$NEWLINE$All causes shall give way. I am in blood$NEWLINE$Stepped in so far that, should I wade no more,$NEWLINE$Returning were as tedious as go o'er.$NEWLINE$Strange things I have in head, that will to hand,$NEWLINE$Which must be acted ere they may be scanned.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I’ve heard about this indirectly, but I will send for him. In every one of the lords' households I have a servant paid to spy for me. Tomorrow, while it’s still early, I will go see the witches. They will tell me more, because I’m determined to know the worst about what’s going to happen. My own safety is the only important thing now. I have walked so far into this river of blood that even if I stopped now, it would be as hard to go back to being good as it is to keep killing people. I have some schemes in my head that I’m planning to put into action. I have to do these things before I have a chance to think about them.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$You lack the season of all natures, sleep.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$You haven’t slept.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Come, we’ll to sleep. My strange and self-abuse$NEWLINE$Is the initiate fear that wants hard use.$NEWLINE$We are yet but young in deed.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Yes, let’s go to sleep. My strange self-delusions just come from inexperience. We’re still just beginners when it comes to crime.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Thunder. Enter the three WITCHES meeting HECATE$NEWLINE$WITCHES$NEWLINE$HECATE
paragraphs.translated: Thunder. The three WITCHES enter, meeting HECATE.$NEWLINE$WITCHES$NEWLINE$HECATE

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Why, how now, Hecate! You look angerly.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$What’s wrong, Hecate? You look angry.

paragraphs.original: HECATE$NEWLINE$Have I not reason, beldams as you are?$NEWLINE$Saucy and overbold, how did you dare$NEWLINE$To trade and traffic with Macbeth$NEWLINE$In riddles and affairs of death,$NEWLINE$And I, the mistress of your charms,$NEWLINE$The close contriver of all harms,$NEWLINE$Was never called to bear my part,$NEWLINE$Or show the glory of our art?$NEWLINE$And, which is worse, all you have done$NEWLINE$Hath been but for a wayward son,$NEWLINE$Spiteful and wrathful, who, as others do,$NEWLINE$Loves for his own ends, not for you.$NEWLINE$But make amends now. Get you gone,$NEWLINE$And at the pit of Acheron$NEWLINE$Meet me i' th' morning. Thither he$NEWLINE$Will come to know his destiny.$NEWLINE$Your vessels and your spells provide,$NEWLINE$Your charms and everything beside.$NEWLINE$I am for the air. This night I’ll spend$NEWLINE$Unto a dismal and a fatal end.$NEWLINE$Great business must be wrought ere noon.$NEWLINE$Upon the corner of the moon$NEWLINE$There hangs a vap'rous drop profound.$NEWLINE$I’ll catch it ere it come to ground.$NEWLINE$And that distilled by magic sleights$NEWLINE$Shall raise such artificial sprites$NEWLINE$As by the strength of their illusion$NEWLINE$Shall draw him on to his confusion.
paragraphs.translated: HECATE$NEWLINE$Don’t I have a reason to be angry, you disobedient hags? How dare you give Macbeth riddles and prophecies about his future without telling me? I am your boss and the source of your powers. I am the one who secretly decides what evil things happen, but you never called me to join in and show off my own powers. And what’s worse, you’ve done all this for a man who behaves like a spoiled brat, angry and hateful. Like all spoiled sons, he chases after what he wants and doesn’t care about you. But you can make it up to me. Go away now and in the morning meet me in the pit by the river in hell. Macbeth will go there to learn his destiny. You bring your cauldrons, your spells, your charms, and everything else. I’m about to fly away. I’ll spend tonight working to make something horrible happen. I have a lot to do before noon. An important droplet is hanging from the corner of the moon. I’ll catch it before it falls to the ground. When I work it over with magic spells, the drop will produce magical spirits that will trick Macbeth with illusions.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: He shall spurn fate, scorn death, and bear$NEWLINE$His hopes 'bove wisdom, grace, and fear.$NEWLINE$And you all know, security$NEWLINE$Is mortals' chiefest enemy.
paragraphs.translated: He will be fooled into thinking he is greater than fate, he will mock death, and he will think he is above wisdom, grace, and fear. As you all know, overconfidence is man’s greatest enemy.

paragraphs.original: Music and a song within: 'Come away, come away,' &c
paragraphs.translated: Music plays offstage, and voices sing a song with the words “Come away, come away.”

paragraphs.original: Hark! I am called. My little spirit, see,$NEWLINE$Sits in a foggy cloud and stays for me.
paragraphs.translated: Listen! I’m being called. Look, my little spirit is sitting in a foggy cloud waiting for me.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: HECATE exits.$NEWLINE$HECATE

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Come, let’s make haste; she’ll soon be back again.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Come on, let’s hurry. She’ll be back again soon.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LENNOX and another LORD$NEWLINE$LENNOX$NEWLINE$LORD
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX and another LORD enter.$NEWLINE$LENNOX$NEWLINE$LORD

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$My former speeches have but hit your thoughts,$NEWLINE$Which can interpret farther. Only I say$NEWLINE$Things have been strangely borne. The gracious Duncan$NEWLINE$Was pitied of Macbeth. Marry, he was dead.$NEWLINE$And the right-valiant Banquo walked too late,$NEWLINE$Whom, you may say, if ’t please you, Fleance killed,$NEWLINE$For Fleance fled. Men must not walk too late.$NEWLINE$Who cannot want the thought how monstrous$NEWLINE$It was for Malcolm and for Donalbain$NEWLINE$To kill their gracious father? Damnèd fact!$NEWLINE$How it did grieve Macbeth! Did he not straight$NEWLINE$In pious rage the two delinquents tear$NEWLINE$That were the slaves of drink and thralls of sleep?$NEWLINE$Was not that nobly done? Ay, and wisely too,$NEWLINE$For ’twould have angered any heart alive$NEWLINE$To hear the men deny ’t. So that, I say,$NEWLINE$He has borne all things well. And I do think$NEWLINE$That had he Duncan’s sons under his key—$NEWLINE$As, an’t please heaven, he shall not—they should find$NEWLINE$What ’twere to kill a father. So should Fleance.$NEWLINE$But, peace! For from broad words, and 'cause he failed$NEWLINE$His presence at the tyrant’s feast, I hear$NEWLINE$Macduff lives in disgrace. Sir, can you tell$NEWLINE$Where he bestows himself?
paragraphs.translated:
LENNOX$NEWLINE$What I’ve already said shows you we think alike, so you can draw your own conclusions. All I’m saying is that strange things have been going on. Macbeth pitied Duncan—after Duncan was dead. And Banquo went out walking too late at night. If you like, we can say that Fleance must have killed him, because Fleance fled the scene of the crime. Clearly, men should not go out walking too late! And who can help thinking how monstrous it was for Malcolm and Donalbain to kill their gracious father? Such a heinous crime—how it saddened
Macbeth! Wasn’t it loyal of him to kill those two servants right away, while they were still drunk and asleep? That was the right thing to do, wasn’t it? Yes, and it was the wise thing, too, because we all would have been outraged to hear those two deny their crime. Considering all this, I think Macbeth has handled things well. If he had Duncan’s sons in prison—which I hope won’t happen—they would find out how awful the punishment is for those who kill their fathers, and so would Fleance. But enough of that. I hear that Macduff is out of favor with the king because he speaks his mind too plainly, and because he failed to show up at Macbeth’s feast. Can you tell me where he’s hiding himself?$NEWLINE$Macbeth$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LORD$NEWLINE$The son of Duncan—$NEWLINE$From whom this tyrant holds the due of birth—$NEWLINE$Lives in the English court and is received$NEWLINE$Of the most pious Edward with such grace$NEWLINE$That the malevolence of fortune nothing$NEWLINE$Takes from his high respect. Thither Macduff$NEWLINE$Is gone to pray the holy king upon his aid$NEWLINE$To wake Northumberland and warlike Siward,$NEWLINE$That by the help of these—with Him above$NEWLINE$To ratify the work—we may again$NEWLINE$Give to our tables meat, sleep to our nights,$NEWLINE$Free from our feasts and banquets bloody knives,$NEWLINE$Do faithful homage and receive free honors.$NEWLINE$All which we pine for now. And this report$NEWLINE$Hath so exasperated the king that he$NEWLINE$Prepares for some attempt of war.
paragraphs.translated: LORD$NEWLINE$Duncan’s son Malcolm, whose birthright and throne Macbeth has stolen, lives in the English court. There, the saintly King Edward treats Malcolm so well that despite Malcolm’s misfortunes, he’s not deprived of respect. Macduff went there to ask King Edward for help. He wants Edward to help him form an alliance with the people of Northumberland and their lord, Siward. Macduff hopes that with their help—and with the help of God above—he may once again put food on our tables, bring peace back to our nights, free our feasts and banquets from violent murders, allow us to pay proper homage to our king, and receive honors freely. Those are the things we pine for now. Macbeth has heard this news and he is so angry that he’s preparing for war.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Sent he to Macduff?
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Did he tell Macduff to return to Scotland?

paragraphs.original: LORD$NEWLINE$He did, and with an absolute “Sir, not I,”$NEWLINE$The cloudy messenger turns me his back,$NEWLINE$And hums, as who should say “You’ll rue the time$NEWLINE$That clogs me with this answer.”
paragraphs.translated: LORD$NEWLINE$He did, but Macduff told the messenger, “No way.” The messenger scowled and rudely turned his back on Macduff, as if to say, “You’ll regret the day you gave me this answer.”

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$And that well might$NEWLINE$Advise him to a caution, t' hold what distance$NEWLINE$His wisdom can provide. Some holy angel$NEWLINE$Fly to the court of England and unfold$NEWLINE$His message ere he come, that a swift blessing$NEWLINE$May soon return to this our suffering country$NEWLINE$Under a hand accursed!
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$That might well keep Macduff away from Scotland. Some holy angel should go to the court of England and give Macduff a message. He should return quickly to free our country, which is suffering under a tyrant!

paragraphs.original: LORD$NEWLINE$I’ll send my prayers with him.
paragraphs.translated: LORD$NEWLINE$I’ll send my prayers with him.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: A cavern. In the middle, a boiling cauldron. Thunder. Enter the three WITCHES.$NEWLINE$WITCHES
paragraphs.translated: A cavern. In the middle, a boiling cauldron. Thunder. The three WITCHES enter.$NEWLINE$WITCHES

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Thrice the brinded cat hath mewed.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$The tawny cat has meowed three times.

paragraphs.original: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Thrice, and once the hedge-pig whined.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Three times. And the hedgehog has whined once.

paragraphs.original: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$Harpier cries, “'Tis time, ’tis time.”
paragraphs.translated: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$My spirit friend, Harpier, is yelling, “It’s time, it’s time!”

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Round about the cauldron go,$NEWLINE$In the poisoned entrails throw.$NEWLINE$Toad, that under cold stone$NEWLINE$Days and nights has thirty-one$NEWLINE$Sweltered venom sleeping got,$NEWLINE$Boil thou first i' th' charmèd pot.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Dance around the cauldron and throw in the poisoned entrails. (holding up a toad) You’ll go in first—a toad that sat under a cold rock for a month, oozing poison from its pores.$NEWLINE$(holding up a toad)

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Double, double toil and trouble,$NEWLINE$Fire burn, and cauldron bubble.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Double, double toil and trouble,$NEWLINE$Fire burn, and cauldron bubble.

paragraphs.original: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Fillet of a fenny snake,$NEWLINE$In the cauldron boil and bake.$NEWLINE$Eye of newt and toe of frog,$NEWLINE$Wool of bat and tongue of dog,$NEWLINE$Adder’s fork and blind-worm’s sting,$NEWLINE$Lizard’s leg and owlet’s wing,$NEWLINE$For a charm of powerful trouble,$NEWLINE$Like a hell-broth boil and bubble.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$(holding something up) We’ll boil you in the cauldron next—a slice of swamp snake. All the rest of you in too: a newt’s eye, a frog’s tongue, fur from a bat, a dog’s tongue, the forked tongue of an adder, the stinger of a burrowing worm, a lizard’s leg, an owl’s wing. (speaking to the ingredients) Make a charm to cause powerful trouble, and boil and bubble like a broth of hell.$NEWLINE$(holding something up)$NEWLINE$(speaking to the ingredients)

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Double, double toil and trouble,$NEWLINE$Fire burn and cauldron bubble.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Double, double toil and trouble,$NEWLINE$Fire burn and cauldron bubble.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$Scale of dragon, tooth of wolf,$NEWLINE$Witches' mummy, maw and gulf$NEWLINE$Of the ravined salt-sea shark,$NEWLINE$Root of hemlock digged i' th' dark,$NEWLINE$Liver of blaspheming Jew,$NEWLINE$Gall of goat and slips of yew$NEWLINE$Slivered in the moon’s eclipse,$NEWLINE$Nose of Turk and Tartar’s lips,$NEWLINE$Finger of birth-strangled babe$NEWLINE$Ditch-delivered by a drab,$NEWLINE$Make the gruel thick and slab.$NEWLINE$Add thereto a tiger’s chaudron,$NEWLINE$For the ingredients of our cauldron.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$Here come some more ingredients: the scale of a dragon, a wolf’s tooth, a witch’s mummified flesh, the gullet and stomach of a ravenous shark, a root of hemlock that was dug up in the dark, a Jew’s liver, a goat’s bile, some twigs of yew that were broken off during a lunar eclipse, a Turk’s nose, a Tartar’s lips, the finger of a baby that was strangled as a prostitute gave birth to it in a ditch. (to the ingredients) Make this potion thick and gluey. (to the other WITCHES) Now let’s add a tiger’s entrails to the mix.$NEWLINE$(to the ingredients)$NEWLINE$(to the other$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Double, double toil and trouble,$NEWLINE$Fire burn and cauldron bubble.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Double, double toil and trouble,$NEWLINE$Fire burn and cauldron bubble.

paragraphs.original: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Cool it with a baboon’s blood,$NEWLINE$Then the charm is firm and good.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$We’ll cool the mixture with baboon blood. After that the charm is finished.

paragraphs.original: Enter HECATE and the other three WITCHES$NEWLINE$HECATE$NEWLINE$WITCHES
paragraphs.translated: HECATE enters with three other WITCHES.$NEWLINE$HECATE$NEWLINE$WITCHES

paragraphs.original: HECATE$NEWLINE$Oh well done! I commend your pains,$NEWLINE$And every one shall share i' th' gains.$NEWLINE$And now about the cauldron sing,$NEWLINE$Like elves and fairies in a ring,$NEWLINE$Enchanting all that you put in.
paragraphs.translated: HECATE$NEWLINE$Well done! I admire your efforts, and all of you will share the rewards. Now come sing around the cauldron like a ring of elves and fairies, enchanting everything you put in.

paragraphs.original: Music and a song: “Black spirits,” &c. HECATE retires$NEWLINE$HECATE
paragraphs.translated: Music plays and the six WITCHES sing a song called “Black Spirits.” HECATE leaves.$NEWLINE$WITCHES$NEWLINE$HECATE

paragraphs.original: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$By the pricking of my thumbs,$NEWLINE$Something wicked this way comes.$NEWLINE$Open, locks,$NEWLINE$Whoever knocks.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$I can tell that something wicked is coming by the tingling in my thumbs. Doors, open up for whoever is knocking!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter MACBETH$NEWLINE$MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH enters.$NEWLINE$MACBETH

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$How now, you secret, black, and midnight hags?$NEWLINE$What is ’t you do?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$What’s going on here, you secret, evil, midnight hags? What are you doing?

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$A deed without a name.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Something there isn’t a word for.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I conjure you by that which you profess—$NEWLINE$Howe'er you come to know it—answer me.$NEWLINE$Though you untie the winds and let them fight$NEWLINE$Against the churches, though the yeasty waves$NEWLINE$Confound and swallow navigation up,$NEWLINE$Though bladed corn be lodged and trees blown down,$NEWLINE$Though castles topple on their warders' heads,$NEWLINE$Though palaces and pyramids do slope$NEWLINE$Their heads to their foundations, though the treasure$NEWLINE$Of nature’s germens tumble all together,$NEWLINE$Even till destruction sicken, answer me$NEWLINE$To what I ask you.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I don’t know how you know the things you do, but I insist that you answer my questions. I command you in the name of whatever dark powers you serve. I don’t care if you unleash violent winds that tear down churches, make the foamy waves overwhelm ships and send sailors to their deaths, flatten crops and trees, make castles fall down on their inhabitants' heads, make palaces and pyramids collapse, and mix up everything in nature. Tell me what I want to know.

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Speak.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Speak.

paragraphs.original: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Demand.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Demand.

paragraphs.original: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$We’ll answer.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$We’ll answer.

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Say, if th' hadst rather hear it from our mouths,$NEWLINE$Or from our masters'.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Would you rather hear these things from our mouths or from our master’s?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Call 'em. Let me see 'em.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Call them. Let me see them.

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Pour in sow’s blood, that hath eaten$NEWLINE$Her nine farrow; grease that’s sweaten$NEWLINE$From the murderer’s gibbet throw$NEWLINE$Into the flame.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Pour in the blood of a sow who has eaten her nine offspring. Take the sweat of a murderer on the gallows and throw it into the flame.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Come, high or low;$NEWLINE$Thyself and office deftly show!
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Come, high or low spirits. Show yourself and what you do.

paragraphs.original: Thunder. FIRST APPARITION : an armed head$NEWLINE$FIRST APPARITION
paragraphs.translated: Thunder. The FIRST APPARITION appears, looking like a head with an armored helmet.$NEWLINE$FIRST APPARITION

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Tell me, thou unknown power—
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Tell me, you unknown power—

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$He knows thy thought.$NEWLINE$Hear his speech but say thou nought.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$He can read your thoughts. Listen, but don’t speak.

paragraphs.original: FIRST APPARITION$NEWLINE$Macbeth! Macbeth! Macbeth! Beware Macduff.$NEWLINE$Beware the thane of Fife. Dismiss me. Enough.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST APPARITION$NEWLINE$Macbeth! Macbeth! Macbeth! Beware Macduff. Beware the thane of Fife. Let me go. Enough.

paragraphs.original: Descends
paragraphs.translated: The FIRST APPARITION descends.$NEWLINE$FIRST APPARITION

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Whate'er thou art, for thy good caution, thanks.$NEWLINE$Thou hast harped my fear aright. But one word more—
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Whatever you are, thanks for your advice. You have guessed exactly what I feared. But one word more—

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$He will not be commanded. Here’s another$NEWLINE$More potent than the first.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$He will not be commanded by you. Here’s another, stronger than the first.

paragraphs.original: Thunder. SECOND APPARITION : a bloody child$NEWLINE$SECOND APPARITION
paragraphs.translated: Thunder. The SECOND APPARITION appears, looking like a bloody child.$NEWLINE$SECOND APPARITION

paragraphs.original: SECOND APPARITION$NEWLINE$Macbeth! Macbeth! Macbeth!—
paragraphs.translated: SECOND APPARITION$NEWLINE$Macbeth! Macbeth! Macbeth!

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Had I three ears, I’d hear thee.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$If I had three ears I’d listen with all three.

paragraphs.original: SECOND APPARITION$NEWLINE$Be bloody, bold, and resolute. Laugh to scorn$NEWLINE$The power of man, for none of woman born$NEWLINE$Shall harm Macbeth.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND APPARITION$NEWLINE$Be violent, bold, and firm. Laugh at the power of other men, because nobody born from a woman will ever harm Macbeth.

paragraphs.original: Descends$NEWLINE$Descends
paragraphs.translated: The SECOND APPARITION descends.$NEWLINE$The$NEWLINE$descends

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Then live, Macduff. What need I fear of thee?$NEWLINE$But yet I’ll make assurance double sure,$NEWLINE$And take a bond of fate. Thou shalt not live,$NEWLINE$That I may tell pale-hearted fear it lies,$NEWLINE$And sleep in spite of thunder.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Then I don’t need to kill Macduff. I have no reason to fear him. But even so, I’ll make doubly sure. I’ll guarantee my own fate by having you killed, Macduff. That way I can conquer my own fear and sleep easy at night.

paragraphs.original: Thunder. THIRD APPARITION : a child crowned, with a tree in his hand$NEWLINE$THIRD APPARITION
paragraphs.translated: Thunder. The THIRD APPARITION appears, in the form of a child with a crown on his head and a tree in his hand.$NEWLINE$THIRD APPARITION

paragraphs.original: What is this$NEWLINE$That rises like the issue of a king,$NEWLINE$And wears upon his baby-brow the round$NEWLINE$And top of sovereignty?
paragraphs.translated: What is this spirit that looks like the son of a king and wears a crown on his young head?

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Listen but speak not to ’t.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Listen but don’t speak to it.

paragraphs.original: THIRD APPARITION$NEWLINE$Be lion-mettled, proud, and take no care$NEWLINE$Who chafes, who frets, or where conspirers are.$NEWLINE$Macbeth shall never vanquished be until$NEWLINE$Great Birnam Wood to high Dunsinane Hill$NEWLINE$Shall come against him.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD APPARITION$NEWLINE$Be brave like the lion and proud. Don’t even worry about who hates you, who resents you, and who conspires against you. Macbeth will never be defeated until Birnam Wood marches to fight you at Dunsinane Hill.

paragraphs.original: Descends
paragraphs.translated: The THIRD APPARITION descends.$NEWLINE$THIRD APPARITION

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$That will never be.$NEWLINE$Who can impress the forest, bid the tree$NEWLINE$Unfix his earthbound root? Sweet bodements! Good!$NEWLINE$Rebellious dead, rise never till the wood$NEWLINE$Of Birnam rise, and our high-placed Macbeth$NEWLINE$Shall live the lease of nature, pay his breath$NEWLINE$To time and mortal custom. Yet my heart$NEWLINE$Throbs to know one thing. Tell me, if your art$NEWLINE$Can tell so much: shall Banquo’s issue ever$NEWLINE$Reign in this kingdom?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$That will never happen. Who can command the forest and make the trees pull their roots out of the earth? These were sweet omens! Good! My murders will never come back to threaten me until the forest of Birnam gets up and moves, and I will be king for my entire natural life. But my heart is still throbbing to know one thing. Tell me, if your dark powers can see this far: will Banquo’s sons ever reign in this kingdom?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Seek to know no more.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Don’t try to find out more.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I will be satisfied. Deny me this,$NEWLINE$And an eternal curse fall on you! Let me know.$NEWLINE$Why sinks that cauldron? And what noise is this?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I demand to be satisfied. If you refuse, let an eternal curse fall on you. Let me know. Why is that cauldron sinking? And what is that music?

paragraphs.original: Hautboys
paragraphs.translated: Hautboys play music for a ceremonial procession.

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Show.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Show.

paragraphs.original: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Show.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WITCH$NEWLINE$Show.

paragraphs.original: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$Show.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD WITCH$NEWLINE$Show.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Show his eyes and grieve his heart.$NEWLINE$Come like shadows; so depart!
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Show him and make him grieve. Come like shadows and depart in the same way!

paragraphs.original: A show of eight kings, the last with a glass in his hand, followed by BANQUO$NEWLINE$BANQUO
paragraphs.translated: Eight kings march across the stage, the last one with a mirror in his hand, followed by the GHOST OF BANQUO.$NEWLINE$GHOST OF BANQUO

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Thou art too like the spirit of Banquo. Down!$NEWLINE$Thy crown does sear mine eyeballs. And thy hair,$NEWLINE$Thou other gold-bound brow, is like the first.$NEWLINE$A third is like the former.—Filthy hags!$NEWLINE$Why do you show me this? A fourth? Start, eyes!$NEWLINE$What, will the line stretch out to th' crack of doom?$NEWLINE$Another yet? A seventh? I’ll see no more.$NEWLINE$And yet the eighth appears, who bears a glass$NEWLINE$Which shows me many more, and some I see$NEWLINE$That twofold balls and treble scepters carry.$NEWLINE$Horrible sight! Now I see ’tis true;$NEWLINE$For the blood-boltered Banquo smiles upon me$NEWLINE$And points at them for his.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$You look too much like the ghost of Banquo. Go away!     (to the first) Your crown hurts my eyes. (to the second) Your blond hair, which looks like another crown underneath the one you’re wearing, looks just like the first king’s hair. Now I see a third king who looks just like the second. Filthy hags! Why are you showing me this? A fourth! My eyes are bulging out of their sockets! Will this line stretch on forever? Another one! And a seventh! I don’t want to see any more. And yet an eighth appears, holding a mirror in which I see many more men. And some are carrying double balls and triple scepters, meaning they’re kings of more than one country! Horrible sight! Now I see it is true, they are Banquo’s descendants. Banquo, with his blood-clotted hair, is smiling at me and pointing to them as his.$NEWLINE$(to the first)$NEWLINE$(to the second)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Apparitions vanish
paragraphs.translated: The spirits of the kings and the GHOST OF BANQUO vanish.$NEWLINE$GHOST OF BANQUO

paragraphs.original: What, is this so?
paragraphs.translated: What? Is this true?

paragraphs.original: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Ay, sir, all this is so. But why$NEWLINE$Stands Macbeth thus amazedly?$NEWLINE$Come, sisters, cheer we up his sprites,$NEWLINE$And show the best of our delights.$NEWLINE$I’ll charm th' air to give a sound,$NEWLINE$While you perform your antic round.$NEWLINE$That this great king may kindly say,$NEWLINE$Our duties did his welcome pay.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WITCH$NEWLINE$Yes, this is true, but why do you stand there so dumbfounded? Come, sisters, let’s cheer him up and show him our talents. I will charm the air to produce music while you all dance around like crazy, so this king will say we did our duty and entertained him.

paragraphs.original: Music. The WITCHES dance and then vanish$NEWLINE$WITCHES
paragraphs.translated: Music plays. The WITCHES dance and then vanish.$NEWLINE$WITCHES

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Where are they? Gone? Let this pernicious hour$NEWLINE$Stand aye accursèd in the calendar!$NEWLINE$Come in, without there.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Where are they? Gone? Let this evil hour be marked forever in the calendar as cursed. (calls to someone offstage) You outside, come in!$NEWLINE$(calls to someone offstage)

paragraphs.original: Enter LENNOX$NEWLINE$LENNOX
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX enters.$NEWLINE$LENNOX

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$What’s your grace’s will?
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$What does your grace want?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Saw you the weird sisters?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Did you see the weird sisters?

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$No, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$No, my lord.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Came they not by you?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Didn’t they pass by you?

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$No, indeed, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$No, indeed, my lord.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Infected be the air whereon they ride,$NEWLINE$And damned all those that trust them! I did hear$NEWLINE$The galloping of horse. Who was ’t came by?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$The air on which they ride is infected. Damn all those who trust them! I heard the galloping of horses. Who was it that came here?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$'Tis two or three, my lord, that bring you word$NEWLINE$Macduff is fled to England.
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Two or three men, my lord, who brought the message that Macduff has fled to England.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Fled to England?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Fled to England?

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Ay, my good lord.
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Yes, my good lord.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Time, thou anticipat’st my dread exploits.$NEWLINE$The flighty purpose never is o'ertook$NEWLINE$Unless the deed go with it. From this moment$NEWLINE$The very firstlings of my heart shall be$NEWLINE$The firstlings of my hand. And even now,$NEWLINE$To crown my thoughts with acts, be it thought and done:$NEWLINE$The castle of Macduff I will surprise,$NEWLINE$Seize upon Fife, give to th' edge o' th' sword$NEWLINE$His wife, his babes, and all unfortunate souls$NEWLINE$That trace him in his line. No boasting like a fool.$NEWLINE$This deed I’ll do before this purpose cool.$NEWLINE$But no more sights!—Where are these gentlemen?$NEWLINE$Come, bring me where they are.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Time, you thwart my dreadful plans. Unless a person does something the second he thinks of it, he’ll never get a chance to do it. From now on, as soon as I decide to do something I’m going to act immediately. In fact, I’ll start following up my thoughts with actions right now. I’ll raid Macduff’s castle, seize the town of Fife, and kill his wife, his children, and anyone else unfortunate enough to stand in line for his inheritance. No more foolish talk. I will do this deed before I lose my sense of purpose. But no more spooky visions!—Where are the messengers? Come, bring me to them.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LADY MACDUFF, her SON, and ROSS$NEWLINE$LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$SON$NEWLINE$ROSS
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF, her SON, and ROSS enter.$NEWLINE$LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$SON$NEWLINE$ROSS

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$What had he done to make him fly the land?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$What did he do that made him flee this land?

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$You must have patience, madam.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$You have to be patient, madam.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$He had none.$NEWLINE$His flight was madness. When our actions do not,$NEWLINE$Our fears do make us traitors.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$He had no patience. He was crazy to run away. Even if you’re not a traitor, you’re going to look like one if you run away.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$You know not$NEWLINE$Whether it was his wisdom or his fear.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$You don’t know whether it was wisdom or fear that made him flee.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Wisdom! To leave his wife, to leave his babes,$NEWLINE$His mansion and his titles in a place$NEWLINE$From whence himself does fly? He loves us not;$NEWLINE$He wants the natural touch. For the poor wren,$NEWLINE$The most diminutive of birds, will fight,$NEWLINE$Her young ones in her nest, against the owl.$NEWLINE$All is the fear and nothing is the love,$NEWLINE$As little is the wisdom, where the flight$NEWLINE$So runs against all reason.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$How could it be wisdom! To leave his wife, his children, his house, and his titles in a place so unsafe that he himself flees it! He doesn’t love us. He lacks the natural instinct to protect his family. Even the fragile wren, the smallest of birds, will fight against the owl when it threatens her young ones in the nest. His running away has everything to do with fear and nothing to do with love. And since it’s so unreasonable for him to run away, it has nothing to do with wisdom either.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$My dearest coz,$NEWLINE$I pray you school yourself. But for your husband,$NEWLINE$He is noble, wise, judicious, and best knows$NEWLINE$The fits o' th' season. I dare not speak much further;$NEWLINE$But cruel are the times when we are traitors$NEWLINE$And do not know ourselves; when we hold rumor$NEWLINE$From what we fear, yet know not what we fear,$NEWLINE$But float upon a wild and violent sea$NEWLINE$Each way and none. I take my leave of you.$NEWLINE$Shall not be long but I’ll be here again.$NEWLINE$Things at the worst will cease, or else climb upward$NEWLINE$To what they were before.—My pretty cousin,$NEWLINE$Blessing upon you.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$My dearest relative, I’m begging you, pull yourself together. As for your husband, he is noble, wise, and judicious, and he understands what the times require. It’s not safe for me to say much more than this, but times are bad when people get denounced as traitors and don’t even know why. In times like these, we believe frightening rumors but we don’t even know what we’re afraid of. It’s like being tossed around on the ocean in every direction, and finally getting nowhere. I’ll say good-bye now. It won’t be long before I’m back. When things are at their worst they have to stop, or else improve to the way things were before. My young cousin, I put my blessing upon you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Fathered he is, and yet he’s fatherless.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$He has a father, and yet he is fatherless.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$I am so much a fool, should I stay longer$NEWLINE$It would be my disgrace and your discomfort.$NEWLINE$I take my leave at once.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$I have to go. If I stay longer, I’ll embarrass you and disgrace myself by crying. I’m leaving now.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: ROSS exits.$NEWLINE$ROSS

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Sirrah, your father’s dead.$NEWLINE$And what will you do now? How will you live?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Young man, your father’s dead. What are you going to do now? How are you going to live?

paragraphs.original: SON$NEWLINE$As birds do, Mother.
paragraphs.translated: SON$NEWLINE$I will live the way birds do, Mother.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$What, with worms and flies?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$What? Are you going to start eating worms and flies?

paragraphs.original: SON$NEWLINE$With what I get, I mean, and so do they.
paragraphs.translated: SON$NEWLINE$I mean I will live on whatever I get, like birds do.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Poor bird! Thou ’dst never fear the net nor lime,$NEWLINE$The pitfall nor the gin.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$You’d be a pitiful bird. You wouldn’t know enough to be afraid of traps.

paragraphs.original: SON$NEWLINE$Why should I, mother? Poor birds they are not set for.$NEWLINE$My father is not dead, for all your saying.
paragraphs.translated: SON$NEWLINE$Why should I be afraid of them, Mother? If I’m a pitiful bird, like you say, hunters won’t want me. No matter what you say, my father is not dead.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Yes, he is dead. How wilt thou do for a father?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Yes, he is dead. What are you going to do for a father?

paragraphs.original: SON$NEWLINE$Nay, how will you do for a husband?
paragraphs.translated: SON$NEWLINE$Maybe you should ask, what will you do for a husband?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Why, I can buy me twenty at any market.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Oh, I can buy twenty husbands at any market.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SON$NEWLINE$Then you’ll buy 'em to sell again.
paragraphs.translated: SON$NEWLINE$If so, you’d be buying them to sell again.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Thou speak’st with all thy wit; and yet, i' faith,$NEWLINE$With wit enough for thee.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$You talk like a child, but you’re very smart anyway.

paragraphs.original: SON$NEWLINE$Was my father a traitor, Mother?
paragraphs.translated: SON$NEWLINE$Was my father a traitor, Mother?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Ay, that he was.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Yes, he was.

paragraphs.original: SON$NEWLINE$What is a traitor?
paragraphs.translated: SON$NEWLINE$What is a traitor?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Why, one that swears and lies.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Someone who makes a promise and breaks it.

paragraphs.original: SON$NEWLINE$And be all traitors that do so?
paragraphs.translated: SON$NEWLINE$And is everyone who swears and lies a traitor?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Every one that does so is a traitor and must be hanged.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Everyone who does so is a traitor and should be hanged.

paragraphs.original: SON$NEWLINE$And must they all be hanged that swear and lie?
paragraphs.translated: SON$NEWLINE$And should everyone who makes promises and breaks them be hanged?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Every one.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Everyone.

paragraphs.original: SON$NEWLINE$Who must hang them?
paragraphs.translated: SON$NEWLINE$Who should hang them?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Why, the honest men.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$The honest men.

paragraphs.original: SON$NEWLINE$Then the liars and swearers are fools, for there are liars and swearers enough to beat the honest men and hang up them.
paragraphs.translated: SON$NEWLINE$Then the liars are fools, for there are enough liars in the world to beat up the honest men and hang them.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Now, God help thee, poor monkey! But how wilt thou do for a father?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$(laughing) Heaven help you for saying that, boy! (sad again) But what will you do without a father?$NEWLINE$(laughing)$NEWLINE$(sad again)

paragraphs.original: SON$NEWLINE$If he were dead, you’d weep for him. If you would not, it were a good sign that I should quickly have a new father.
paragraphs.translated: SON$NEWLINE$If he were dead, you’d be weeping for him. If you aren’t weeping, it’s a good sign that I’ll soon have a new father.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Poor prattler, how thou talk’st!
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Silly babbler, how you talk!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Bless you, fair dame! I am not to you known,$NEWLINE$Though in your state of honor I am perfect.$NEWLINE$I doubt some danger does approach you nearly.$NEWLINE$If you will take a homely man’s advice,$NEWLINE$Be not found here. Hence with your little ones.$NEWLINE$To fright you thus methinks I am too savage;$NEWLINE$To do worse to you were fell cruelty,$NEWLINE$Which is too nigh your person. Heaven preserve you!$NEWLINE$I dare abide no longer.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Bless you, fair lady! You don’t know me, but I know you’re an important person. I’m afraid something dangerous is coming toward you. If you’ll take a simple man’s advice, don’t be here when it arrives. Go away and take your children. I feel bad for scaring you like this, but it would be much worse for me to let you come to harm. And harm is getting close! Heaven keep you safe!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: The MESSENGER exits.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Whither should I fly?$NEWLINE$I have done no harm. But I remember now$NEWLINE$I am in this earthly world, where to do harm$NEWLINE$Is often laudable, to do good sometime$NEWLINE$Accounted dangerous folly. Why then, alas,$NEWLINE$Do I put up that womanly defense,$NEWLINE$To say I have done no harm?
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Where should I go? I haven’t done anything wrong. But I have to remember that I’m here on Earth, where doing evil is often praised, and doing good is sometimes a stupid and dangerous mistake. So then why should I offer this womanish defense that I’m innocent?

paragraphs.original: Enter MURDERERS$NEWLINE$MURDERERS
paragraphs.translated: The MURDERERS enter.$NEWLINE$MURDERERS

paragraphs.original: What are these faces?
paragraphs.translated: Who are these men?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Where is your husband?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Where is your husband?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I hope, in no place so unsanctified$NEWLINE$Where such as thou mayst find him.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I hope he’s not anywhere so disreputable that thugs like you can find him.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$He’s a traitor.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$He’s a traitor.

paragraphs.original: SON$NEWLINE$Thou liest, thou shag-haired villain!
paragraphs.translated: SON$NEWLINE$You’re lying, you shaggy-haired villain!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$(Stabbing him)     What, you egg?$NEWLINE$(Stabbing him)$NEWLINE$Young fry of treachery!
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$What’s that, you runt? (stabbing him) Young son of a traitor!$NEWLINE$(stabbing him)

paragraphs.original: SON$NEWLINE$He has killed me, mother.$NEWLINE$Run away, I pray you!
paragraphs.translated: SON$NEWLINE$He has killed me, Mother. Run away, I beg you!

paragraphs.original: He dies. Exit LADY MACDUFF, crying “Murder!” followed by MURDERERS$NEWLINE$LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$MURDERERS
paragraphs.translated: The SON dies. LADY MACDUFF exits, crying “Murder!” The MURDERERS exit, following her.$NEWLINE$SON$NEWLINE$LADY MACDUFF$NEWLINE$MURDERERS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter MALCOLM and MACDUFF$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$MACDUFF
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM and MACDUFF enter.$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$MACDUFF

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Let us seek out some desolate shade and there$NEWLINE$Weep our sad bosoms empty.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Let’s seek out some shady place where we can sit down alone and cry our hearts out.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Let us rather$NEWLINE$Hold fast the mortal sword and, like good men,$NEWLINE$Bestride our downfall'n birthdom. Each new morn$NEWLINE$New widows howl, new orphans cry, new sorrows$NEWLINE$Strike heaven on the face, that it resounds$NEWLINE$As if it felt with Scotland and yelled out$NEWLINE$Like syllable of dolor.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Instead of crying, let’s keep hold of our swords and defend our fallen homeland like honorable men. Each day new widows howl, new orphans cry, and new sorrows slap heaven in the face, until it sounds like heaven itself feels Scotland’s anguish and screams in pain.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$What I believe I’ll wail;$NEWLINE$What know believe, and what I can redress,$NEWLINE$As I shall find the time to friend, I will.$NEWLINE$What you have spoke, it may be so perchance.$NEWLINE$This tyrant, whose sole name blisters our tongues,$NEWLINE$Was once thought honest. You have loved him well.$NEWLINE$He hath not touched you yet. I am young, but something$NEWLINE$You may deserve of him through me, and wisdom$NEWLINE$To offer up a weak, poor, innocent lamb$NEWLINE$T' appease an angry god.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$I will avenge whatever I believe is wrong. And I’ll believe whatever I’m sure is true. And I’ll put right whatever I can when the time comes. What you just said may perhaps be true. This tyrant, whose mere name is so awful it hurts us to say it, was once considered an honest man. You were one of his favorites. He hasn’t done anything to harm you yet. I’m inexperienced, but maybe you’re planning to win Macbeth’s favor by betraying me to him. It would be smart to offer someone poor and innocent like me as a sacrificial lamb to satisfy an angry god like Macbeth.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I am not treacherous.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I am not treacherous.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$But Macbeth is.$NEWLINE$A good and virtuous nature may recoil$NEWLINE$In an imperial charge. But I shall crave your pardon.$NEWLINE$That which you are, my thoughts cannot transpose.$NEWLINE$Angels are bright still, though the brightest fell.$NEWLINE$Though all things foul would wear the brows of grace,$NEWLINE$Yet grace must still look so.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$But Macbeth is. Even someone with a good and virtuous nature might give way to a royal command. But I beg your pardon. My fears can’t actually make you evil. Angels are still bright even though Lucifer, the brightest angel, fell from heaven. Even though everything evil wants to look good, good still has to look good too.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I have lost my hopes.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I have lost my hope of convincing you to fight against Macbeth.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Perchance even there where I did find my doubts.$NEWLINE$Why in that rawness left you wife and child,$NEWLINE$Those precious motives, those strong knots of love,$NEWLINE$Without leave-taking? I pray you,$NEWLINE$Let not my jealousies be your dishonors,$NEWLINE$But mine own safeties. You may be rightly just,$NEWLINE$Whatever I shall think.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Maybe you lost your hopes about me where I found my doubts about you. Why did you leave your wife and child vulnerable—the most precious things in your life, those strong bonds of love? How could you leave them behind? But I beg you, don’t interpret my suspicions as slander against you. You must understand that I want to protect myself. You may really be honest, no matter what I think.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Bleed, bleed, poor country!$NEWLINE$Great tyranny, lay thou thy basis sure,$NEWLINE$For goodness dare not check thee. Wear thou thy wrongs;$NEWLINE$The title is affeered.—Fare thee well, lord.$NEWLINE$I would not be the villain that thou think’st$NEWLINE$For the whole space that’s in the tyrant’s grasp,$NEWLINE$And the rich East to boot.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Bleed, bleed, poor country! Great tyrant, go ahead and build yourself up, because good people are afraid to stand up to you. Enjoy everything you stole, because your title is safe! Farewell, lord. I wouldn’t be the villain you think I am even if I were offered all of Macbeth’s kingdom and the riches of the East too.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Be not offended.$NEWLINE$I speak not as in absolute fear of you.$NEWLINE$I think our country sinks beneath the yoke.$NEWLINE$It weeps, it bleeds, and each new day a gash$NEWLINE$Is added to her wounds. I think withal$NEWLINE$There would be hands uplifted in my right;$NEWLINE$And here from gracious England have I offer$NEWLINE$Of goodly thousands. But, for all this,$NEWLINE$When I shall tread upon the tyrant’s head,$NEWLINE$Or wear it on my sword, yet my poor country$NEWLINE$Shall have more vices than it had before,$NEWLINE$More suffer, and more sundry ways than ever,$NEWLINE$By him that shall succeed.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Don’t be offended. I don’t completely distrust you. I do think Scotland is sinking under Macbeth’s oppression. Our country weeps, it bleeds, and each day a fresh cut is added to her wounds. I also think there would be many people willing to fight for me. The English have promised me thousands of troops. But even so, when I have Macbeth’s head under my foot, or stuck on the end of my sword, then my poor country will be plagued by worse evil than it was before. It will suffer worse and in more ways than ever under the reign of the king who follows Macbeth.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$What should he be?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Who are you talking about?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$It is myself I mean, in whom I know$NEWLINE$All the particulars of vice so grafted$NEWLINE$That, when they shall be opened, black Macbeth$NEWLINE$Will seem as pure as snow, and the poor state$NEWLINE$Esteem him as a lamb, being compared$NEWLINE$With my confineless harms.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$I’m talking about myself. I know I have so many vices that when people see all of them exposed, evil Macbeth will seem as pure as snow in comparison, and poor Scotland will call him a sweet lamb when they compare him to me and my infinite evils.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Not in the legions$NEWLINE$Of horrid hell can come a devil more damned$NEWLINE$In evils to top Macbeth.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Even in hell you couldn’t find a devil worse than Macbeth.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$I grant him bloody,$NEWLINE$Luxurious, avaricious, false, deceitful,$NEWLINE$Sudden, malicious, smacking of every sin$NEWLINE$That has a name. But there’s no bottom, none,$NEWLINE$In my voluptuousness. Your wives, your daughters,$NEWLINE$Your matrons, and your maids could not fill up$NEWLINE$The cistern of my lust, and my desire$NEWLINE$All continent impediments would o'erbear$NEWLINE$That did oppose my will. Better Macbeth$NEWLINE$Than such an one to reign.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$I admit that he’s murderous, lecherous, greedy, lying, deceitful, violent, malicious, and guilty of every sin that has a name. But there is no end, absolutely none, to my sexual desires. Your wives, your daughters, your old women, and your young maids together could not satisfy my lust. My desire would overpower all restraints and anyone who stood in my way. It would be better for Macbeth to rule than someone like me.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Boundless intemperance$NEWLINE$In nature is a tyranny. It hath been$NEWLINE$The untimely emptying of the happy throne$NEWLINE$And fall of many kings. But fear not yet$NEWLINE$To take upon you what is yours. You may$NEWLINE$Convey your pleasures in a spacious plenty$NEWLINE$And yet seem cold; the time you may so hoodwink.$NEWLINE$We have willing dames enough. There cannot be$NEWLINE$That vulture in you to devour so many$NEWLINE$As will to greatness dedicate themselves,$NEWLINE$Finding it so inclined.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Endless greed and lust in a man’s nature is a kind of tyranny. It has caused the downfall of many kings. But don’t be afraid to take the crown that belongs to you. You can find a way to satisfy your desires in secret, while still appearing virtuous. You can deceive everyone. There are more than enough willing women around. Your lust can’t possibly be so strong that you’d use up all the women willing to give themselves to the king once they find out he wants them.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$With this there grows$NEWLINE$In my most ill-composed affection such$NEWLINE$A stanchless avarice that, were I king,$NEWLINE$I should cut off the nobles for their lands,$NEWLINE$Desire his jewels and this other’s house.$NEWLINE$And my more-having would be as a sauce$NEWLINE$To make me hunger more, that I should forge$NEWLINE$Quarrels unjust against the good and loyal,$NEWLINE$Destroying them for wealth.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Along with being full of lust, I’m also incredibly greedy. If I became king, I would steal the nobles' lands, taking jewels from one guy and houses from another. The more I had, the greedier I would grow, until I’d invent false quarrels with my good and loyal subjects, destroying them so I could get my hands on their wealth.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$This avarice$NEWLINE$Sticks deeper, grows with more pernicious root$NEWLINE$Than summer-seeming lust, and it hath been$NEWLINE$The sword of our slain kings. Yet do not fear;$NEWLINE$Scotland hath foisons to fill up your will,$NEWLINE$Of your mere own. All these are portable,$NEWLINE$With other graces weighed.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$The greed you’re talking about is worse than lust because you won’t outgrow it. Greed has been the downfall of many kings. But don’t be afraid. Scotland has enough treasures to satisfy you out of your own royal coffers. These bad qualities are bearable when balanced against your good sides.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$But I have none. The king-becoming graces,$NEWLINE$As justice, verity, temperance, stableness,$NEWLINE$Bounty, perseverance, mercy, lowliness,$NEWLINE$Devotion, patience, courage, fortitude,$NEWLINE$I have no relish of them but abound$NEWLINE$In the division of each several crime,$NEWLINE$Acting it many ways. Nay, had I power, I should$NEWLINE$Pour the sweet milk of concord into hell,$NEWLINE$Uproar the universal peace, confound$NEWLINE$All unity on earth.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$But I don’t have any good sides. I don’t have a trace of the qualities a king needs, such as justice, truth, moderation, stability, generosity, perseverance, mercy, humility, devotion, patience, courage, and bravery. Instead, I overflow with every variation of all the different vices. No, if I had power I would take world peace and throw it down to hell.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$O Scotland, Scotland!
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Oh Scotland, Scotland!

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$If such a one be fit to govern, speak.$NEWLINE$I am as I have spoken.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$If someone like me is fit to be king, let me know. I really am exactly as I have described myself to you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Fit to govern?$NEWLINE$No, not to live.—O nation miserable,$NEWLINE$With an untitled tyrant bloody-sceptered,$NEWLINE$When shalt thou see thy wholesome days again,$NEWLINE$Since that the truest issue of thy throne$NEWLINE$By his own interdiction stands accursed,$NEWLINE$And does blaspheme his breed?—Thy royal father$NEWLINE$Was a most sainted king. The queen that bore thee,$NEWLINE$Oftener upon her knees than on her feet,$NEWLINE$Died every day she lived. Fare thee well!$NEWLINE$These evils thou repeat’st upon thyself$NEWLINE$Have banished me from Scotland.—O my breast,$NEWLINE$Thy hope ends here!
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$(to MALCOLM) Fit to be king? You’re not fit to live!—Oh miserable nation, ruled by a usurping, murderous tyrant, when will you see peaceful days again? The man who has a legal right to the throne is, by his own admission, a cursed man and a disgrace to the royal family.—Your royal father Duncan was a virtuous king. Your mother spent more time on her knees in prayer than she did standing up, and she lived a life of absolute piety. Good-bye. The evils you have described inside yourself have driven me out of Scotland forever. Oh my heart, your hope is dead!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$—$NEWLINE$—

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Macduff, this noble passion,$NEWLINE$Child of integrity, hath from my soul$NEWLINE$Wiped the black scruples, reconciled my thoughts$NEWLINE$To thy good truth and honor. Devilish Macbeth$NEWLINE$By many of these trains hath sought to win me$NEWLINE$Into his power, and modest wisdom plucks me$NEWLINE$From overcredulous haste. But God above$NEWLINE$Deal between thee and me, for even now$NEWLINE$I put myself to thy direction and$NEWLINE$Unspeak mine own detraction, here abjure$NEWLINE$The taints and blames I laid upon myself,$NEWLINE$For strangers to my nature. I am yet$NEWLINE$Unknown to woman, never was forsworn,$NEWLINE$Scarcely have coveted what was mine own,$NEWLINE$At no time broke my faith, would not betray$NEWLINE$The devil to his fellow, and delight$NEWLINE$No less in truth than life. My first false speaking$NEWLINE$Was this upon myself. What I am truly,$NEWLINE$Is thine and my poor country’s to command.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Macduff, this passionate outburst, which proves your integrity, has removed my doubts about you and made me realize that you really are trustworthy and honorable. That devil Macbeth has tried many times to trick me and lure me into his power, and prudence prevents me from believing people too quickly. But with God as my witness, I will let myself be guided by you, and I take back my confession. I take back all the bad things I said about myself, because none of those flaws are really part of my character. I’m still a virgin. I have never told a lie. I barely care about what I already own, let alone feel jealous of another’s possessions. I have never broken a promise. I wouldn’t betray the devil himself. I love truth as much as I love life. The lies I told about my character are actually the first false words I have ever spoken. The person who I really am is ready to serve you and our poor country.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Whither indeed, before thy here-approach,$NEWLINE$Old Siward, with ten thousand warlike men,$NEWLINE$Already at a point, was setting forth.$NEWLINE$Now we’ll together, and the chance of goodness$NEWLINE$Be like our warranted quarrel! Why are you silent?
paragraphs.translated: Indeed, before you arrived here, old Siward, with ten thousand soldiers already prepared for battle, was making his way here. Now we will fight Macbeth together, and may the chances of our success be as great as the justice of our cause! Why are you silent?

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Such welcome and unwelcome things at once$NEWLINE$'Tis hard to reconcile.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$It’s hard to make sense of such different stories.

paragraphs.original: Enter a DOCTOR$NEWLINE$DOCTOR
paragraphs.translated: A DOCTOR enters.$NEWLINE$DOCTOR

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Well, more anon.—Comes the king forth, I pray you?
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Well, we’ll speak more soon. (to the DOCTOR) Is King Edward coming out?$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Ay, sir; there are a crew of wretched souls$NEWLINE$That stay his cure. Their malady convinces$NEWLINE$The great assay of art, but at his touch—$NEWLINE$Such sanctity hath heaven given his hand—$NEWLINE$They presently amend.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Yes, sir. A crowd of sick people is waiting for him to heal them. Their illness confounds the most advanced techniques of modern medicine, but when he touches them, they heal immediately because of the power granted to him by heaven.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$I thank you, doctor.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Thank you, doctor.

paragraphs.original: Exit DOCTOR$NEWLINE$DOCTOR
paragraphs.translated: The DOCTOR exits.$NEWLINE$DOCTOR

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$What’s the disease he means?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$What disease is he talking about?

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$'Tis called the evil.$NEWLINE$A most miraculous work in this good king,$NEWLINE$Which often since my here-remain in England$NEWLINE$I have seen him do. How he solicits heaven,$NEWLINE$Himself best knows, but strangely visited people,$NEWLINE$All swoll'n and ulcerous, pitiful to the eye,$NEWLINE$The mere despair of surgery, he cures,$NEWLINE$Hanging a golden stamp about their necks,$NEWLINE$Put on with holy prayers. And, ’tis spoken,
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$It’s called the evil. Edward’s healing touch is a miracle that I have seen him perform many times during my stay in England. How he receives these gifts from heaven, only he can say. But he cures people with strange conditions—all swollen, plagued by ulcers, and pitiful to look at, patients who are beyond the help of surgery—by placing a gold coin around their necks and saying holy prayers over them.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: To the succeeding royalty he leaves$NEWLINE$The healing benediction. With this strange virtue,$NEWLINE$He hath a heavenly gift of prophecy,$NEWLINE$And sundry blessings hang about his throne,$NEWLINE$That speak him full of grace.
paragraphs.translated: They say that he bequeaths this ability to heal to his royal descendants. Along with this strange power, he also has the gift of prophecy and various other abilities. All of these signs mark him as a man graced by God.

paragraphs.original: Enter ROSS$NEWLINE$ROSS
paragraphs.translated: ROSS enters.$NEWLINE$ROSS

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$See, who comes here?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Who’s that coming over here?

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$My countryman, but yet I know him not.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$By his dress I can tell he’s my countryman, but I don’t recognize him.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$My ever-gentle cousin, welcome hither.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$My noble kinsman, welcome.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$I know him now.—Good God, betimes remove$NEWLINE$The means that makes us strangers!
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$I recognize him now. May God alter the circumstances that keep us apart!

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Sir, amen.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$Hello, sir.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Stands Scotland where it did?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Is Scotland the same as when I left it?

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Alas, poor country!$NEWLINE$Almost afraid to know itself. It cannot$NEWLINE$Be called our mother, but our grave, where nothing,$NEWLINE$But who knows nothing, is once seen to smile;$NEWLINE$Where sighs and groans and shrieks that rend the air$NEWLINE$Are made, not marked; where violent sorrow seems$NEWLINE$A modern ecstasy. The dead man’s knell$NEWLINE$Is there scarce asked for who, and good men’s lives$NEWLINE$Expire before the flowers in their caps,$NEWLINE$Dying or ere they sicken.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$Alas, our poor country! It’s too frightened to look at itself. Scotland is no longer the land where we were born; it’s the land where we’ll die. Where no one ever smiles except for the fool who knows nothing. Where sighs, groans, and shrieks rip through the air but no one notices. Where violent sorrow is a common emotion. When the funeral bells ring, people no longer ask who died. Good men die before the flowers in their caps wilt. They die before they even fall sick.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Oh, relation$NEWLINE$Too nice and yet too true!
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Oh, your report is too poetic, but it sounds so true!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$What’s the newest grief?
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$What is the most recent news?

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$That of an hour’s age doth hiss the speaker.$NEWLINE$Each minute teems a new one.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$Even news an hour old is old news. Every minute another awful thing happens.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$How does my wife?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$How is my wife?

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Why, well.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$She’s well.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$And all my children?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$And all my children?

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Well too.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$They’re well too.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$The tyrant has not battered at their peace?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Macbeth hasn’t attacked them?

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$No, they were well at peace when I did leave 'em.
paragraphs.translated:
ROSS$NEWLINE$They were
at peace when I left them.$NEWLINE$at peace$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Be not a niggard of your speech. How goes ’t?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Don’t be stingy with your words. What’s the news?

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$When I came hither to transport the tidings,$NEWLINE$Which I have heavily borne, there ran a rumor$NEWLINE$Of many worthy fellows that were out;$NEWLINE$Which was to my belief witnessed the rather$NEWLINE$For that I saw the tyrant’s power afoot.$NEWLINE$Now is the time of help. Your eye in Scotland$NEWLINE$Would create soldiers, make our women fight,$NEWLINE$To doff their dire distresses.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$While I was coming here to tell you my sad news, I heard rumors that many good men are arming themselves to rebel against Macbeth. When I saw Macbeth’s army on the move, I knew the rumors must be true. Now is the time when we need your help. Your presence in Scotland would inspire people to fight. Even the women would fight to rid themselves of Macbeth’s oppression.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Be ’t their comfort$NEWLINE$We are coming thither. Gracious England hath$NEWLINE$Lent us good Siward and ten thousand men;$NEWLINE$An older and a better soldier none$NEWLINE$That Christendom gives out.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Let them be comforted—I’m returning to Scotland. Gracious King Edward has sent us noble Siward and ten thousand soldiers. There is no soldier more experienced or successful than Siward in the entire Christian world.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Would I could answer$NEWLINE$This comfort with the like. But I have words$NEWLINE$That would be howled out in the desert air,$NEWLINE$Where hearing should not latch them.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$I wish I could repay this happy news with good news of my own. But I have some news that should be howled in a barren desert where nobody can hear it.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$What concern they?$NEWLINE$The general cause, or is it a fee-grief$NEWLINE$Due to some single breast?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$What is this news about? Does it affect all of us? Or just one of us?

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$No mind that’s honest$NEWLINE$But in it shares some woe, though the main part$NEWLINE$Pertains to you alone.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$No decent man can keep from sharing in the sorrow, but my news affects you alone.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$If it be mine,$NEWLINE$Keep it not from me. Quickly let me have it.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$If it’s for me, don’t keep it from me. Let me have it now.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Let not your ears despise my tongue forever,$NEWLINE$Which shall possess them with the heaviest sound$NEWLINE$That ever yet they heard.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$I hope you won’t hate me forever after I say these things, because I will soon fill your ears with the most dreadful news you have ever heard.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Hum! I guess at it.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I think I can guess what you’re about to say.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Your castle is surprised, your wife and babes$NEWLINE$Savagely slaughtered. To relate the manner,$NEWLINE$Were, on the quarry of these murdered deer$NEWLINE$To add the death of you.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$Your castle was attacked. Your wife and children were savagely slaughtered. If I told you how they were killed, it would cause you so much pain that it would kill you too, and add your body to the pile of murdered corpses.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Merciful heaven!$NEWLINE$What, man! Ne'er pull your hat upon your brows.$NEWLINE$Give sorrow words. The grief that does not speak$NEWLINE$Whispers the o'erfraught heart and bids it break.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Merciful heaven! (to MACDUFF) Come on, man, don’t keep your grief hidden. Put your sorrow into words. The grief you keep inside you will whisper in your heart until it breaks.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$My children too?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$They killed my children too?

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Wife, children, servants, all that could be found.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$They killed your wife, your children, your servants, anyone they could find.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$And I must be from thence!$NEWLINE$My wife killed too?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$And I had to be away! My wife was killed too?

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$I have said.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$I said she was.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Be comforted.$NEWLINE$Let’s make us med'cines of our great revenge,$NEWLINE$To cure this deadly grief.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Take comfort. Let’s cure this awful grief by taking revenge on Macbeth.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$He has no children. All my pretty ones?$NEWLINE$Did you say all? O hell-kite! All?$NEWLINE$What, all my pretty chickens and their dam$NEWLINE$At one fell swoop?
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$He doesn’t have children. All my pretty little children? Did you say all? Oh, that bird from hell! All of them? What, all my children and their mother dead in one fell swoop?

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Dispute it like a man.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Fight it like a man.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I shall do so,$NEWLINE$But I must also feel it as a man.$NEWLINE$I cannot but remember such things were$NEWLINE$That were most precious to me. Did heaven look on,$NEWLINE$And would not take their part? Sinful Macduff,$NEWLINE$They were all struck for thee! Naught that I am,$NEWLINE$Not for their own demerits, but for mine,$NEWLINE$Fell slaughter on their souls. Heaven rest them now.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I will. But I also have to feel it like a man. I can’t help remembering the things that were most precious to me. Did heaven watch the slaughter and not send down any help? Sinful Macduff, they were killed because of you! As wicked as I am, they were slaughtered because of me, not because of anything they did. May God give their souls rest.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Be this the whetstone of your sword. Let grief$NEWLINE$Convert to anger. Blunt not the heart, enrage it.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Let this anger sharpen your sword. Transform your grief into anger. Don’t block the feelings in your heart; let them loose as rage.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Oh, I could play the woman with mine eyes$NEWLINE$And braggart with my tongue! But, gentle heavens,$NEWLINE$Cut short all intermission. Front to front$NEWLINE$Bring thou this fiend of Scotland and myself.$NEWLINE$Within my sword’s length set him; if he ’scape,$NEWLINE$Heaven forgive him too.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I could go on weeping like a woman and bragging about how I will avenge them! But gentle heavens, don’t keep me waiting. Bring me face to face with Macbeth, that devil of Scotland. Put him within the reach of my sword, and if he escapes, may heaven forgive him as well!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$This tune goes manly.$NEWLINE$Come, go we to the king. Our power is ready;$NEWLINE$Our lack is nothing but our leave. Macbeth$NEWLINE$Is ripe for shaking, and the powers above$NEWLINE$Put on their instruments. Receive what cheer you may.$NEWLINE$The night is long that never finds the day.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Now you sound like a man. Come on, let’s go see King Edward. The army is ready. All we have to do now is say goodbye to the king. Macbeth is ripe for the picking. We’ll be acting as God’s agents. Cheer up as much as you can. A new day will come at last.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT
