paragraphs.original: Enter a DOCTOR of physic and a waiting-GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$DOCTOR$NEWLINE$GENTLEWOMAN
paragraphs.translated:
A DOCTOR and a waiting-
GENTLEWOMAN enter.$NEWLINE$DOCTOR$NEWLINE$GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$I have two nights watched with you but can perceive no truth in your report. When was it she last walked?
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$I’ve stayed up with you for two nights now, and I haven’t seen any evidence of what you were talking about. When was the last time you saw her sleepwalking?

paragraphs.original: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$Since his majesty went into the field, I have seen her rise from her bed, throw her nightgown upon her, unlock her closet, take forth paper, fold it, write upon ’t, read it, afterwards seal it, and again return to bed; yet all this while in a most fast sleep.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$Since Macbeth went to war, I have seen her rise from her bed, put on her nightgown, unlock her closet, take out some paper, fold it, write on it, read it, seal it up, and then return to bed, remaining asleep the entire time.

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$A great perturbation in nature, to receive at once the benefit of sleep, and do the line>effects of watching. In this slumbery agitation, besides her walking and other actual performances, what, at any time, have you heard her say?
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$It’s unnatural to be asleep and act as if you’re awake. When she is like this, besides walking and performing various activities, have you heard her say anything?

paragraphs.original: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$That, sir, which I will not report after her.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$She says something, sir, but I will not repeat it to you.

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$You may to me, and ’tis most meet you should.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$You can tell me. You really should.

paragraphs.original: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$Neither to you nor any one, having no witness to confirm my speech.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$I will not confess it to you nor to anyone else, because there was no one else to witness her speech.

paragraphs.original: Enter LADY MACBETH with a taper$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH enters, holding a candle.$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH

paragraphs.original: Lo you, here she comes. This is her very guise; and, upon my life, fast asleep. Observe her, stand close.
paragraphs.translated: Look, here she comes! This is exactly how she always looks, and—I swear it—she is fast asleep. Watch her. Keep hidden.

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$How came she by that light?
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$How did she get that candle?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$Why, it stood by her. She has light by her continually. 'Tis her command.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$It stands by her bedside. She always has to have a light next to her. Those are her orders.

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$You see her eyes are open.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$You see, her eyes are open.

paragraphs.original: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$Ay, but their sense is shut.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$Yes, but they don’t see anything.

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$What is it she does now? Look, how she rubs her hands.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$What’s she doing now? Look how she rubs her hands.

paragraphs.original: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$It is an accustomed action with her to seem thus washing her hands. I have known her continue in this a quarter of an hour.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$She often does that. She looks like she’s washing her hands. I’ve seen her do that before for as long as fifteen minutes.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Yet here’s a spot.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$There’s still a spot here.

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Hark! She speaks. I will set down what comes from her, to satisfy my remembrance the more strongly.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Listen! She’s talking. I’ll write down what she says, so I’ll remember it better.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Out, damned spot! Out, I say!—One, two. Why, then, ’tis time to do ’t. Hell is murky!—Fie, my lord, fie! A soldier, and afeard? What need we fear who knows it, when none can call our power to account?—Yet who would have thought the old man to have had so much blood in him.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$(rubbing her hands) Come out, damned spot! Out, I command you! One, two. OK, it’s time to do it now.—Hell is murky!—Nonsense, my lord, nonsense! You are a soldier, and yet you are afraid? Why should we be scared, when no one can lay the guilt upon us?—But who would have thought the old man would have had so much blood in him?$NEWLINE$(rubbing her hands)

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Do you mark that?
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Did you hear that?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$The thane of Fife had a wife. Where is she now?—What, will these hands ne'er be clean?—No more o' that, my lord, no more o' that. You mar all with this starting.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$The thane of Fife had a wife. Where is she now?—What, will my hands never be clean?—No more of that, my lord, no more of that. You’ll ruin everything by acting startled like this.

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Go to, go to. You have known what you should not.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Now look what you’ve done. You’ve heard something you shouldn’t have.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$She has spoke what she should not, I am sure of that. Heaven knows what she has known.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$She said something she shouldn’t have said, I’m sure of that. Heaven knows what secrets she’s keeping.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Here’s the smell of the blood still. All the perfumes of Arabia will not sweeten this little hand. Oh, Oh, Oh!
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$I still have the smell of blood on my hand. All the perfumes of Arabia couldn’t make my little hand smell better. Oh, oh, oh!

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$What a sigh is there! The heart is sorely charged.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$What a heavy sigh! Her heart is carrying a heavy weight.

paragraphs.original: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$I would not have such a heart in my bosom for the dignity of the whole body.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$I wouldn’t want a heart like hers even if you made me queen.

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Well, well, well.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Well, well, well.

paragraphs.original: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$Pray God it be, sir.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$I hope what she’s saying is well, sir!

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$This disease is beyond my practice. Yet I have known those which have walked in their sleep who have died holily in their beds.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$This disease is beyond my medical skills. But I have known people who sleepwalked and weren’t guilty of anything.

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Wash your hands. Put on your nightgown. Look not so pale.—I tell you yet again, Banquo’s buried; he cannot come out on ’s grave.
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$Wash your hands. Put on your nightgown. Don’t look so frightened. I tell you again, Banquo is buried. He cannot come out of his grave.

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Even so?
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Is this true?

paragraphs.original: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$To bed, to bed. There’s knocking at the gate. Come, come, come, come. Give me your hand. What’s done cannot be undone.—To bed, to bed, to bed!
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH$NEWLINE$To bed, to bed! There’s a knocking at the gate. Come, come, come, come, give me your hand. What’s done cannot be undone. To bed, to bed, to bed!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: LADY MACBETH exits.$NEWLINE$LADY MACBETH

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Will she go now to bed?
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Will she go to bed now?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$Directly.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$Yes, right away.

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Foul whisp'rings are abroad. Unnatural deeds$NEWLINE$Do breed unnatural troubles. Infected minds$NEWLINE$To their deaf pillows will discharge their secrets.$NEWLINE$More needs she the divine than the physician.$NEWLINE$God, God forgive us all! Look after her,$NEWLINE$Remove from her the means of all annoyance,$NEWLINE$And still keep eyes upon her. So, good night.$NEWLINE$My mind she has mated, and amazed my sight.$NEWLINE$I think, but dare not speak.
paragraphs.translated:
DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Evil rumors are going around. Unnatural acts will cause
supernatural things to happen. People with guilty and deranged minds will confess their secrets to their pillows as they sleep. This woman needs a priest more than a doctor. God forgive us all! (to the waiting- GENTLEWOMAN) Look after her. Remove anything she might hurt herself with. Watch her constantly. And now, good-night. She has bewildered my mind and amazed my eyes. I have an opinion, but I don’t dare to say it out loud.$NEWLINE$supernatural$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$(to the waiting-$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$Good night, good doctor.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEWOMAN$NEWLINE$Good night, good doctor.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Drum and colors. Enter MENTEITH, CAITHNESS, ANGUS, LENNOX, and soldiers$NEWLINE$MENTEITH$NEWLINE$CAITHNESS$NEWLINE$ANGUS$NEWLINE$LENNOX
paragraphs.translated: MENTEITH, CAITHNESS, ANGUS, LENNOX, and soldiers enter with a drummer and flag.$NEWLINE$MENTEITH$NEWLINE$CAITHNESS$NEWLINE$ANGUS$NEWLINE$LENNOX

paragraphs.original: MENTEITH$NEWLINE$The English power is near, led on by Malcolm,$NEWLINE$His uncle Siward and the good Macduff.$NEWLINE$Revenges burn in them, for their dear causes$NEWLINE$Would to the bleeding and the grim alarm$NEWLINE$Excite the mortified man.
paragraphs.translated: MENTEITH$NEWLINE$The English army is near, led by Malcolm, his uncle Siward, and the good Macduff. They burn for revenge. The wrongs they have suffered would make dead men rise up and fight.

paragraphs.original: ANGUS$NEWLINE$Near Birnam Wood$NEWLINE$Shall we well meet them; that way are they coming.
paragraphs.translated: ANGUS$NEWLINE$We’ll meet them near Birnam Wood. They are coming that way.

paragraphs.original: CAITHNESS$NEWLINE$Who knows if Donalbain be with his brother?
paragraphs.translated: CAITHNESS$NEWLINE$Does anyone know if Donalbain is with his brother?

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$For certain, sir, he is not. I have a file$NEWLINE$Of all the gentry. There is Siward’s son,$NEWLINE$And many unrough youths that even now$NEWLINE$Protest their first of manhood.
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$He is definitely not there, sir. I have a list of all the important men. Siward’s son is there, as well as many boys too young to have beards who will become men by joining in this battle.

paragraphs.original: MENTEITH$NEWLINE$What does the tyrant?
paragraphs.translated: MENTEITH$NEWLINE$What is the tyrant Macbeth doing?

paragraphs.original: CAITHNESS$NEWLINE$Great Dunsinane he strongly fortifies.$NEWLINE$Some say he’s mad, others that lesser hate him$NEWLINE$Do call it valiant fury. But, for certain,$NEWLINE$He cannot buckle his distempered cause$NEWLINE$Within the belt of rule.
paragraphs.translated: CAITHNESS$NEWLINE$He is fortifying his castle at Dunsinane with heavy defenses. Some say he’s insane. Those who hate him less call it brave anger. One thing is certain: he’s out of control.

paragraphs.original: ANGUS$NEWLINE$Now does he feel$NEWLINE$His secret murders sticking on his hands.$NEWLINE$Now minutely revolts upbraid his faith-breach.$NEWLINE$Those he commands move only in command,$NEWLINE$Nothing in love. Now does he feel his title$NEWLINE$Hang loose about him, like a giant’s robe$NEWLINE$Upon a dwarfish thief.
paragraphs.translated: ANGUS$NEWLINE$Now Macbeth feels the blood of his murdered enemies sticking to his hands. Now, rebel armies punish him every minute for his treachery. The soldiers he commands are only following orders. They don’t fight because they love Macbeth. Now he seems too small to be a great king, like a midget trying to wear the robes of a giant.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MENTEITH$NEWLINE$Who then shall blame$NEWLINE$His pestered senses to recoil and start,$NEWLINE$When all that is within him does condemn$NEWLINE$Itself for being there?
paragraphs.translated: MENTEITH$NEWLINE$Who can blame him for acting crazy, when inside he condemns himself for everything he’s done?

paragraphs.original: CAITHNESS$NEWLINE$Well, march we on,$NEWLINE$To give obedience where ’tis truly owed.$NEWLINE$Meet we the medicine of the sickly weal,$NEWLINE$And with him pour we in our country’s purge$NEWLINE$Each drop of us.
paragraphs.translated: CAITHNESS$NEWLINE$Well, let’s keep marching and give our loyalty to someone who truly deserves it. We’re going to meet Malcolm, the doctor who will cure our sick country. We’ll pour out our own blood to help him.

paragraphs.original: LENNOX$NEWLINE$Or so much as it needs,$NEWLINE$To dew the sovereign flower and drown the weeds.$NEWLINE$Make we our march towards Birnam.
paragraphs.translated: LENNOX$NEWLINE$However much blood we need to give to water the royal flower and drown the weeds—to make Malcolm king and get rid of Macbeth. Let’s proceed on our march to Birnam.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt, marching
paragraphs.translated: They exit, marching.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter MACBETH, DOCTOR, and attendants$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$DOCTOR
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH, a DOCTOR, and attendants enter.$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$DOCTOR

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Bring me no more reports. Let them fly all.$NEWLINE$Till Birnam Wood remove to Dunsinane$NEWLINE$I cannot taint with fear. What’s the boy Malcolm?$NEWLINE$Was he not born of woman? The spirits that know$NEWLINE$All mortal consequences have pronounced me thus:$NEWLINE$“Fear not, Macbeth. No man that’s born of woman$NEWLINE$Shall e'er have power upon thee.” Then fly, false thanes,$NEWLINE$And mingle with the English epicures.$NEWLINE$The mind I sway by and the heart I bear$NEWLINE$Shall never sag with doubt nor shake with fear.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Don’t bring me any more reports. I don’t care if all the thanes desert me. Until Birnam Wood gets up and moves to Dunsinane, I won’t be affected by fear. What’s the boy Malcolm? Wasn’t he born from a woman? The spirits that know the future have told me this: “Don’t be afraid, Macbeth. No man born from a woman will ever defeat you.” So get out of here, disloyal thanes, and join the weak and decadent English! My mind and courage will never falter with doubt or shake with fear.

paragraphs.original: Enter a SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: A SERVANT enters.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: The devil damn thee black, thou cream-faced loon!$NEWLINE$Where got’st thou that goose look?
paragraphs.translated: May the devil turn you black, you white-faced fool! Why do you look like a frightened goose?

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$There is ten thousand—
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$There are ten thousand—

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Geese, villain?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Geese, you idiot?

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Soldiers, sir.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Soldiers, sir.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Go, prick thy face and over-red thy fear,$NEWLINE$Thou lily-livered boy. What soldiers, patch?$NEWLINE$Death of thy soul! Those linen cheeks of thine$NEWLINE$Are counselors to fear. What soldiers, whey-face?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Go pinch your cheeks and bring some color back into your face, you cowardly boy. What soldiers, fool? Curse you! That pale face of yours will frighten the others as well. What soldiers, milk-face?

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$The English force, so please you.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$The English army, sir.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Take thy face hence.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Get out of my sight.

paragraphs.original: Exit SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: The SERVANT exits.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Seyton!—I am sick at heart,$NEWLINE$When I behold—Seyton, I say!—This push$NEWLINE$Will cheer me ever, or disseat me now.$NEWLINE$I have lived long enough. My way of life$NEWLINE$Is fall'n into the sere, the yellow leaf,$NEWLINE$And that which should accompany old age,$NEWLINE$As honor, love, obedience, troops of friends,$NEWLINE$I must not look to have, but, in their stead,$NEWLINE$Curses, not loud but deep, mouth-honor, breath$NEWLINE$Which the poor heart would fain deny and dare not.$NEWLINE$Seyton!
paragraphs.translated: Seyton!—I’m sick at heart when I see—Seyton, come here!—This battle will either secure my reign forever or else topple me from the throne. I have lived long enough. The course of my life is beginning to wither and fall away, like a yellowing leaf in autumn. The things that should go along with old age, like honor, love, obedience, and loyal friends, I cannot hope to have. Instead, I have passionate but quietly whispered curses, people who honor me with their words but not in their hearts, and lingering life, which my heart would gladly end, though I can’t bring myself to do it. Seyton!

paragraphs.original: Enter SEYTON$NEWLINE$SEYTON
paragraphs.translated: SEYTON enters.$NEWLINE$SEYTON

paragraphs.original: SEYTON$NEWLINE$What’s your gracious pleasure?
paragraphs.translated: SEYTON$NEWLINE$What do you want?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$What news more?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Is there more news?

paragraphs.original: SEYTON$NEWLINE$All is confirmed, my lord, which was reported.
paragraphs.translated: SEYTON$NEWLINE$All the rumors have been confirmed.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I’ll fight till from my bones my flesh be hacked.$NEWLINE$Give me my armor.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I’ll fight until they hack the flesh off my bones. Give me my armor.

paragraphs.original: SEYTON$NEWLINE$'Tis not needed yet.
paragraphs.translated: SEYTON$NEWLINE$You don’t need it yet.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I’ll put it on.$NEWLINE$Send out more horses. Skirr the country round.$NEWLINE$Hang those that talk of fear. Give me mine armor.$NEWLINE$How does your patient, doctor?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I’ll put it on anyway. Send out more cavalry. Scour the whole country and hang anyone spreading fear. Give me my armor. (to the DOCTOR) How is my wife, doctor?$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Not so sick, my lord,$NEWLINE$As she is troubled with thick-coming fancies$NEWLINE$That keep her from her rest.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$She is not sick, my lord, but she is troubled with endless visions that keep her from sleeping.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Cure her of that.$NEWLINE$Canst thou not minister to a mind diseased,$NEWLINE$Pluck from the memory a rooted sorrow,$NEWLINE$Raze out the written troubles of the brain$NEWLINE$And with some sweet oblivious antidote$NEWLINE$Cleanse the stuffed bosom of that perilous stuff$NEWLINE$Which weighs upon the heart?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Cure her of that. Can’t you treat a diseased mind? Take away her memory of sorrow? Use some drug to erase the troubling thoughts from her brain and ease her heart?

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Therein the patient$NEWLINE$Must minister to himself.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$For that kind of relief, the patient must heal herself.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Throw physic to the dogs; I’ll none of it.$NEWLINE$Come, put mine armor on. Give me my staff.$NEWLINE$Seyton, send out.—Doctor, the thanes fly from me.$NEWLINE$Come, sir, dispatch.—If thou couldst, doctor, cast$NEWLINE$The water of my land, find her disease,$NEWLINE$And purge it to a sound and pristine health,$NEWLINE$I would applaud thee to the very echo,$NEWLINE$That should applaud again.—Pull ’t off, I say.—$NEWLINE$What rhubarb, senna, or what purgative drug,$NEWLINE$Would scour these English hence? Hear’st thou of them?
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Medicine is for the dogs. I won’t have anything to do with it. (to SEYTON) Come, put my armor on me. Give me my lance. Seyton, send out the soldiers. (to the DOCTOR) Doctor, the thanes are running away from me. (to SEYTON) Come on, sir, hurry. (to the DOCTOR) Can you figure out what’s wrong with my country? If you can diagnose its disease by examining its urine, and bring it back to health, I will praise you to the ends of the Earth, where the sound will echo back so you can hear the applause again.—(to SEYTON) Pull it off, I tell you. (to the DOCTOR) What drug would purge the English from this country? Have you heard of any?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Ay, my good lord. Your royal preparation$NEWLINE$Makes us hear something.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$Yes, my good lord. Your preparation for war sounds like something.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Bring it after me.$NEWLINE$I will not be afraid of death and bane,$NEWLINE$Till Birnam Forest come to Dunsinane.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$(to SEYTON) Bring the armor and follow me. I will not be afraid of death and destruction until Birnam forest picks itself up and moves to Dunsinane.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$(aside) Were I from Dunsinane away and clear,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Profit again should hardly draw me here.
paragraphs.translated: DOCTOR$NEWLINE$(to himself) I wish I were far away from Dunsinane. You couldn’t pay me to come back here.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Drum and colors. Enter MALCOLM, SIWARD, MACDUFF, Siward’s SON, MENTEITH, CAITHNESS, ANGUS, LENNOX, ROSS, and SOLDIERS, marching$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$SIWARD$NEWLINE$MACDUFF$NEWLINE$SON$NEWLINE$MENTEITH$NEWLINE$CAITHNESS$NEWLINE$ANGUS$NEWLINE$LENNOX$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM, old SIWARD and his SON, MACDUFF, MENTEITH, CAITHNESS, ANGUS, LENNOX, ROSS, and SOLDIERS enter marching, with a drummer and flag.$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$SIWARD$NEWLINE$SON$NEWLINE$MACDUFF$NEWLINE$MENTEITH$NEWLINE$CAITHNESS$NEWLINE$ANGUS$NEWLINE$LENNOX$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Cousins, I hope the days are near at hand$NEWLINE$That chambers will be safe.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Kinsmen, I hope the time is coming when people will be safe in their own bedrooms.

paragraphs.original: MENTEITH$NEWLINE$We doubt it nothing.
paragraphs.translated: MENTEITH$NEWLINE$We don’t doubt it.

paragraphs.original: SIWARD$NEWLINE$What wood is this before us?
paragraphs.translated: SIWARD$NEWLINE$What’s the name of this forest behind us?

paragraphs.original: MENTEITH$NEWLINE$The wood of Birnam.
paragraphs.translated: MENTEITH$NEWLINE$Birnam Wood.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Let every soldier hew him down a bough$NEWLINE$And bear ’t before him. Thereby shall we shadow$NEWLINE$The numbers of our host and make discovery$NEWLINE$Err in report of us.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Tell every soldier to break off a branch and hold it in front of him. That way we can conceal how many of us there are, and Macbeth’s spies will give him inaccurate reports.

paragraphs.original: SOLDIERS$NEWLINE$It shall be done.
paragraphs.translated: SOLDIERS$NEWLINE$We’ll do it.

paragraphs.original: SIWARD$NEWLINE$We learn no other but the confident tyrant$NEWLINE$Keeps still in Dunsinane and will endure$NEWLINE$Our setting down before ’t.
paragraphs.translated: SIWARD$NEWLINE$We have no news except that the overconfident Macbeth is still in Dunsinane and will allow us to lay siege to the castle.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$'Tis his main hope:$NEWLINE$For, where there is advantage to be given,$NEWLINE$Both more and less have given him the revolt,$NEWLINE$And none serve with him but constrainèd things$NEWLINE$Whose hearts are absent too.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$He wants us to lay siege. Wherever his soldiers have an opportunity to leave him, they do, whatever rank they are. No one fights with him except men who are forced to, and their hearts aren’t in it.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Let our just censures$NEWLINE$Attend the true event, and put we on$NEWLINE$Industrious soldiership.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$We shouldn’t make any judgments until we achieve our goal. Let’s go fight like hardworking soldiers.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIWARD$NEWLINE$The time approaches$NEWLINE$That will with due decision make us know$NEWLINE$What we shall say we have and what we owe.$NEWLINE$Thoughts speculative their unsure hopes relate,$NEWLINE$But certain issue strokes must arbitrate.$NEWLINE$Towards which, advance the war.
paragraphs.translated: SIWARD$NEWLINE$Soon we’ll find out what’s really ours and what isn’t. It’s easy for us to get our hopes up just sitting around thinking about it, but the only way this is really going to be settled is by violence. So let’s move our armies forward.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt, marching
paragraphs.translated: They exit, marching.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter MACBETH, SEYTON, and SOLDIERS, with drum and colors$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$SEYTON$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH, SEYTON, and SOLDIERS enter with a drummer and flag.$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$SEYTON$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Hang out our banners on the outward walls.$NEWLINE$The cry is still “They come!” Our castle’s strength$NEWLINE$Will laugh a siege to scorn. Here let them lie$NEWLINE$Till famine and the ague eat them up.$NEWLINE$Were they not forced with those that should be ours,$NEWLINE$We might have met them dareful, beard to beard,$NEWLINE$And beat them backward home.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Hang our flags on the outer walls. Everyone keeps yelling, “Here they come!” Our castle is strong enough to laugh off their seige. They can sit out there until they die of hunger and disease. If it weren’t for the fact that so many of our soldiers revolted and joined them, we could have met them out in front of the castle, man to man, and beaten them back to England.

paragraphs.original: A cry within of women
paragraphs.translated: A sound of women crying offstage.

paragraphs.original: What is that noise?
paragraphs.translated: What’s that noise?

paragraphs.original: SEYTON$NEWLINE$It is the cry of women, my good lord.
paragraphs.translated: SEYTON$NEWLINE$It’s women crying, my good lord.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: SEYTON exits.$NEWLINE$SEYTON

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I have almost forgot the taste of fears.$NEWLINE$The time has been my senses would have cooled$NEWLINE$To hear a night-shriek, and my fell of hair$NEWLINE$Would at a dismal treatise rouse and stir$NEWLINE$As life were in ’t. I have supped full with horrors.$NEWLINE$Direness, familiar to my slaughterous thoughts$NEWLINE$Cannot once start me.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I’ve almost forgotten what fear feels like. There was a time when I would have been terrified by a shriek in the night, and the hair on my skin would have stood up when I heard a ghost story. But now I’ve had my fill of real horrors. Horrible things are so familiar that they can’t startle me.

paragraphs.original: Enter SEYTON$NEWLINE$SEYTON
paragraphs.translated: SEYTON comes back in.$NEWLINE$SEYTON

paragraphs.original: Wherefore was that cry?
paragraphs.translated: What was that cry for?

paragraphs.original: SEYTON$NEWLINE$The queen, my lord, is dead.
paragraphs.translated: SEYTON$NEWLINE$The queen is dead, my lord.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$She should have died hereafter.$NEWLINE$There would have been a time for such a word.$NEWLINE$Tomorrow, and tomorrow, and tomorrow,$NEWLINE$Creeps in this petty pace from day to day$NEWLINE$To the last syllable of recorded time,$NEWLINE$And all our yesterdays have lighted fools$NEWLINE$The way to dusty death. Out, out, brief candle!$NEWLINE$Life’s but a walking shadow, a poor player$NEWLINE$That struts and frets his hour upon the stage$NEWLINE$And then is heard no more. It is a tale$NEWLINE$Told by an idiot, full of sound and fury,$NEWLINE$Signifying nothing.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$She would have died later anyway. That news was bound to come someday. Tomorrow, and tomorrow, and tomorrow. The days creep slowly along until the end of time. And every day that’s already happened has taken fools that much closer to their deaths. Out, out, brief candle. Life is nothing more than an illusion. It’s like a poor actor who struts and worries for his hour on the stage and then is never heard from again. Life is a story told by an idiot, full of noise and emotional disturbance but devoid of meaning.

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: Thou comest to use$NEWLINE$Thy tongue; thy story quickly.
paragraphs.translated: You’ve come to tell me something. Tell me quickly.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Gracious my lord,$NEWLINE$I should report that which I say I saw,$NEWLINE$But know not how to do ’t.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$My gracious lord, I should tell you what I saw, but I don’t know how to say it.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Well, say, sir.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Just say it.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$As I did stand my watch upon the hill,$NEWLINE$I looked toward Birnam, and anon methought$NEWLINE$The wood began to move.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$As I was standing watch on the hill, I looked toward Birnam, and I thought I saw the forest begin to move.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Liar and slave!
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Liar and slave!

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Let me endure your wrath, if ’t be not so.$NEWLINE$Within this three mile may you see it coming;$NEWLINE$I say, a moving grove.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Punish me if it’s not true. Three miles from here you can see it coming, a moving forest.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$If thou speak’st false,$NEWLINE$Upon the next tree shall thou hang alive$NEWLINE$Till famine cling thee. If thy speech be sooth,$NEWLINE$I care not if thou dost for me as much.$NEWLINE$I pull in resolution and begin$NEWLINE$To doubt th' equivocation of the fiend$NEWLINE$That lies like truth. “Fear not, till Birnam wood$NEWLINE$Do come to Dunsinane”; and now a wood$NEWLINE$Comes toward Dunsinane.—Arm, arm, and out!—$NEWLINE$If this which he avouches does appear,$NEWLINE$There is nor flying hence nor tarrying here.$NEWLINE$I 'gin to be aweary of the sun,$NEWLINE$And wish th' estate o' th' world were now undone.—$NEWLINE$Ring the alarum-bell!—Blow, wind! Come, wrack!$NEWLINE$At least we’ll die with harness on our back.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$If you’re lying, I’ll hang you alive from the nearest tree until you die of hunger. If what you say is true, you can do the same to me. (to himself) My confidence is failing. I’m starting to doubt the lies the devil told me, which sounded like truth. “Don’t worry until Birnam Wood comes to Dunsinane.” And now a wood is coming to Dunsinane. Prepare for battle, and go! If what this messenger says is true, it’s no use running away or staying here. I’m starting to grow tired of living, and I’d like to see the world plunged into chaos. Ring the alarms! Blow, wind! Come, ruin! At least we’ll die with our armor on.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Drum and colors. Enter MALCOLM, SIWARD, MACDUFF, and their army, with boughs$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$SIWARD$NEWLINE$MACDUFF
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM, old SIWARD, MACDUFF, and their army enter carrying branches, with a drummer and flag.$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$SIWARD$NEWLINE$MACDUFF

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Now near enough. Your leafy screens throw down,$NEWLINE$And show like those you are.—You, worthy uncle,$NEWLINE$Shall, with my cousin, your right-noble son,$NEWLINE$Lead our first battle. Worthy Macduff and we$NEWLINE$Shall take upon ’s what else remains to do,$NEWLINE$According to our order.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$We’re close enough now. Throw down these branches and show them who you really are. Uncle Siward, you and your son will lead the first battle. Brave Macduff and I will do the rest, according to our battle plan.

paragraphs.original: SIWARD$NEWLINE$Fare you well.$NEWLINE$Do we but find the tyrant’s power tonight,$NEWLINE$Let us be beaten if we cannot fight.
paragraphs.translated: SIWARD$NEWLINE$Good luck. If we meet Macbeth’s army tonight, let us be beaten if we cannot fight.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Make all our trumpets speak; give them all breath,$NEWLINE$Those clamorous harbingers of blood and death.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Blow all the trumpets. They loudly announce the news of blood and death.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alarums. Enter MACBETH$NEWLINE$MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets and the noise of battle. MACBETH enters.$NEWLINE$MACBETH

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$They have tied me to a stake. I cannot fly,$NEWLINE$But, bearlike, I must fight the course. What’s he$NEWLINE$That was not born of woman? Such a one$NEWLINE$Am I to fear, or none.
paragraphs.translated:
MACBETH$NEWLINE$They have me tied to a stake. I can’t run away. I have to stand and fight, like a
bear.Where’s the man who wasn’t born from a woman? He’s the only one I’m afraid of, nobody else.$NEWLINE$bear$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter YOUNG SIWARD$NEWLINE$YOUNG$NEWLINE$SIWARD
paragraphs.translated: YOUNG SIWARD enters.$NEWLINE$YOUNG$NEWLINE$SIWARD

paragraphs.original: YOUNG SIWARD$NEWLINE$What is thy name?
paragraphs.translated: YOUNG SIWARD$NEWLINE$What’s your name?

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Thou 'lt be afraid to hear it.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$You’ll be afraid to hear it.

paragraphs.original: YOUNG SIWARD$NEWLINE$No, though thou call’st thyself a hotter name$NEWLINE$Than any is in hell.
paragraphs.translated: YOUNG SIWARD$NEWLINE$No I won’t, even if you were one of the worst demons in hell.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$My name’s Macbeth.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$My name’s Macbeth.

paragraphs.original: YOUNG SIWARD$NEWLINE$The devil himself could not pronounce a title$NEWLINE$More hateful to mine ear.
paragraphs.translated: YOUNG SIWARD$NEWLINE$The devil himself couldn’t say a name I hate more.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$No, nor more fearful.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$No, nor could the devil’s name be more frightening.

paragraphs.original: YOUNG SIWARD$NEWLINE$Thou liest, abhorrèd tyrant. With my sword$NEWLINE$I’ll prove the lie thou speak’st.
paragraphs.translated: YOUNG SIWARD$NEWLINE$You lie, you disgusting tyrant. I’ll prove with my sword that I’m not scared of you.

paragraphs.original: They fight and YOUNG SIWARD is slain$NEWLINE$YOUNG SIWARD
paragraphs.translated: They fight and YOUNG SIWARD is killed.$NEWLINE$YOUNG SIWARD

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Thou wast born of woman.$NEWLINE$But swords I smile at, weapons laugh to scorn,$NEWLINE$Brandished by man that’s of a woman born.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$You were born from a woman. Swords don’t frighten me. I laugh at any weapon used by a man who was born from a woman.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH exits.$NEWLINE$MACBETH

paragraphs.original: Alarums. Enter MACDUFF$NEWLINE$MACDUFF
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets and battle sounds. MACDUFF enters.$NEWLINE$MACDUFF

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$That way the noise is. Tyrant, show thy face!$NEWLINE$If thou beest slain, and with no stroke of mine,$NEWLINE$My wife and children’s ghosts will haunt me still.$NEWLINE$I cannot strike at wretched kerns, whose arms$NEWLINE$Are hired to bear their staves. Either thou, Macbeth,$NEWLINE$Or else my sword with an unbattered edge$NEWLINE$I sheathe again undeeded. There thou shouldst be;$NEWLINE$By this great clatter, one of the greatest note$NEWLINE$Seems bruited. Let me find him, Fortune,$NEWLINE$And more I beg not.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$The noise is coming from over there. Tyrant, show your face! If someone other than me kills you, the ghosts of my wife and children will haunt me forever. I can’t be bothered to fight these lame soldiers who only fight for money. I’ll either fight you, Macbeth, or else I’ll put down my sword unused. You must be over there. By the great noise, it sounds like one of the highest-ranking men is being announced. I hope I find him! I ask for nothing more than that.

paragraphs.original: Exit. Alarums
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF exits. More battle noises.$NEWLINE$MACDUFF

paragraphs.original: Enter MALCOLM and SIWARD$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$SIWARD
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM and old SIWARD enter.$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$SIWARD

paragraphs.original: SIWARD$NEWLINE$This way, my lord. The castle’s gently rendered.$NEWLINE$The tyrant’s people on both sides do fight,$NEWLINE$The noble thanes do bravely in the war,$NEWLINE$The day almost itself professes yours,$NEWLINE$And little is to do.
paragraphs.translated: SIWARD$NEWLINE$Come this way, my lord. The castle has been surrendered without a fight. Macbeth’s soldiers are fighting on both sides. Our noblemen are battling bravely. The victory is almost yours, and it seems like there’s not much left to do.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$We have met with foes$NEWLINE$That strike beside us.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Our enemies fight as if they’re trying not to hurt us.

paragraphs.original: SIWARD$NEWLINE$Enter, sir, the castle.
paragraphs.translated: SIWARD$NEWLINE$Sir, enter the castle.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt. Alarums
paragraphs.translated: They exit. Battle noises continue.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter MACBETH$NEWLINE$MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH enters.$NEWLINE$MACBETH

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Why should I play the Roman fool and die$NEWLINE$On mine own sword? Whiles I see lives, the gashes$NEWLINE$Do better upon them.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Why should I commit suicide like one of the ancient Romans? As long as I see enemies of mine alive, I would rather see my sword wound them than me.

paragraphs.original: Enter MACDUFF$NEWLINE$MACDUFF
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF enters.$NEWLINE$MACDUFF

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Turn, hellhound, turn!
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Turn around, you dog from hell, turn around!

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Of all men else I have avoided thee.$NEWLINE$But get thee back. My soul is too much charged$NEWLINE$With blood of thine already.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$You are the only man I have avoided. But go away now. I’m already guilty of killing your whole family.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I have no words.$NEWLINE$My voice is in my sword. Thou bloodier villain$NEWLINE$Than terms can give thee out!
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$I have nothing to say to you. My sword will talk for me. You are too evil for words!

paragraphs.original: They fight
paragraphs.translated: They fight.

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Thou losest labor.$NEWLINE$As easy mayst thou the intrenchant air$NEWLINE$With thy keen sword impress as make me bleed.$NEWLINE$Let fall thy blade on vulnerable crests;$NEWLINE$I bear a charmèd life, which must not yield$NEWLINE$To one of woman born.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$You’re wasting your time trying to wound me. You might as well try to stab the air with your sword. Go fight someone who can be harmed. I lead a charmed life, which can’t be ended by anyone born from a woman.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Despair thy charm,$NEWLINE$And let the angel whom thou still hast served$NEWLINE$Tell thee, Macduff was from his mother’s womb$NEWLINE$Untimely ripped.
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$You can forget about your charm. The evil spirit you serve can tell you that I was not born. They cut me out of my mother’s womb before she could bear me naturally.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Accursèd be that tongue that tells me so,$NEWLINE$For it hath cowed my better part of man!$NEWLINE$And be these juggling fiends no more believed,$NEWLINE$That palter with us in a double sense,$NEWLINE$That keep the word of promise to our ear,$NEWLINE$And break it to our hope. I’ll not fight with thee.
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$Curse you for telling me this. You’ve fightened away my courage. I don’t believe those evil creatures anymore. They tricked me with their wordgames, raising my hopes and then destroying them. I won’t fight you.

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Then yield thee, coward,$NEWLINE$And live to be the show and gaze o' th' time.$NEWLINE$We’ll have thee, as our rarer monsters are,$NEWLINE$Painted on a pole, and underwrit,$NEWLINE$“Here may you see the tyrant.”
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Then surrender, coward, and we’ll put you in a freakshow, just like they do with deformed animals. We’ll put a picture of you on a sign, right above the words “Come see the tyrant!”

paragraphs.original: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I will not yield,$NEWLINE$To kiss the ground before young Malcolm’s feet,$NEWLINE$And to be baited with the rabble’s curse.$NEWLINE$Though Birnam Wood be come to Dunsinane,$NEWLINE$And thou opposed, being of no woman born,$NEWLINE$Yet I will try the last. Before my body$NEWLINE$I throw my warlike shield. Lay on, Macduff,$NEWLINE$And damned be him that first cries, “Hold, enough!”
paragraphs.translated: MACBETH$NEWLINE$I’m not going to surrender and have to kiss the ground in front of Malcolm, or be taunted by the common people. Even though Birnam Wood really did come to Dunsinane, and I’m fighting a man not of woman born, I’ll fight to the end. I’ll put up my shield and battle you. Come on, let’s go at it, Macduff, and damn the first man who cries, 'Stop! Enough!'

paragraphs.original: Exeunt, fighting. Alarums. They enter fighting, and MACBETH slain. Retreat. Flourish. Enter, with drum and colors MALCOLM, SIWARD, ROSS, THANES, and SOLDIERS$NEWLINE$MACBETH$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$SIWARD$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$THANES$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS
paragraphs.translated: They exit fighting. Trumpets and battle noises. The trumpet of one army sounds a call to retreat. The other army’s trumpet sounds a call of victory. The victorious army enters, led by MALCOLM, old SIWARD, ROSS, the other THANES, and soldiers, with a drummer and flag.$NEWLINE$MALCOLM$NEWLINE$SIWARD$NEWLINE$ROSS$NEWLINE$THANES

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$I would the friends we miss were safe arrived.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$I wish all of our friends could have survived this battle.

paragraphs.original: SIWARD$NEWLINE$Some must go off. And yet, by these I see,$NEWLINE$So great a day as this is cheaply bought.
paragraphs.translated: SIWARD$NEWLINE$In every battle, some people will always be killed, but judging from the men I see around us, our great victory didn’t cost us very much.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Macduff is missing, and your noble son.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$Macduff is missing, and so is your noble son.

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Your son, my lord, has paid a soldier’s debt.$NEWLINE$He only lived but till he was a man,$NEWLINE$The which no sooner had his prowess confirmed$NEWLINE$In the unshrinking station where he fought,$NEWLINE$But like a man he died.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$My lord, your son has paid the soldier’s price: death. He only lived long enough to become a man, and as soon as he proved that he was a man by fighting like one, he died.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SIWARD$NEWLINE$Then he is dead?
paragraphs.translated: SIWARD$NEWLINE$So he’s dead?

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Ay, and brought off the field. Your cause of sorrow$NEWLINE$Must not be measured by his worth, for then$NEWLINE$It hath no end.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$Yes, and he’s been carried off the field. Your grief should not be equal to his worth, because then your sorrow would never end.

paragraphs.original: SIWARD$NEWLINE$Had he his hurts before?
paragraphs.translated: SIWARD$NEWLINE$Were his wounds on his front side?

paragraphs.original: ROSS$NEWLINE$Ay, on the front.
paragraphs.translated: ROSS$NEWLINE$Yes, on his front.

paragraphs.original: SIWARD$NEWLINE$Why then, God’s soldier be he!$NEWLINE$Had I as many sons as I have hairs,$NEWLINE$I would not wish them to a fairer death.$NEWLINE$And so, his knell is knolled.
paragraphs.translated: SIWARD$NEWLINE$Well then, he’s God’s soldier now! If I had as many sons as I have hairs on my head, I couldn’t hope that any of them would die more honorably than he did. And that’s all there is to it.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$He’s worth more sorrow,$NEWLINE$And that I’ll spend for him.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$He is worth more mourning than that, and I will mourn for him.

paragraphs.original: SIWARD$NEWLINE$He’s worth no more.$NEWLINE$They say he parted well and paid his score.$NEWLINE$And so, God be with him! Here comes newer comfort.
paragraphs.translated: SIWARD$NEWLINE$He is worth no more than that. They tell me he died well, and settled his scores. With that, I hope God is with him! Here comes better news.

paragraphs.original: Enter MACDUFF with MACBETH’s head$NEWLINE$MACDUFF$NEWLINE$MACBETH
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF enters, carrying MACBETH’s head.$NEWLINE$MACDUFF$NEWLINE$MACBETH

paragraphs.original: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Hail, king! For so thou art. Behold where stands$NEWLINE$The usurper’s cursèd head. The time is free.$NEWLINE$I see thee compassed with thy kingdom’s pearl,$NEWLINE$That speak my salutation in their minds,$NEWLINE$Whose voices I desire aloud with mine.$NEWLINE$Hail, King of Scotland!
paragraphs.translated: MACDUFF$NEWLINE$Hail, king! Because that’s what you are now. Look, here I have Macbeth’s cursed head. We are free from his tyranny. I see that you have the kingdom’s noblemen around you, and they’re thinking the same thing as me. I want them to join me in this loud cheer, Hail, King of Scotland!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Hail, King of Scotland!
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Hail, King of Scotland!

paragraphs.original: Flourish
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play.

paragraphs.original: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$We shall not spend a large expense of time$NEWLINE$Before we reckon with your several loves$NEWLINE$And make us even with you. My thanes and kinsmen,$NEWLINE$Henceforth be earls, the first that ever Scotland$NEWLINE$In such an honor named. What’s more to do,$NEWLINE$Which would be planted newly with the time,$NEWLINE$As calling home our exiled friends abroad$NEWLINE$That fled the snares of watchful tyranny,$NEWLINE$Producing forth the cruel ministers$NEWLINE$Of this dead butcher and his fiendlike queen,$NEWLINE$Who, as ’tis thought, by self and violent hands$NEWLINE$Took off her life; this, and what needful else$NEWLINE$That calls upon us, by the grace of Grace,$NEWLINE$We will perform in measure, time, and place.$NEWLINE$So, thanks to all at once and to each one,$NEWLINE$Whom we invite to see us crowned at Scone.
paragraphs.translated: MALCOLM$NEWLINE$It won’t be long before I reward each of you as he deserves. My thanes and kinsmen, I name you all earls, the first earls that Scotland has ever had. We have a lot to do at the dawn of this new era. We must call home all of our exiled friends who fled from the grip of Macbeth’s tyranny, and we must bring to justice all the evil ministers of this dead butcher and his demon-like queen, who, rumor has it, committed suicide. This, and whatever else we are called to do by God, we will do at the right time and in the right place. So I thank you all, and I invite each and every one of you to come watch me be crowned king of Scotland at Scone.

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play. They all exit.
